McMurphy epitomizes a heroic figure, without the normal qualities of a paladin, in an unheroic setting and circumstances (and in this case the most unlikely of places, a mental ward).  The acting is unbelievable not just by Fletcher (superb!) and Nicholson (who will never surpass his effort here) but the entire cast (featuring unknown at the time talents like Danny Devito and Christopher Lloyd).The story is outstanding, the dialogue compelling and of course the memorable scenes.  Who could forget the `invisible' World Series', the boat trip in which McMurphy introduces the patients as `doctors' to a suspicious harbor master and as the camera shows each, we are given a vivid portrait of the fine line between sanity and insanity, and the dreadful confrontation between the newly empowered Billy and the insidious Nurse Ratched that ends so tragic. Two scenes stand out particularly, where Chief reveals that he can hear and speak and of course the great, great ending!  It is a paradoxical finale to say the least.  Who could not be saddened as the Chief bravely shows all the mercy he can in saving McMurphy from a living death and who could not be inspired as he tosses the fountain through the window. An all time classic!

This is the story of Randle Patrick McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) as he enters a mental institution. In the institution, he meets Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher), a cruel, unyielding nurse who makes life unbearable for the patients. After McMurphy has a few run ins with Ratched, he is sent for shock treatments, and war breaks out on ward.This is an intense movie with some great performances all around. It is creepy and has all the earmarks of a great movie. The soundtrack is great, and the script is good.I give this movie an eight out of ten because of the stellar performances and the great plot!
When this came out. I saw it at the cinema. I saw it 3 times during its 2 week run. To say that I was affected is an understatement. A defining moment in cinema in the 1970's.

I have to say, even the old movies decades ago. The design of the plot, the language of the music, and the lens are all perfect.
The strange music at the beginning can already attract people. In a short period of time, the shaping of several major characters was reflected. Milk's characters: delusional, lively and unruly. The strictness of the head nurse also has many patient characteristics. The characters is full erected.
At the same time , the plot advances while going fishing. Freedom, life, who would think of group mental illness?
During the meeting, Milk was a little puzzled when he learned that most people entered voluntarily. Mental illness, who will rush to do it? What's wrong wirh society, still......
With the appearance of Milk, this peaceful place was broken and the small society changed. So Milk must disappear. No matter whether he is active or passive. Ok the initiative failed. So, he's dead. The lively, unruly Milk disappeared, leaving only an obedient child.
The chief who pulls up the drinking fountain and seeks the so-called freedom, hope Carrying that Milk's ideal may be like the last scene of the lens:darkness. Nothing more

Two Words: Jack Nicholson. You'll learn to care and feel for J.P. McMurphy during watching this film. The actors all around him are also excellent. It's not the Winning Oscars that get my attention, it's the great acting and great story that's unique, touching, real to life, and frightening.

Anticipation 2

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest movies ever made
reviews.content: Everything about this movie is amazing, breathtaking. Nurse Ratched is perhaps one of the greatest and yet most underrated movie villains in cinema history; power-hungry, controlling, and tyrannical, she stops at nothing to prevent McMurphy from bringing joy, or to a degree, the real world into the lives of these detained misfits. Nicholson is the perfect rebel, one has to wonder whether he is truly crazy, or so sane he can no longer take the insanity of the medical staff and establishment. This movie is as close to perfect as i've ever seen. One of only three movies to win the big five academy awards, this movie is most certainly my favorite. Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher deliver, the sound and cinematography are remarkable and the supporting cast is flawless.

Jack Nicholson when he was on his game, was amazing to watch. Such a charismatic and unique individual, with a sharp sense of humour and sarcasm. Can you imagine anyone else as Jack Torrance (The Shining)
One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest was another example of Nicholson on peak form. And Randle McMurphy is a character that I'm sure many of us can relate to. I know I do.Excellent dark humoured psychological drama, which is both funny and tragic. Great script and cast, direction, soundtrack, the lot. I've watched this movie numerous times, and it hasn't lost any of it's magic.Classic Nicholson. And a classic film.

reviews.review_title: one of the the greatest films ever made
reviews.content: this movie ,simply put is the greatest drama ever made.the cast is so superb that one cannot believe it.jack nicholson gives his best performance,period.and that is saying a LOT.not to mention that louise fletcher plays the most chilling villain that film has ever seen.in the scene in which a character gets dragged off, stuttering like a madman literally sends chills down your back. saying any more would be giving away the plot to one of the great films of all time. seeing this movie will move you, uplift you , and also make you think "one flew over the cukoo's nest" will do that to you.

reviews.review_title: Redemption and the power mad woman.
reviews.content: Based on R1 DVD 134 minutes.I recall being very impressed with this movie during its original cinema release, now 25 years later I have the chance to enjoy it again on DVD.The main theme of inmate being wiser than the doctors is convincing, especially in the relationship between McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) and Chief. All the crazy actors give good to very good performances. The film has many touching and humorous moments while avoiding sentimentality.Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) is a fine example of female abuse of power, she is spiteful, cold and intelligent. Given an opportunity she is prepared to inflict considerable pain on her defenseless male charges.The movie fails to make my 'all time great' list but it is worth visiting or revisiting if you have the chance.7/10

reviews.review_title: Funny but still touching movie about how raw Human race can be.
reviews.content: I've seen a lot of movies. And by a lot I mean A lot. Never have I felt like i did when watching One Flew Over The Cuckoos Nest. Kind of late commenting it now but this movie is one of a kind. I am a big fan of Sci-fi, Star Wars, The Matrix etc. One Flew Over The Cuckoos Nest Is the best movie EVER made. If you haven't seen you probably know something about it. When you start watch you understand from the beginning that this movie ain't going to have a "happy" ending. I laugh when jokes are made but i also feel sad because I can guess from what i've heard and by what I see what's going to happen. And finally it does.Don't just walk around and think for yourself that someday, someday I am going to take the time and watch it. Just do IT, NOW! I wont write about the story, you either find it out by yourself or just don't mind knowing. You just don't need to know.//Viktor from Sweden

reviews.review_title: one of the best movies ever
reviews.content: Every movie fanatic has to see this. It's not my personal favorite, but it is one of the ones I respect the most. The acting, directing and story are what makes it great. It's often sad, and often funny. It's much better than "Saving Private Ryan", or "Titanic" (which sucked, by the way).A definite classic.

I just watched "One Flew" for the first time in 30 years, having seen it in the theater as a kid way back in 1975, when I was ten years old. It definitely holds up well, although there's no doubt that Nicholson's performance makes the film. Without him, you can easily see how many scenes would drag and be downright boring.One thing I noticed upon viewing, is that Nurse Ratched isn't nearly the mean nurse she is made out to be whenever this film is discussed. Sure, she seems to have a "fakeness" many times when she caters to the mental patients, but she really isn't that bad at all. It isn't until the end, when she threatens Billy with telling his mother he slept with the girl, knowing he has suicidal tendencies, that she seems wicked. But until then, she really isn't so bad.And nothing against Louise Fletcher, who does a decent job at playing Nurse Ratched, but winning best actress? For what? She pretty much never really does anything more here than give icy stares, and while she certainly played the part well, it really had to be a very weak year in the "Best Actress" category. She's a very decent actress as we've seen in her other films, but she just doesn't have to do much here at all. Ratched even looks kind of hot sometimes, and her fellow nurse, whatever her name is, is very hot indeed. She is definitely something nice to look at whenever the film tends to drag a bit. It is also fun picking out the 70's cars in the outdoors scenes, when the film is set in '63. The Pinto and Duster are great! The appearance of Scatman Crothers was a surprise as I completely forgot he was in the film, and his scenes led to some (probably unintentionally) funny sequences with The Scatman doing his thing.But this is definitely better than most films of the time, mainly because Jack Nicholson is just so darn good. This isn't something I'd be in a rush to see again, but one viewing is good, and the deleted scenes on the DVD were interesting.

One Flew Over is an amazing book/movie combo in that both pieces interact somewhat, but stand on their own well.  The book is amazing and well worth the read.  The movie is different enough in point of view and events to make it stand on its own.Nicholson is, as almost always, incredible in the McMurphy character. It's amazing that you can laugh at something in one scene ("Little dab'll do ya, huh?") and then see the results of this same character in the final scenes. The character of Chief is perfectly portrayed, and in fact every patient comes through with his or her character intact.It's also great to watch!  Truly a classic.  5.0/5.0 stars.

Jack Nicholson turns in his finest performance of all time as con Randle McMurphy. McMurphy doesn't like prison life so he decides to get a transfer to the mental institution, pretending to be a nut, for a cushier life. Halt! Enter Nurse Mildred Ratchett (Louise Fletcher) who grinds McMurphy down until he ends up labotamised and turned into a live cabbage. Not before Nicholson takes the patients on a fishing trip, throws a party in the ward with women and plenty of booze and of course his world series rant, where he commentates on the world series after nurse ratchett won't allow the patients to watch the game like she said she would. A great movie directed by Czech Milos Foreman, which was the movie Jack Nicholson was born to star in. Also an impressive supporting cast Christopher Lloyd and Danny De Vito spring to mind.

This film is simply superb! Jack Nicholson "SHINES" as R P McMurphy with a cast of fellow actors to die for. Scatman Crothers as "Orderly Turkle" and Brad Dourif as "Billy Bibbit" from the Exorcist 3 lend support, humour and tragedy to this greatest of films. My only further comment is- Get off the Internet, found out where to borrow or buy it and watch it!..........Now

reviews.review_title: Very worthy, but something seems to be missing - realism?
reviews.content: This is a very worthy movie, dealing with the important issue of free will against authority.  It's inspiring, humorous and mostly satisfying.Something rings false though.  When is the movie supposed to take place? From the fashions I would guess the 70s, though the book might say different.  My (limited) knowledge of working with psychiatric patients indicates that while there did use to be abusive treatment (like electroconvulsive therapy given for the wrong reasons rather than for serious depression) this was over by the 1950s.  In particular, nobody got psychosurgery (like poor old Randall) later than the 1950s.  Maybe it was different in the US, or maybe I just didn't know about abuses like this. Also, I find it hard to believe that psychiatric patients would be the kind of people who are so beaten down by authority that all they need is to be shown a different way of being to be "cured".  It certainly wouldn't be like that nowadays.If the film is describing the past that's fine, but it seems to me to lose a lot of its power and urgency. However apart from that, everything else was excellent.  All the actors were quite outstanding, and Jack Nicholson was awesome.  There is one point about three quarters of the way through the movie where the camera is on his face for a long time, maybe 30 seconds, and you watch his expression change through about five emotions on camera (wicked sense of humour, indifference, pain, thoughtfulness and tiredness, or something like).  Wow!The film is extremely highly rated (as well as having won the 5 major oscars), so maybe I'm just out of line in carping about realism.

reviews.review_title: Greatest comedy drama ever made. Nicholson's best acting.
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest must be recognized as one of the best comedy dramas in existance.The acting, the directing, and the writing are far better then any Academy Award can notice. Jack Nicholson was at his best in this film and made R.P. McMurphy one the most notable and quotable characters in movie history. Louise Fletcher portrayed one of the best villians of that era. And who could forget the cheif and his Juicy Fruit. Along with one of the best supporting casts to be assembled, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is definilty a favorite of movie lovers past, present, and future.

I love the psychological ride that I took watching this movie. I laughed, I cried and I could feel the anger for Nurse Ratched throughout the entire film. It is so hard to take her condescending attitude. It is so sad what they used to do to people in psyche wards! This film truly shows that. An astonishing masterpiece. I loved it. Every minute of it. I love how McmMurphy caused chaos, but in a good way. He brought them happiness.Nurse Ratched resented how he could have more control over them, because they liked him and that was certainly intriguing to see. The ending is sad, truly sad, but life cannot be all full of happy endings. Not everyone has a happy ending. At least one cuckoo gets out. One of my favorite movies for sure.

Many people who want to cheat the system fail in succeeding, for example Randal Mc Murphy, from the movie "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's nest", tries to pass as a mentally ill patient but only ends with his death. As many movies have symbols that a reader can connect to, moral values are shown to make a movie meaningful ass well the movie can also have two characters which personalities stand out, and show a theme embraced by the actors, thus, creating a classic that will be shown to future generations for its values shown in the movie. From birth many parents teach their children moral values: Do not steal, no profanity, and always tell the truth, these are a few examples that can be used and remembered into shaping child's mind, later on creating a good citizen. As well as the opposite, some may not have had the chance to have a parental figure in their life so they can grow up emotionless and can end up a psychotic killer or a murderer(like Mc Murphy). In the movie, Mc Murphy lies his way through life and throughout his jail sentence and the mental ward showing how he only thinks about himself and always tries to beat the judicial system. As the lies continue to spread, Mc Murphy also manipulates the other patients and takes away their "treats" a manipulation that Nurse Ratched observes. Throughout the movie his behavior changes slightly as he shares the happiness of being free with his fellow friends from the mental ward. As moral values have been lost for Mc Murphy, the nurse Ratched has built a mental ward from values that create a friendly atmosphere and a place where communication is widely accepted. Nurse Ratched is the type of person who believes that all people are good or have good in them, and if they are mislead by vices or bad habits she can help them to a better path. As a nurturer, she takes care and lookouts for all the patients in the ward, even Mc Murphy. In the movie Nurse Ratched is viewed as the supreme authority, a figure that Mc Murphy is attracted to but at the same time despises a figure that Mc Murphy always tries to cheat and lie to. Mc Murphy can be viewed as the common thief, one who breaks all the rules, a rebel, a person who defies the authority and at the same time tries to cheat the justice system. A type of person who always looks for the easy way out, a person who through his behavior makes him always ends up with conflict with the authorities; he is also, in my opinion, a person who many people want to be but have a fear of being that person. Due to moral values and how society views these "rebels" the type of behavior Mc Murphy shows is repressed in us. His behavior makes him have an assault-battery-rape convict that makes him find an alternate choice to finishing his jail sentence. His behavior then changes to a caring friend, a friend who the whole ward admires, an admiration that made the Chief (the mute) talk. With these new friendships he puts all his attention on the Chief; he is the only person that understands Mc Murphy and also wants to be free from the ward, the medicine, and especially the other patients. The theme is based on how cheating the system can never happen without worse consequences happening. An act that punishes the person who tries to beat or cheat the system, for example, Mc Murphy, his jail sentence was actually made longer because his stay in the mental ward would be for life. As he finally understood how his plan fell apart he did not use his judgment but instead went on an impulse to flee from the ward. A thought that Mc Murphy could not stand, a thought that made him make foolish decisions to jeopardize his plan of escape. As time comes and goes, the moral values that have been shown throughout the movie will forever stay with me. The lesson learned here can make me choose between learning from Mc Murphy's mistake or learning the hard way and ending up dead from the foolish choice of trying to beat the system. The characters created an environment that in an odd way I related to them by showing how Mc Murphy is part of me that is trapped inside held by a conscience and high moral values that were thought to me.

One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest must be regarded as one of the best films of the 70s, if not all time. Jack Nicholson is at his absolute peak as Randle, the film's lead character. The film revolves around a pyschiatric ward and captures the sheer brutality that used to be witnessed in such places. The supporting cast is outstanding, very believable performances coming from those playing patients. Danny De Vito especially is very convincing in his portrayal of somebody with mental difficulties. Nicholson steals the show however as the wisecracking con trying to fake a mental illness in the mistaken belief that the ward will be easier than prison. The first half of the film is very upbeat and entertaining, the second sees things unravel spectacularly, leading to a very sad ending. There is nothing wrong with One Flew, its everything that a film should be. Rather than taking the usual Hollywood cop-out of a schmaltzy happy ending the film tries something much more rewarding. Full marks to all involved with the picture, its a credit to movie-making.

Jack Nicholson gives an Academy Award winning performance as a cynic who decides to go into a mental institution as opposed to going to prison.  I don't want to give away all the details, but as you would assume, the stay in the mental institution changes Nicholson.  Look for excellent performances by some classic TV stars, as well as an Oscar winning performance by Louise Fletcher, who plays the infamous nurse. 
Although this movie can be very depressing, it has funny moments, and is definitely a movie that is worth seeing.  I strongly recommend "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest."

reviews.review_title: The Movie which can drive you mad and make you sad
reviews.content: A small Hospital with a bunch of fifty crazy guys, an arrogant and callous nurse, a convict who enters this MAD PLACE with lot of thrill and anticipation in his face and a low lighting environment. What do you expect?Let me cut it short. If you watch this movie alone you won't be able to smile for the next three hours .(Period)The characters are so intensely crafted by the director. You can feel the madness that our protagonist experiences in this 'Cuckoo's nest'. We can judge a movie by 3H parameter (Proud to say that I am the guru who invented it), Happiness, Hope and Hate. This Movie satisfies all the three.Happy for our chief flying over the cuckoo's nest Hope, when we see the smiling faces of the inmates and Hate that develops towards the arrogant nurse.

Movies come and go. Some touch you - some don't.This one will touch you - I promise. And it will stand forever as a movie classic. Milos Foreman's and Jack Nicholson's best movie so far.A masterpiece of a movie. Rating 10 of 10.

The movie is perhaps more comedy and entertainment than drama. Still that doesn't mean that the movie isn't filled with some powerful emotional acting. The tension between the patients and the staff becomes obvious and grows throughout the movie, which eventually leads to a tremendous ending. The supporting cast, Louise Fletcher, Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd, and Brad Dourif also give terrific performances. Danny, Christopher, and Brad's careers took off from this classic movie. It's all sentimental, funny, dramatic, intense, chilling, disturbing, diverting, and tragic. The finale leaves the viewer stunned and sitting there thinking about what he just saw.I think you will find, its one of the best movies of its time.

This movie is just sheer brilliance.  Starring Louise Fletcher and Jack Nicholson, One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is a brilliant capture of people trying to make it by in a havoc mental hospital life.  If you liked the book, you'll love the movie.  8.6 out of 10!

reviews.review_title: Jack Nicholson plays McMurphy as if he were born to it in this hilarious and heartbreaking classic.
reviews.content: McMurphy is an Irish-American brawler found culpable of battery and gambling. He is a Korean War veteran who was also held as a prisoner of war. He is sentenced to a fairly short prison term, and decides to have himself declared insane in order to be shifted to a mental institution, where he expects to serve the rest of his time in comfort and luxury.Randle Patrick McMurphy appears on the well-organized and claustrophobic scene of the psychiatric ward like a bolt from the blue in the movie, "One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest." He is a sharp-witted, elegant, aggressive, and an energetic person who always challenges the status quo from day one. He introduces himself to all and sundry in the ward, shakes hands and fills the silence with loud laughter. He is perhaps not mentally ill; he has chosen to be sent to the psychiatric hospital because he did not like to work on the prison farm, where he had six months to go before his discharge. The desirability of the psychiatric hospital for him was the idea of enjoying better food and a trouble-free lifestyle. This is not exactly what he actually gets.McMurphy has brought a touch of normalcy in the general atmosphere of the ward with his sense of humor and rebellious voice. He instantly engages in a long, hopeless, and endless battle with a "Big Nurse". What Nurse Ratched wants is a group of passive and silent men who do not offend or query how she has ordered things. It is their incarceration, voluntary or otherwise, upon which her job and role in life depends. Hence, McMurphy is the ultimate threat—a nonconformist who encourages the residents into a desire for action. He provokes them up out of the lifelessness and dullness in which they have been dwelling. In fact, he provides them with the creation of a treatment to their problems. The more victorious McMurphy is at disturbing the status quo, the more severe the battle becomes between him and Nurse Ratched. McMurphy is a very funny character but the humor ends when he discovers that Big Nurse has complete control over his fate—over what treatment he receives and when he is discharged. What starts as a boisterous mutiny against authority becomes a calamity. McMurphy is repetitively subjected to electric shock therapy. He manages to joke about it and to gather the strength to arrange a fishing expedition for some of the men. Finally, he makes a plan to escape one night but before that he invites everyone to a night of drinking and partying in the ward. The drunken orgy, complete with prostitutes, turns into a debacle and becomes the cause of his demise. Big Nurse comes to know about the party and sends him for electro-shock treatment. He returns lobotomized, as a human vegetable, after the therapy. All the lights in his bright mind and brave personality have been extinguished due to continual electro-shock therapy. Afterwards, his trusted friend "Chief" asphyxiates him with a pillow and saves half-living McMurphy from sinking into a vegetative existence. In spite of his final degradation to a vegetative state, he wins the fight for freedom that he has fought so courageously.

reviews.review_title: A great heartwarming film like no other
reviews.content: I am a big Oscar 'Best Picture' buff and I was seeking out to see all the winners. When I saw this movie at the video stores- I laughed and wondered how can a movie like that win best picture? I reluctantly got it and watched it last out of the two others- Midnight Cowboy and Amadeus. One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest was better than the first two I have seen and better than tons of films. I was suprised at how funny a movie like this could be but it was. Tons of different people/personalities- all together for this special film. Jack Nicholson played his role great and so did many others (my personal favorite was Chief)- and this movie makes the viewers laugh, cry, cheer, excited, and most of all, interested. The best of the best of comedic dramas is in this movie.Out of four stars- I give it a 3 3/4

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is movie directed by Milos Forman. It is about a man named Randle Patrick McMurphy, a character played amazingly by Jack Nicholson, who is on a trail bases on a mental hospital so they can evaluate him if he is crazy or not. It was McMurphy scheme to be in that place so he doesn't have to go to prison. He met few people there and showed them a very good time. Is trail was over and the doctors had concluded that he is not crazy but Nurse Ratchet, played by Louise Fletcher, thought otherwise and suggested that he should stay so they can heal him. While in the institution he met a deaf huge Indian named Chief Bromden, played by Will Sampson. Later he found out that McMurphy found out that he was faking it. Together they planed an escape. Mcmurphy had a late night party for his farewell. Soon after enjoying they all passed out and Billy Bibbit played by Brad Dourif slept with a party girl Candy. Nurse was very upset and angered and threatened to call billy's mother. Billy in anger committed suicide. Rage took over McMurphy and he tried to choke Nurse Ratchet, but was unsuccessful and after that moment McMurphy became mentally ill due to the death of Billy.The film is rated R but kid who have the knowledge of bad word can enjoy this film. The movie has a funny theme at the start but then changed to serious with a little drama after the party. The acting done by people in this movie is superb. Many actors and actress had a career defying role and became very famous people. It won 5 Oscar including the Best Actor in a Leading Role, Best Actress in a Leading Role Best Director and Best Picture and had many other wins.It was a great movie and is must watch by all

I saw this film when it first came out nearly 40 years ago, and the impact it had on me then has remained with me to this day. It saddens me that some people have been so obtuse as to score a 1 simply because it doesn't "stick to the book". This site is about 'films' and really the whole army can't be out of step (witness the overall 8.8 score despite its detractors). Treatment of mental health has moved on a lot since this film was made, but this film brought to light the type of horrors that were happening in the 70's. An absolute classic, combining humour, pathos and hope.Jack Nicholson's name became synonymous with the film and, with the exception of "The Shining", it is probably the film for which he is best known. As the self-committed 'lunatic' who sets about changing the lives of the other patients in an asylum, his wacky charm and disregard for authority seem to epitomise the characteristics of the different roles he has played over the years.

This film is a classic and there is nothing negative about the film at all. It'a shocking, it's funny and IT's POWERFUL like everybody says it is.When I saw this film, at times I was gripping my chair as if something amazing was going to happen and then at other memorable moments I just laughed out loud.The story is inspired by the novel which was written up in the 60's (I think).Besides a true, strong plot, the film has an excellent cast. Jack Nicolson (Batman, The Shining, The Departed), Bard Dourif (Child's Play), Danny Devito (Matilda, Twins), Michael Berryman (Hills Have Eyes) and many more excellent, memorable actors.i have watched this film three times this year and I have to say it never gets boring and it never gets old.A True Masterpiecie of a Classic in my eyes. 10/10

reviews.review_title: One of the Greatest Movies Ever
reviews.content: Need I say more?  The acting, the directing, the screenplay, the cinematography.  It's so superb I am lost for words.  Jack Nicholson displays arguably his best acting performance, next to movies such as Chinatown, The Shining, and About Schmidt.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is an absolutely fantastic film but I have one issue with it that is kind of hard to look past. I read the book before I watched the movie and when I do that I try really hard to keep my opinions on the two mediums separate. I understand that what works well in a book can't work for a film and vice versa. The movie is a really great adaptation. All the performances are fantastic (especially Jack Nicholson's) and it just looks really great. But, and here's my issue, the ending of the movie doesn't fit. And by ending I mean that literal last scene where Chief Bromden kills R.P. McMurphy and escapes. Now, the scene plays out exactly like it does in the book which was great to watch but it just doesn't fit with the movie. One thing they changed was the point of view. The book is told from Chief's point of view and is ultimately his story of how he grows through watching R.P. McMurphy. The movie, on the other hand, is changed to be R.P. McMurphy's story. But the ending is the same. The movie, which is about McMurphy, ends with Chief's redemption. If they just fixed the ending to fit better with McMurphy's story then the movie could be perfect.

reviews.review_title: one of the most entertaining films out there
reviews.content: I don't know much about psychology to determine how accurate this film is scientifically, nor that it really tries to delve deep into the science part of things, but I do know a thing or two about cinema and based on that knowledge, this film has everything for a perfect watch.An ultra-charismatic anti-hero, magnified by a tour de force performance by Jack Nicholson; a villainous, cold-hearted nurse Ratched; a highly interesting set of supporting characters, mostly mental institution patients; a screenplay adapted of an acclaimed novel and lastly a brilliant director that is Milos Forman. Put all these ingredients in a bowl, stir it for a while, add some salt and pepper and le voila! You have one hell of a film!

This is one of the movies that changed the landscape of motion pictures forever.Jack Nicholson appears after his first big role in "Chinatown" and shines. Milos Forman's creation has to be praised- a mixture of drama and comedy fulfilled with deep emotions. Forman presents a whole new world, a world behind "the Wall". There is one enthusiastic person who tries to destroy, or better, avoid this barrier, but finally fails. Like the political scene in the middle 70's in Europe, two different worlds separated, causing so much pain and trouble for a ordinary person. Inside "the Wall" the regime dictates and jeopardizes the basic thoughts of democracy and freedom. Formans great talent to find a balanced story, which enters deeply inside of you; and a remarkable cast of Nicholson, Fletcher, DeVito and Redfield all together make a winning formula.This film was a prototype of all the modern movies made after it, from the "Rain Man", to the "Deer Hunter" to the modern "Girl. Interrupted".Forman and Kubrick led us into a new era of film, as the real leaders of modern Cinema.This is the one of ten or twenty movies you MUST SEE. 9 of 10 easy.

reviews.review_title: A strong film that highly impressed me. One of the best films I have ever seen.
reviews.content: This movie is a fantastic prison escape movie that is less about escaping, and more about prison. The actors all give some of the greatest performances I have ever seen. Jack Nicholson steals the show though. The relationships between the characters feel so real. The emotion is very powerful. At the end I was holding back some tears. It also is a very funny movie. I laughed many times. The characters are all so memorable. My favorite of course is Jack's character. The direction, and editing are also good stuff. When the score is playing it is very good. This film has everything I could ask for in a movie. It is an amazing film that is one of the very best.4 stars out of 4

In my mind, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, a film that's constantly found in lists of the greatest movies ever, is about many things. More than anything, to me the movie is about friendship, camaraderie and the idea that the best way to solve mental issues, regardless of their severity, is simply through being human beings. Roger Ebert said it best in his review of the film: "They will be cured not by Nurse Ratched's pills, Muzak and discussion groups, but by McMurphy liberating them to be guys--to watch the World Series on TV, go fishing, play pick-up basketball, get drunk, get laid." I don't think the movie really tries to be about mental illness, it just happens that this is the story that they decided to focus on, but the core of the film lies in guys being guys.There is a shot of Mcmurphy, played brilliantly by Jack Nicholson almost at the end point of the movie, where it's a lingering close up of his face and his expression slowly changes from laughter and defiance to seriousness and thought, to finally a subtle smile. The question of course is what he is thinking in this moment. It reminded me of an earlier moment in the film, where Chief talks about his father and the idea of course,not just for Chief, but for many of the characters in the movie, is that what they've done in real life or what they have to face in the real world, is so bad that they would rather stay in this hospital. Mcmurphy then comes in and this idea is questioned and we see actual character development, not just from him but from all of the characters. In the end, Mcmurphy decides to stay, whatever the consequences may be and it's interesting to think about whether or not this signifies victory or defeat for him.All of the characters are very interesting, memorable and unique, the performances are excellent by everyone. Standouts are, of course, Nicholson and Louise Fletcher, who plays Nurse Ratched, one of the most hated characters in movie history. The funny thing about that is, as I was watching this movie I realized that a) she's definitely a c**nt, no doubt about that, but she was really just doing her job. Could she have been nicer and more reasonable? Absolutely. But I don't think she's necessarily evil, even though she is most definitely the villain of the film. Her methods don't work, the therapy doesn't seem to be doing much or the pills, but at the same time, it feels like she really thinks her methods are the only way to solve these people's problems, but it's one of those things of "the road to hell is paved with good intentions", I guess.But anyway, it is an excellent, wonderful, heart-warming (although kind of depressing in the end, too) film and everyone should watch it at least once.

A group of people orgy, a one-man lunatic asylum. In the movie, the lunatic asylum is a place with strong metaphors. Autocracy runs wild, freedom and personality are extremely suppressed and deprived. It is a modeled general autocracy. It uses the sounding banner to deceive and deceive people, depriving people of their personality. A lunatic is a relative definition that requires a certain evaluation standard. In the eyes of a lunatic, those so-called normal people are not lunatics.

Ken Kesey's blistering attack on American society as viewed through an insane asylum where R.P. McMurphy (a career-best Jack Nicholson) is sent for "evaluation treatment".Oscars went to Nicholson, Louise Fletcher as castrating Nurse Ratched, producer Michael Douglas and Milos Forman's unblinking direction. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest spent 14 years in development limbo but remains the most radical film to emerge from mainstream Hollywood. Too many classic set pieces to mention but keep your ears cocked for that immortal line "Mmmm, Juicy Fruit." The best film of that era... Certified brilliance!

reviews.review_title: Nicholson in the mental institution WARNING: SPOILER
reviews.content: I saw this movie for the first time last week when my psychology teacher showed it to us.  We had been studying psychological disorders and she figured this would be a good movie to watch.  It's about a convict named Randll MacMurphy who gets out of prison by pretending to be crazy.  When he is taken to the mental hospital, he meets the other patients and the stern Nurse Ratched.  Although this movie was a drama, there were a lot of funny scenes like when we see some of the patients throwing tantrums(it reminded me of an autistic boy who I went to grade school and still go to high school with who threw tantrums all the time in grade school).  One interesting character was Chief, the Native American patient, who like MacMurphy, was faking his craziness.  He pretended that he couldn't talk or move around well.  Another funny scene was when all the staff had gone home for the night and the patients had a party.  MacMurphy's friend came and one of the mental patients, whose name was Billy, fell in love with her.  When the staff came back that morning, Nurse Ratched discovered Billy and the woman in a bed. Nurse Ratched threatened to call Billy's mother and Billy left (he had obviously killed himself when the patients came in and saw blood all over his body).  Angry, MacMurphy strangles Nurse Ratched and she has some doctors take away part of his brain.  Chief suffocates him that night so he won't have to live the rest of his life like a "vegetable" and picks up a sink, throws it out the window, and escapes the institution.  I really thought it was wonderful how MacMurphy brought some life into all those patients and made them feel appreciated.  I didn't like Nurse Ratched at all.  She reminded me of a techer I once had.

I thought it was interesting how the writer make a criminal the protagonist of the story.  I would buy it, but I can't believe a convicted rapist would have any heart or soul that the character had in the movie.  If he was convicted of assault, ok.  But a rapist?  He wouldn't think twice about anyone and just leave the place as soon as he can.  Other than that I thought it was good.

reviews.review_title: Why does freedom become a tragedy?
reviews.content:
What is McMurphy's projection in reality?He is an asshoie who has made you mad over and over again. When you scold them as scum, there will be no sympathy between words.Compared to freedom, people want security more. So they sent him into the high wall for their safety.But when McMurphy was tortured by the lunatic asylum, everyone suddenly became his close comrade-in-arms, hoping for "freedom" with him, planning a perfect escape.It's weird.Why does freedom become a tragedy?
Because you are the lock.

well. first of all there was only three people which this film is all about, jack neckelson as Mcc-Merphy, Brad Dourif as Billy Bibbit and Will Sampson as Chief Bromden.I was amused by Mcc-Murphy and moved by Billy and finally astonished by the Indian chief.during the movie I saw the dramatic events and touched by it.near the end I was nearly crying.but THE END was beyond expectations I couldn't believe that I went all this drama and actually watched the movie and find this lame end.this movie doesn't deserve more than 4/10.

As Jiddu Krishnamurti said; "It is no measure of health to be well adjusted to a profoundly sick society. In my humble opinion 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' is an analogy of a brilliant, uncontrollable, free mind trapped in a sick society where being different is the deadliest sin. The society (insane asylum) orders you to conform and if you resist to conform you will be eliminated one way or another.. Although R.P. McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) cant win, at least he tries. "But I tried, didn't I? Goddamnit, at least I did that."This is an extraordinarily brilliant and impressive film for all beautiful free minds.

reviews.review_title: Nicholson shines in "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest"
reviews.content: While watching Milos Foreman's "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest", it occurred to me that I've been on a real psych movie kick lately. Shutter Island, Good Will Hunting, Cuckoo's Nest...I even caught myself looking at YouTube videos of Titicut Follies the other day. Psychiatry is often portrayed in a negative light in the media-- as a field of medicine where pedophiles and monsters pump their patients full of pills and electroshock while caging them like animals. While the field has come a long way in the last hundred years, the early 20th century was marred with highly dangerous and pseudo scientific procedures and patterns of inhumane treatment toward patients. "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" is, among other things, a commentary on the barbarism of mid-century psychiatry.An adaptation of the classic anti-establishment novel by Ken Kesey, "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" follows the free-spirited criminal Randall McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) as he is being admitted to an Oregan mental hospital. Randall aims to be declared insane so that he may ride out his short prison term in what he feels will be a comparatively comfortable setting. McMurphy is put in a ward with quite an eclectic cast of characters including the 6'5" Native American "Chief" Bromden (Will Sampson), stuttering suicidal Billy Bibbit (Brad Douriff, who would later go on to play Wormtongue in the Lord of the Rings movies), the diminutive Mr. Martini (Danny DeVito, a connection I didn't notice until well over halfway through the movie!) and the spastic "Taber" (Christopher Lloyd). Shortly after his admission to the hospital, McMurphy begins to notice that many of the patients are being abused and degraded, kept in submission by the tyrannical and calculating Head Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher). McMurphy bands together with the other patients in his ward to mount a rebellion against the oppressive Ratched, causing more than a few riotous moments.This film is intellectual gold. Aside from being immensely culturally relevant (a strong theme of individuality v. authority/establishment is felt throughout) the film is a scathing commentary on the state of mental health treatment in the 1960's (Ken Kesey based the story on his experience working in a VA Hospital in Palo Alto, California). The means and methods of treatment were inelegant and at times did more harm than good, while patients were stripped of their individuality and reduced to helpless subhuman husks of men in hospital Johnny coats. The dialog is smart, the direction is spot on (a number of the extras were actual mental patients, and the actors supposedly stayed in character between takes). The film lacks any true emotional content, save for the final scene, but overall I found it to be thoroughly satisfying.

Hey guys! ok, I will not tell what other people tell you in the user comments, but when you see this one, you will find that americans can do also excellent films, and this is proof.Director Forman does what others directors can't. reviews.review_title: One of the worst films ever made!!!

I suppose having previous exposure to Kesey's work before seeing the movie spoiled me. I was expecting to see a great book made into a great movie. The movie Murphy was a totally different person than the book Murphy. The book Murphy instilled in the other patient a new found sense of self. In the movie, Murphy replaces the staff as the authority figure. The patients did what Murphy said, much the same as they did with the hospital staff. All in all an extremely pathetic translation to film.

reviews.review_title: Awful if you read the book.

DON'T WATCH THIS. If you haven't, then watch this movie but someday read the book, it is great.

reviews.review_title: Sanity is a matter of perception.
reviews.content: One of the universal characteristics about works of fiction is the audiences ability to relate to the characters. It is the common traits that we share with them that brings them to life. We can easily identify with a characters triumphs, their intentions, their failures and their frustrations. Many of these traits are easy to identify. They are either black or white, good or bad. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest goes into more of a gray area, giving us one of the all time great unanswered questions- What is crazy? When the film begins we are introduced to the hospital, set in 1963. The ward is run by Nurse Ratched (Lousie Fletcher), a woman with a sweet yet stern and cold face. When we are introduced to the patients we as the audience automatically assume we are crazy. Some of the patients outright exhibit deranged behavior. Others seem eccentric and a few seem downright "normal" but we assume they are there for a reason.We are then introduced to the films main character, RP McMurphy (Jack Nicholson). Despite his claims that he is crazy, it is made clear to the audience that McMurphy is not crazy but attempting to avoid jail time for criminal behavior. Nicholson's portrayal of McMurphy is nothing short of masterful with his over the top explosiveness and outbursts to his subtle reactions of his observation of the hospital.McMurphy's persona at once makes him a hero to the inmates and an enemy to Nurse Ratched. Almost instantly a war has begun between McMurphy and Nurse Ratched and neither side will back down. Fletcher's portrayal of Nurse Ratched is the personification of order. The sweetness that she portrays is phony and unsettling. The coldness and cruelness laying just below her surface becomes more and more apparent as we can see that she will go to any length to have control and show no mercy.We also get to know the characters better it is revealed that many of them are not insane at all but rather socially inept and loners. The revelation to McMurphy that these inmates are there voluntarily is almost an unbearable shock. These men are not there because they are evil or dangerous. They are there because they can not function within our society.McMurphy leaves his impression on all of the inmates, but the one he reaches through the most to is a gigantic mute Native American character simply referred to as the Chief. The Chief silently observes all activity in the ward while showing no emotion. It is his interaction with McMurphy that brings him to life and brings him to start speaking again.The heart of this film is not about mental illness. Despite taking place in a mental ward and there being mentally ill characters in the background, this is a film about human spirit. Spirit is what McMurphy has in abundance, what the inmates in his circle are critically lacking and what Nurse Ratched and the institution labels as insanity.And yet the war inevitably comes to its conclusion. SPOILER ALERT- Nurse Ratched's determination to have control and complete lack of mercy takes its toll on one of the most innocent inmates and drives him to take his life. The tragedy of his death unleashes the pent up rage that has built up in McMurphy and he unleashes it on full force on Nurse Ratched.The end result is a tragedy. The hospital lobotomizes McMurphy. He is now a vegetable and will be for the rest of his life. The Chief is horrified when he discovers his beloved friends fate and immediately smothers him with a pillow, doing him the favor of a quick death instead of spending the rest of his life immobile.Earlier in the film McMurphy had tried to lift a heavy marble water fountain out of the ground. When he failed he was mocked and he replied to the rest of them that at least he tried. Upon Mcmurphy's death the Chief does what had been laughed at as impossible- he rips the water fountain out of the ground and throws it through the window. The closing shot is of the Chief running away from the hospital....free from the hospital and free in his soul. He no longer needs the hospital. He was won the war that McMurphy started.

After so many years since this movie came out, it still hasn't lost its quality like most new movies. Such a simple and in fact such a profoundly intelligent film that unfortunately we will never get again. When acting was for the sake of acting and not for money, when everyone played their role perfectly and brought it to the screen, that's what this movie is about. One Flew Over .. is what can be called cinema, that something about the film that you will remember even after a few years, it's worth watching!

reviews.review_title: "Jack Nicholson at his best a truly wonderful film."
reviews.content: Quite simply one of the greatest films ever made. Flawless film making from start to finish.Powerful emotional funny sad this film has it All. Milos forman directs this film beautifully capturing all the emotions and sadness along the way.The acting is outstanding.Jack Nicholson finally win's his Oscar after four nominations. A brilliant supporting cast including Christopher Lloyd Danny Devito and Brad Dourif. If you have not watched this great film I truly recommend it. Every actor is at the top of there game , if you are fans of them you will really enjoy this Cinematic master piece. 10/10

reviews.review_title: "Which one of you nuts has got guts?"
reviews.content: This is in my top ten movies. My favorite Jack Nicholson movie. I'm half way through the book, and of course, I'm liking the book better, but it's still one of the best movies I've ever seen. All the characters are great, and Nurse Ratched is one of the greatest villains in movie history, not 'THE' greatest, but one of them.It's not only a great story, but there are many excellent side story's along with it, like the fishing trip, the World Series vote, and the bitter sweet ending. This will definitely be one of the most memorable films of all time. I know it will be to me. 10/10

Ah so touching I didn't want him to die though good end and its so warm to see how he was treating them and when had the chance to leave he stayed with them known that they are crazy oh jack u surprise me every time I watch your movie Definitely one of the greats love love love love

reviews.review_title: Excellent film, but not enjoyable to watch
reviews.content: It was over 40 years in between the two times that I have seen this film. It found it to be just as good a film as I remember, but not one of my favorites because it is a difficult story to enjoy. All of the production qualities are excellent. Since 1975 was not a banner year for great films, and "Cuckoo's" only real competition was "Jaws", which Academy members refused to accept that a film about a Great White Shark" was sufficiently "artsy", "Cuckoo" deserved winning the five major Oscars.

Beautiful film filled with such amazing performances, unforgettable moments and great characters. The film is very touching and I recommend it to everyone who appreciates an excellent cinematic production.

Jack rocks this movie! What an awesome piece of film this is. So very powerful and raw with emotion. This movie has a little something for everyone. And a little something to rock most peoples boat! Characters are insanely real! So subtle in ways and so bold and in your face in others. My favorite Nicholson role. Just remember, before the Joker there was Randle!

reviews.content: This one was of the best movies of all time for sure. I saw this movie 4 or 5 times in past 20 years. first time I saw this as kid when I only had 10 or 12 years old and as kid I had very bad feeling when I saw the McMurphy's dead. & I used to think that the justice never took palace because simple that mean nurse get away with what she did to the others & I always liked it this way that somebody just kill that mean nurse. but as conclusion maybe it doesn't have a very nice ending but we liked it because it turns out someone had the gut to do what McMurphy always wanted to do since he came to the warn for first time and escape form that lunatic ward. along the nice story line I should say actually this movie was one of the masterpieces of Jack Nicholson in performance.

reviews.review_title: It was the best picture of the year "1975"
reviews.content: Very touching and emotional movie, I believe it was the best picture of the year, actually one the top 10 of all time so far and of curse it's because of the amazing acting by Jack Nicholson. I saw this movie maybe 4 or 5 times in 20 years first time when I was about 10 or 12 year old & I couldn't say how sad I was when they turn McMurphy to a crazy person by an Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). the movie was a masterpiece although I liked it better if it hasn't that tragic ending. & As personal opinion I think the justice didn't took place they should have kill that cruel nurse. & sure McMurphy was right that she "the nurse" was a real cunt.

reviews.review_title: You've all been conned. This film is rubbish
reviews.content: Who could possibly find anything worthwhile to say about this film? Obviously the 159000 plus members who collectively rated it 8.8! It's hard to imagine how the Academy could have given Awards ( the big five no less ) to this over-long piece of pretentious nonsense. Giving the Oscar to Louise Fletcher for her performance has to be the all-time joke of the movie business. That much more able actresses had turned the role down speaks for itself. With the current lack of financial wisdom in the US in 2008, however, the film obviously had some serious irony up its sleeve to be kept for 33 years down the track. Fortunately since 1975, most Award seasons have seen logic and reason return to The Academy. One can only conclude that most of the Academy members who voted this Lulu Best Picture must have been smoking the butts that Ken Kesey couldn't finish.

reviews.review_title: Loony bin that's full of memorable characters
reviews.content: I must be crazy to be in a loony bin like this.This might be a weird comparison, considering that the majority of the plot takes place in a mental hospital, but this movie reminded me about my experiences in middle and high school. No, I didn't grow up in a mental hospital and without getting too much into the spoilers, I'll just say that gambling with cigarettes as a value, drinking on school grounds, leaving school grounds to do something stupid wasn't rare in the school that I went to. We also had that one highly disruptive kid that was leading the pack into all sorts of misadventures just because he was bored and wanted to rebel. Once he convinced everyone to skip our chemistry class because the teacher was late and even came up with an escape plan where we all split up into groups and left the school grounds. It doesn't sound fun on paper but the whole strategy and execution felt like a war movie where we had to sneak from the enemy base by relying on the communication on everyone.Getting back on the movie - I liked it. Not as much as I wanted to but I liked it. I got to know all the silly characters and even got a bit attached to them towards the end of the movie. The only movie that comes close to comparison on that level is Dazed and Confused, where you feel like you've reunited with your old friends every time you watch that movie. I'd say the actor here did a spectacular job, including Danny Devito, who I haven't seen in cinema since his appearance in "Friends" during one of the shows later seasons. Jack Nicholson, who's performance terrified the following generations with "The Shining" was spectacular as the chaotic-good Randle Patrick McMurphy and Louise Fletcher, who's work I definitely saw somewhere else but I just can't pint point where I know her from stood out the most for obvious reasons.Mental illnesses are no joke unless you're watching this movie. Most guys just seemed happy being there and their wild and unpredictable personalities made the watching experience fun. I especially can relate to Billy as I used to stutter back in my school days and I still suffer from mild dyslalia (and let's be honest, my situation with the ladies is not better than his). What I liked most here is that this movie took a simplistic approach to mental illness and it had no interest in being about insanity, it's more about being a free spirit in a closed system. In other words - even though it took place in a mental hospital, its goal was not to showcase how insane people can be in these kinds of institutions. Of course, it had the chance to show how these disorders should be taken seriously and not made fun of but this movie is not about that.In conclusion, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a spectacular experience that had an amazing cast that portrayed events that can be compared to the ones I experiences in my past and showcased messages of independence and bohemian approaches to life.

If you were able to sit through Citizen Kane, and maybe even got something from it you'll enjoy One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. Sure, Jack Nicholson gives a great performance (he usually does), and Nurse Ratchet is sicker than the patients, but that doesn't make a great movie. Just a long, pointless journey through a psycho-ward. If you're looking for something worthwhile, check out something other than this or Citizen Kane of AFI's or IMDB's top movies list.

reviews.review_title: "I knew you wouldn't leave without me"
reviews.content: A spirited film that is equally uplifting, and depressing. I think it has aged well throughout the years as it teaches us the flawed systems of our past.One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest delves deep into mental illness and touches on places that greatly affect the mind. It discusses a person's past traumas and what might make them who they have become. It also raises other important themes of Friendship, Happiness, Manipulation, Individuality, and how we are driven by our own emotions.Jack Nicholson always portrays such passionate emotion and has such a powerful presence that you never know if he is playing a character on screen or just being himself. He is the headliner of the film, (Much like The Shining) but not without the help of a superb support cast. Most of them went on to become some of the best entertainers in the film industry such as Christopher Lloyd, Danny DeVito, Brad Dourif, Louise Fletcher, Scatman Crothers, and Will Sampson.Some moments make you feel inspired when you see the inmates beginning to stand up for each other, and build their friendships. The companionship between Randle McMurphy and Chief Bromden is a major theme in the film which ends up giving the Chief back his independence.The Basketball scene is an emotional, glorious piece of cinema. It had all the inmates and orderlies bonding together and having a good time and you start to see in the inmate's demeanor that they are developing a new lease of happiness in their lives. This is all led by the spontaneous and charismatic Randle McMurphy.While Randle has done some horrible things in the past which is why he was admitted to the asylum including five assaults and the statutory rape of an underage girl. This film still makes his character fun and likable and that is because he is a free spirit and not a person who is a danger to himself or others, but someone who just truly enjoys life's simple pleasures such as watching as he puts it world series, heavy drinking, and sex.Louise Fletcher as Nurse Ratched is brutally cold, manipulative, and intelligent. While she does stand up for herself she also bullies, intimidates, and uses the patient's past and fears against them.One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is a film that I highly recommend for several reasons. It explores the human mind, and the storytelling is profound and thought-provoking. This is all capped off with one of the most memorable ending scenes in movie history involving Will Sampson and Jack Nicholson.10/10.

reviews.review_title: Absolutely perfect in every possible way
reviews.content: Please ignore any negative commentary on this movie, as it call comes from the know-it-all dissenters that are against all things good and all things "conformist."  Allow them to conform with their fellow "nonconformists"The movie is terribly perfect.  Acting and characters are awesome.  Nicholson truly at his best, no question there.  And Fletcher plays her role flawlessly.  She's supposed to be a boring, impassive nurse -- duh!  The supporting cast is just as deserving of kudos.  Based on a GREAT and classic book, probably one of the few movies that does any justice, along with To Kill A Mockingbird and the Grapes of Wrath.This movies combines humor with poignancy and emotion.  Great dialogue, great script, wonderful direction.  Really, you can't complain at all.10/10 - Far and away the best movie I own

This is as good as it gets in filmmaking.  Forman's film is absolutely brilliant.  The acting is great, particularly by the star, Jack Nicholson, who is at his finest.  The scene where he imagines a baseball game is memorable.  The end scene, where Chief runs off, is also great.  Truly a masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Where do you suppose she lives?
reviews.content: SPOILER WARNING!! Is "One flew over the cuckoo's nest" the greatest film of all time?  Perhaps not, but it is certainly one of the greatest.  And, in both Jack's and Louise's performances, it contains some of the finest screen acting you will ever, EVER, see.  Maybe you prefer to watch computer-generated dolts hitting each other in slow-motion.  I wish you all the luck in the world. Meanwhile, Jack is arriving at the mental institution, in the cold and gloom.  That weird music is playing.  The Chief, Nurse Ratched, Danny Devito, Chris Lloyd, Brad Dourif and all the rest of the guys are waiting for him to turn their lives upside down.  Here he comes now, with his cap, his leather jacket (notice how the colour scheme of his clothes slowly changes throughout the film until he's clad in all-white, just like the rest of them), his crazy grin, his rapid-fire chatter, his profanity, his spirit. The sad-sack inmates need him and fear him in roughly equal measure.  Their world is ordered and petty and routine, dominated by the terrifying Nurse (Louise Fletcher - what an astonishingly controlled performance she gives). MacMurphy is the last thing they need.  Playing basketball and going fishing ("Dr. Scanlon - the famous Dr. Scanlon") and watching the ball game (or not) and drinking and - hell - living, are not on the agenda.  The authorities cannot control someone like Mac ("I fight and **** too much"), they cannot even understand him.  Think of those great scenes in which men in suits ask him sensible questions and he responds by displaying a pornographic playing card and asking, "where do you suppose she lives?".  Think also of how awesomely easy it is to escape, and how he never manages it.  Why?  Why doesn't he go out the window that night?  Why doesn't he just disappear when they go for the fishing trip?  These are the questions that keep you awake at night.  "One flew over the cuckoo's nest" lingers long in the mind.  Its haunting imagery, brilliant dialogue and wonderful ending remind you of the true power of the movies.

reviews.review_title: A rare masterpiece is shining in the long river of time.
reviews.content: The film conveys a spirit of rebellion in pursuit of freedom, which is also manifested in the unwillingness to submit to the system, the courage to struggle, the courage to get rid of the shackles of thought, and help the people around you to wake up. Acting as the soul of the film, Mike Murphy, played by male lead Jack Nicholson, contributes to the plot and height of the film. He showed off a cynical and clever pseudo-psychiatric patient. This character will be complacent because he fools the system, and he will be excited about helping the real mental patient out of the cage.

While feeling pretty cloister phobic and trapped alongside the inmates, the film gives off such fun and mood boosting entertainment along with such a great story and outstanding performances all around, especially from our lead, Jack Nicholson, who will forever give off a perfectly crazy performance in every film.

reviews.review_title: It is always us who bind us
reviews.content: Our freedom and resistance have always been the heaviest and sharpest topics of an era. People's longing for freedom is often stronger than the desire for life. We live in an era where we cannot decide our birth, but we all have the same pursuit-freedom. True freedom will not be bound.

Having seen this film when I was a teenager, I remember feeling very sad and oppressed after going out of the cinema with an aunt who absolutely adores films of any genre. At that time my grammar is not even as developed as it is now, but the actors have clearly succeeded in showing me a masterpiece, one that haunts a person forever.Some thirty years later someone gifted me a 'classics cinema pass ' and decided to see this film once more. It's as disturbing and mind boggling as the first time I saw it. Some scenes will make a person think harder and again and again as if entering a courtyard of chaos and institutionalized yourself. For the simple reason that many of the characters here are to be found in our daily lives. Don't look further as the saying goes ' the only normal people are the ones you don't know that well '.Jack Nicholson is for me in character, simply the 'Van Gogh of actors' .
It's been a very long time since I've seen this so I don't feel great about this rating. Such good actors though. Great performances by Nicholson, Devito, and Lloyd. Probably worth a revisit.

One thing I would like to say is that this a great movie all around and by reading most of the comments youll see Im not alone in saying that. The main reason for this comment is a response to a couple of the other comments. Other people said " I didnt think nurse Ratchett was that bad, she's was just doing her job." What a bunch of crap. Watch the movie and find out that Nicholson should have been the nurse there. He's the only one there providing any help toward the other patients. If you notice the nurse sees the positive response to Nicholson by the the other patients that she is very jealous! Ratchett insists everytime to keep Nicholson in the asylum longer when the rest of the Board is completely convinced he is normal. Even Nicholson proves most of the patients in the asylum aren't even close to being insane. It's just the sedating drugs and shock treatments that mess them up. And nurse Ratchett gets off on all of it. I swear if you watch this movie and don't want to beat the nurse in the head there's something wrong with you! She played that part awesome! Just a little response to the other comments. I think most of you will agree with me. Enjoy.

This movie has all of it. Comedy, Suspense, Drama, a touch of romance, and more. Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher both deserved their oscars for this wonderful movie with an ending that will make you happy and sad at the same time. Absolutely amazing.

One Flew over the cuckoo's nest is a perfect example of great film-making. Milos Forman directs this story of a Randall McMurphy(Nicholson), a man who fakes being insane to avoid going to jail. But he is faced with a problem in the mental hospital and is always clashing with the head nurse (Louise Fletcher). The story is very touching and at times extremely funny. With awesome direction and a flawless screenplay, Brad Dourif, Danny DeVito, Sydney Lassick and Christopher Lloyd also give very good supporting performances, especially Dourif who plays a young unconfident stuttering patient. Overall there is little to be said about this film that has not been said before, but it is near perfect in every sense, and plays a great message as well as a very interesting story. Its Nicholson at his very best. 10/10

I saw this film recently...and what superb excellence. I am convinced now that Jack Nicholson (next to Dustin Hoffman) is the finest actor pulled out of America ever. He remarkably adopts the role of Randal.P. McMurphy ( a con who had the idea that spending time in a mental institution would be easier that fufilling his custodial sentence) The Irony is that McMurphy started off sane when he entered the institution and ended up being labotomised If you use you eyes you spot other famous thespians in that film like Louise Fletcher as the soft spoken but cruel Nurse Ratchit, Danny Devito, Brad Dourif and Christopher Lloyd also make noticable appearances as some of the inmates. This film is funny, touching and in some places disturbing but it is without a doubt one of cinema's greatest moments when it was released in 1975.

Nurse Ratched is a lonely, defensive, hostile character wielding power, but governed by hate for her job and limited freedom. McMurphy is her nemesis. But he is precariously placed in this war on the status quo. This shockingly great film championed a revolution in the provision of adult mental health care services. It could be hailed as the last lobotomy.

reviews.review_title: an encouraging movie for people under oppressing
reviews.content: it's a story about liberty and very encouraging till now, though filmed 25 years ago. People who don't believe in super power and confused by the routine life should take a look at this one, but maybe not everyone of them could catch the sense the producer wanted to deliver. free at last.

reviews.review_title: Watch it as a documentary more or less
reviews.content: This is how the legal system works. You admit yourself or somebody puts you there. They don't care who you are or what you did, you are in a prison. They make you into a vegetable and they think what they are doing is right. Whoever is in the mental hospital will automatically be seen as crazy, though the ones in charge are crazy themselves by following rules and regulations that go every way against an individual, because one shoe size does not fit all mfkin feet. Also the "doctors" make mistakes and then brush it off as it wasn't even remotely their fault because they followed the protocol. But in reality they are egomaniacs who are manipulating and want to control others and feel righteous with their authority instead of actually wanting to help people. Though how can they, if they are full of problems themselves or don't even have the comprehension of human conditioning?...Though about the movie, it's funny and depressing at the same time, an amazing film. I've watched it before but this is the first time I rate it. I truly recommend it for those who like slow-burnish movies and to those who ain't no snowflakes and take life/system of how it is.So who are the crazy ones? Those who act like it and aren't understood or pretend that they are normal?

This is quite a good film, and I highly recommend it.  It contains good acting and writing, complete with drama and humor.  A young Jack Nicholson gives a very effective performance.  Although perhaps not as well known as other award winning movies, it has been the subject of a number of parody scenes, in particular on the television show "The Simpsons".

reviews.review_title: Books are overrated. The movie's better.
reviews.content: I'm so sick of all these people saying the book's better. Forget the stupid book. This movie's brilliant. The screenplay is brilliant. The writers took a really good novel and molded it into a perfect movie. I know all the wanna be critics that come here are gonna say how the book did this better and showed all these deep, hidden themes better and how the movie isn't as good and BLAH BLAH BLAH...that stuff is just so clichéd. I'm tired of hearing it. There's nobody in the world that could have done a better job than Foreman. The cast in this is perfect...and let me just say that I actually read the book first before seeing the movie thinking that if I saw the movie first my experience reading the book would be ruined, but the actors in the movie completely demolished the characters I had in my head; Jack Nicholson, Louis Fletcher, Brad Dourif, Christopher Lloyd...all perfect. All of them. Also, wasn't it great how the movie kept Cheswick around. God I love that guy. I think the biggest improvement that the movie had over the book was the ending. Kesey's ending lacked emotion, sensitivity, feeling...it just didn't have the impact on me that Foreman's ending did. I mean, wasn't that soundscore in the end of the movie simply amazing, I get goosebumps every time I see it. Books don't have music like that. They are, afterall, just words.I have great respect for books and novels. Harper Lee's To Kil A Mockingbird towers over the movie, but that just isn't the case here and some of you need to get over it. Some of you also need to accept the fact that not all things in books can be translated into movies. They're two separate forms of entertainment.
Great Movie of a Great novel. Worth your time. Many future stars in this one.

It makes me so sad that movies cannot be the same as books. I understand that it's an entirely different medium and all, but still. I was unfortunate enough to have watched the movie after reading the book. Unfortunate in that because of this the movie was disappointing for me. The book is so complex and emotionally moving, as well as mentally stimulating, that although the movie was good, it didn't even come close to being as memorable. If anyone asked me which was more worthwhile I would unflinchingly answer 'the book'. And if they did decide to do a remake of the film, I reckon Tom Waits would be way better casting for McMurphy than Nicholson.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Review
reviews.content: One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest by Milos Forman really did amaze me with the Actors, Cinematography, and Soundtrack. I usually am not a huge fan of older movies and I was super wowed about how the music intertwined with characters and the overall look of the movie. In the movie there wasn't that many songs present and I honestly didn't even notice the music in the beginning, after the movie I did realize where the music was placed. The overall look of the movie was great, the actors portrayed the soulful aspects as they should for this difficult movie. Overall, I was quite surprised with this movie and would like to watch it again to rediscover this information all over again.

It's simply mindblowing how many people insist that this movie is so brilliant. Personally I find the story weak, the acting poor and the ending!!??? Nicholson is seen better (eg in "as good as it gets), along with other movies. I can't grasp how this movie in some people's opinion is considered a "classic". It sucks, and there's nothing else to say. I rented this movie because I was told it was a classic and very good, but I was very disappointed. And the ending was so weird, after I watched it I though, what the hell was that? A classic? I mean, it wasn't that bad, but I definitely expected it to be better. I like Jack Nicholson, he was great in As Good as it Gets, but this movie was not very good. If you want to watch a movie about a mental institution, Girl, Interruped is better.

Jack Nicholson is at his best as a rambunctious Randall Patrick McMurphy while the supporting cast shines. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a devastating look at the breaking down of supremely flawed but lovable man in a prison in the form of a sanitarium. There is no one scene that makes One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest great, rather it is the boundless energy in the performance of Nicholson and the emotional impact of the closing scenes that make One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest one of the greatest Best Picture winners.

This is a very special film,it`s the first of it`s kind and it had to be Milos Forman(man on the moon, amadeus)that directed it,it was his breaktrough and it put him on the list of the other great directors, Scorsese,Stone,Coppolla and Tarantino.
The acting in this film is so great that everybody that acted in this movie deserved an Academy Award. Jack Nicholson got one for his role as McMurphy, and Louise Fletcher also got one for her role as nurse Ratched.The story is very fascinating and actually very touching.It is a very funny film to,it`s a bit like Man on the moon.You don`t know if you should cry or laugh.This is maybe the greatest film ever made and it is a must-see for everybody that likes to watch a good film.Milos Forman`s directing is so good it`s almost scary(he also got an Oscar for Best Director). Jack Nicholson(as usual)is more than great,he`s fantastic in his role,so don`t miss out on this one. It is one of the greatest.

reviews.review_title: I don't cry easy, but I blubbed like a girl.
reviews.content: Possibly the most powerful movie ever made; it just goes to show what you can do with a superb script and an excellent cast, without having to resort to explosions or special effects.Jack Nicholson has never been the most consistent of actors, but if ever an Academy Award was more deserved, I'd like to see that performance.  His McMurphy is quite simply the most believable and easiest to relate to character in the history of celluloid.  His love for the rest of the inmates is apparent all the way through, and he's backed up superbly by Louise Fletcher as Nurse Ratched, Brad Dourif (whatever happened to him?) as Billy, and Will Sampson as the Chief.
