Even Danny De Vito puts in his best ever performance.McMurphy's punishment is heart-breaking, as a vibrant, intelligent small-time crook is reduced to a vegetable for daring to speak the truth, while Billy's demise is all the more tragic as it is far less inevitable than McMurphy's.I can't believe that anyone reading this hasn't yet watched the film (if not - go and watch it NOW!) but just in case - stop reading now...All I wanted to say was the scene where the Chief smothers McMurphy and then pulls the water fountain out of it's fitting and throws is through the window to escape is probably the best scene in movie history, rivaled only by the very start of Star Wars when the Star Cruiser passes overhead.Saying that this film is a perfect ten is to do it an injustice.  I defy anyone to watch this film and not be deeply moved by it.  It is a perfect example of a screenplay not needing to stick rigidly to its literary fore-runner, and for me, sets the standard for emotional dramas - a standard which no other film has yet lived up to.

Writing/Dialogue/Characters Great 4
Though it takes a dramatic turn rather abruptly.Acting Superb 5
Art?location Great 4
Sound Great 4
Cinematography Good 3

reviews.review_title: Unreal, this truly a unique film experience.
reviews.content: This film always had a unique taste and a very captivating storyline, first of all Milos Forman did a wonderful job, by using his directorial skills and splendid cinematography, he brought to the audience the authentic atmosphere and feeling of a mental health facility, from its exhausting routines to its chaotic moments. The feelings of compassion that everyone felt toward the solitude and innocence of the patients was simply due to quality of screenwriting and dialogues. And finally one of the major aspects of this film, is its great set of cast, with the memorable McMurphy portrayed by Jack Nicholson, also the introduction of one of the most monstrous antagonists, the megalomaniac and sadistic nurse Ratched portrayed by Louise Fletcher. A timeless piece of cinema.

One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is simply a brilliant film. I am really glad it is on the IMDb Top 250 and it deserved all its Oscars. The performances were all incredible, especially from Jack Nicholson, Brad Dourif, Louise Fletcher and Danny DeVito. They all played their characters realistically and for all of them, this film is a career-best. While the acting was probably the best thing about the movie, there is definitely no doubt that the direction from Milos Forman was anything but brilliance, and the adapted script is moving, original and clever.One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is simply top 10 quality, groundbreaking stuff.Rating: 10

This film has no special effects,it has something much better a story great script and acting from the top draw.Jack and Louise are outstanding and the rest of the cast do their jobs well.The film is extremely well written and can be enjoyed on different levels,as a story well told and as comment on the USA of the  Nixon era.The nurse represents Nixon and MacMurphy the anti vietnam movement and freedom from a system that has no room for individuals,if only todays movies were so good.9/10
Extraordinary acting, fantastic characters, compelling story and just heartwarming. Unfortunately, it fell a bit short in the later act of the movie.
No matter now or in the future, the madhouse and the head nurse disguised in various shapes lurk around us, flying over the madhouse is always meaningful.

This should be one of the top 250 best films of all time. Its well deserved. I cried the first time I saw it. Then was disturbed the rest of the evening. The book was better or just as good depending on how you look at it. And I can't say that to most films adapted by novels. Jack Nicholson did an excellent job in portraying the the lead character. He was just like that in the book. All the characters especially the Chief. Overall I was pleased. I have nothing to butcher about this movie.

"Cuckoo's Nest" is one of the most famous films. Jack Nicholson plays a convicted criminal, who make believe to be mentally ill to avoid going to jail. When he is committed to the sanatorium, he starts inciting the other prisoners to rebel against the strict administration. Jack Nicholson unforgettable performances the film features. The film is long, but absorbing and entertaining, and you will really care for all the characters right up to end.The principal artist Jack Nicholson gives his best in this movie, in particular during the scene where he plays cards with other patients, or when he pretends to be watching a baseball match. There is a comic part where Danny DeVito is plainly dancing in the basketball court. A social analysis of the movie is great fun. The ending of the film is truly a classic and dramatic.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest films of all time, great performances and just a great film all round!
reviews.content: ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST (along with; THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION, THE GREEN MILE, GOODFELLAS, THE KING'S SPEECH and many others) is one of my favourite films ever. Jack Nicholson gives one of the best performances of his life in this classic movie. As a young writer I look at a film and I say; "Could I make this movie better or could I cast different people in this film." With this film, if I was to change it. . .I would only ruin it. There are very few films that are perfect from beginning - end this is one of those very few.A great movie and extremely worthy of the five academy awards it received in 1975. Just absolute perfection.

This is the kind of movies with several levels. The first one is a story of a guy trying to escape prison until he realizes that the mental institution is worst, despite the impression it gives. A striking example is given when the nurse offers to make the patients vote on the proposition of Mc Murphy to watch baseball series on TV. First, she offers this because she knows she'll win over Mc Murphy, as the patients are too scared, too docile to publicly disagree with her. Then, she offers a second chance without mentioning that she wants the majority among people who can't vote. Finally, she argues that time was over when Mc Murphy succeeded in convincing a tenth patient. She impersonates the institution: leading you to think that they care while their only concern is to maintain their domination, their power whatsoever.Here appears the second level: a criticism of these mental institutions, answering with authority to people who simply lack the tools to behave like the majority of the population. The only violence the patients show is the one they infringe to themselves. Which leads the only two that see clearly to use it against others, but only for justice: McMurphy against the nurse who led Billy to commit suicide, and the "Chef" against McMurphy to save him from a life of physical and mental imprisonment. A third level deals with love, respect and attitude toward others in general. The main difference between McMurphy and everybody else, patients or institution, is that he treats everyone as equals, and this is what makes him the hero. His humanism is the core quality that will make him play cards with the ones that don't even understand the game (but who will say some of the most intelligent thing when asking how will they win back their money and cigarettes if the nurse keeps them "for their own good"), speak to the deaf and dumb (who appears to actually fake it), and give an opportunity for love to the one who is supposed to not be able to stand for it. And when he fails, at least, as he says in the beginning, he tries. The humiliation of him not being able to lift the block in the bathroom becomes a message of hope addressed to all of them who knew it was impossible but did not realize that the defeat is in the way they think not the fact that they were right on this matter. This key moment is a first step toward the final happy ending for the Indian guy. For all this reasons, this movie really moves me. The actors are exceptional, the grey and cold atmosphere that contrasts with the mood of the hero and with the scene of party and happiness near Christmas or with the one on the boat is perfect for the movie. I simply was not convinced by part of the end, maybe because it went too fast. I don't know. I did not like the opening credits and the poster ether, which may be details but other movies showed that these could be art and I like when filmmaker are perfectionist. Overall, I rated the movie 10/10 not because it was perfect but for all the levels I saw in it. It, for sure, will make me think about it for long, and rise questions about life in general. PS: sorry for my English, I hope it is still understandable ;)

reviews.review_title: One flew over the cuckoos's nest
reviews.content: Awesome movie! I like Danny Devito in this film. He's so funny! And Jack Nicholson does a great job as Randle Patrick McMurphy. One flew over the cuckoos's nest is probably one of the greatest American films of all time. And i'm agree with that. The film dares to be a tragedy on the human level. Life is often not pretty. Neither is this story. It is moving - deeply. But it never panders or moralizes, it just stands as a warning against the Nurse Ratcheds of the world and as an example of how wonderful good writing well-acted can be to behold.It is a Tragi-comedy/Psychological Drama. And Milos Foreman does a great job too. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Impossible to fly, society is a giant madhouse
reviews.content: Whether it is now or in the future, the lunatic asylum and the head nurse lurking around us in various shapes, flying over the lunatic asylum will always make sense.

reviews.review_title: What can I say!!! other than Jack Nicholson
reviews.content: Jack Nicholson!! Jack Nicholson.He has this amazing smile, which complements his acting capabilities. I haven't seen many actors using such a simple thing in the most powerful manner, than Nicholson does. There are a few others that come to my mind; Kevin Spacy, Robin Williams, and probably Anthony Hopkins in Silence of the Lambs. He shines like a jewel in this film. The whole setting is perfect for a guy of his abilities. Surrounded with a bunch of brain'n'ball-less group, he only wants them all to act normally. But his idea about mentally-fit are a bit perverse. The script, the storyline, the direction, the mode, the cinematography, the acting, superb... simply out-of-this world. One of my all time favorites.

This movie is a bit seems to be psychotic at first but its a brilliant movie with amazing story and moral behind it , great performance by all the actor , but specially Jack Nicholson (Worthy of an Oscar) . It's a must watch classic.

reviews.review_title: A must for any human being
reviews.content: One of the best and one of the most beautiful movies of all times. One of the most uplifting love poems about the human spirit. One of the most important movies that you'll see in your life. Some pieces of art are so important and so true that they can not be measured. Giving it a ten is a terrible shame, it needs more because it is one of the three or four movies that can make any human being, as chief said, as big as a mountain. And that is a beautiful thing. However, this is IMDb and it has to be analyzed as a film, so let's do it. It has a script that is just PERFECT. Acting so good that you have to concentrate really hard to pull yourself out of the spell to remember that these are actors. Directing so good that made this movie one of the most important movies of the twentieth century. A piece of art so good that makes you a better human being.

This has got to be one of my best films and i would recommend it to anybody.Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher play there characters extremely well and deserved all their Oscars that they received. This film contains both drama as well as comedy. It all starts when R.P Mcmurphy is sent from a work farm to a physciatric hospital as the people at the work farm think he is crazy but we all know that there is not anything wrong with his mind. We watch R.P Mcmurphy and his day to day routines at the physciatric hospital and his battle with the evil nurse ratchet and we continue the journey with mcmurphy through all his obstacles right to the dramatic end.

Watching this film after a little political philosophy, I suddenly realized that how could a rare film with high scores on both imdb and douban be limited to anti-power?
On reflection, I wanted to share this film as an allegorical interpretation -- a film that really reflects on the impact of political correctness on modern society and the spiritual emasculation of modern men by modern culture.

reviews.review_title: My 2nd Favorite Movie of All Time
reviews.content: "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is great because of how complex the R.P. McMurphy and Nurse Ratchet characters are. R.P. McMurphy is not that different from the people I've met, yet he is dubbed "insane". Nurse Ratchet is so cold. She's the best villain in the cinema, eviler than Darth Vadar from "Star Wars" or Dudley Smith from "L.A. Confidential". And let's not forget great acting from Danny Devito, William Redfield, and "The Chief".

The finest hour of Jack Nicholson! Wow, what a performance! Nicholson puts so many nuances of his character into every shot, into every scene, the Oscar for a leading actor was never so well deserved. For this alone, the film deserves 5 stars. But the film also convinces as a milieu study, which never degrades the patients and skillfully combines all nuances from funny to tragic. You should actually be able to award 10 stars for it.

this is a great movie that clearly illustrates the treatment of the "insane" in this time period.  it is by far jack nicholson's greatest feat as an actor and it also made other actors' names household words, such as danny devito and christopher lloyd.  it's a great movie classic that everyone should see.

Describing the story of a man who is priorly condemned, this film certainly deserves to be placed at the top of IMDb's best rated films. While watching the fight between Miss Ratched and R.P. McMurphy, you have a chance to ask yourself how the docs and nurses should behave to psychopaths. Coming from jail for the observation, an extraordinary man who is R.P. McMurphy decides to make the medication central a social place in spite of Mrs. Ratched. In this way, Mrs. Ratched raises all kind of difficulties.R.P. McMurphy is a smart man and does his best to entertain his friends. He finds meeting times very absurd and thinks that the best medication is to do social activities. Boat trip, basketball match and even a party in nighttime in the central.R.P. McMurphy let you think and laugh, Harding reminds you to your obsessions, Chief for secret side of us and the other whole characters are excellent. I want confess that I swear Mrs. Ratched too much and I know such kind of people are real in the world.Billy's and McMurphy's touching ends make me sad st the end of the film but theses go wells with the theme of film.I start to hide this film in my library and I'll watch whenever I remember it.

"I must be crazy to be in a loony bin like this." This is definitely one of Nicholson's best performances and perhaps one of the greatest performances of all time. Its powerful and compelling message along with the entertaining and engaging characters makes its almost a perfect movie. Its a shocking account of life in a mental asylum with the bitch-face nurse who has just about as much emotion as a robot (im sure everyone can agree with me). Although I thought the ending could of been slightly better i would still acclaim this as one of the best films made. Its not for the faint hearted because of its demented theme. I give it a 9/10, a big achievement in cinema.

Good Nicholson film. Not as good as 'A Few Good Men'. This is a great drama, that also has a lot of humor in it. DeVito's character is someone who brings a smile on your face. And when they go fishing on a boat after McMurphy (Nicholson) steals the bus. Many of the actors got actually seasick. The party scene, that brings a lot of trouble to Crother's character is a lot of laughs. And then the drama. The group session scenes are full of drama. Like when Bibbitt (Dourif) talks about his troubles. Or after the party, when he takes his own life because the nurse from hell threats to talk to his mother about him sleeping with that girl. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975) is directed by the Czech born director Milos Forman. The movie came from the novel (1962) by Ken Kesey, which I haven't read. Then there was a play version, and finally the movie came. The casting is perfect. Jack Nicholson does the role of the lifetime in the lead. Louise Fletcher, a perfect choice to play nurse Mildred "Big Nurse" Ratched. She represents the evil in the movie, but she doesn't see she's doing anything wrong. Will Sampson is huge and really great as Chief Bromden. We can thank Mel Lambert, who plays Harbor Master, for finding Will. His father happened to be an Indian agent. Dean R. Brooks, who plays Dr. John Spivey, was at the time the actual head of the Oregon State Hospital. Harding is playd by the amazing William Redfield. A tragic thing about this actor. He was diagnosed with leukemia during shooting by Dr. Brooks. He told he'd have about 18 months to live, and about 18 months later he died. Yet he stayed in the picture until the very end. The marvelous Scatman Crothers portrays Turkle the janitor. He got the part with the help from his friend, Jack Nicholson. The music done by Jack Nitzche is really beautiful and haunting.

reviews.review_title: As near to perfection as you'll get!
reviews.content: Everything about this film is so near to the perfect film! The screenplay, the acting, the casting, the lighting, camera angles & above all, of course, the directing. Michael Douglas as producer was right to hold out against his father, Kirk's pressure to cast him in the lead role. Jack Nicholson was a 'Tour De Force'. However, let not that comment take anything away from the other actors who were all so superb. The casting had 'genius' written through it in every role. A huge tribute to Milos Foreman for his brilliant understanding of the book, he translated it so well on screen. A film that holds you totally through every minute. A classic of WORLD cinema!!

reviews.review_title: Firstly, I would like to say, What the hell is wrong with all of you people.
reviews.content: I was going to give 8 stars but with only 21 one stars and 478 TEN star,243 nine star and 128 EIGHT star ratings I decided nothing is wrong with US people and gave it a 9.Maybe that one star reviewer who posted that quote needs a little TLC from Nurse Ratched. I loved this movie in 1975 because my Daddy griped for days "Only guy with my last name that's famous and he's crazy as hell." Daddy was also a You People type of guy who was always right.Every movie Uncle Jack was in he seriously seems very close to needing a rubber room but still a great actor. Maybe this movie was a premonition of Jack's future career.

reviews.review_title: Our heart beat with Jack Nicholson and his nutties!
reviews.content: The story of "One flew over the cuckoo's nest" is particular: at the beginning none believed in this film except Kirk Douglas and and Saul Zaentz (a producer,but a jazz producer!!), but finally the success was incredible.This film was the emblem and the swan song of a great and unrepeatable season.When America was crushed but still young and its cinema was dirty,utopian,visionary and rebel.In 1975 there was great film, like Altman's wildness of Nashville,like Kubrick's Barry Lindon, but won McMurphy, with his cap,with his basketball,with his girls,with his rage that push himself to jump on the neck of the nurse-jailor Flatcher and to pay,for the extreme rebellion,the highest price.And in the heart of many people won Great Head that finally destroyed all and conquest freedom.The hospital-prison is an evident metaphor of America, that stifles your brain and your desires with pills (or, if are very bad like Nicholson,with lobotomy). But McMurphy is always ready to remember to you that is very important to find a passage in the wall and to aim a kick to the indifference. And,above all to refuse the overwhelming.

reviews.review_title: Disliked Both Ward and McMurphy, Liked the Film
reviews.content:
The ward this film was based on had Ratched who was too cold and ineffective as a nurse. Her eyes scared me more than reassured me there was safety. This does not make the ward seem like a safe place to me. So, the red flag is being raised a certain level.
Now, for Randle McMurphy. He knows he is contemptible but continues on to use people for his amusement. So, he is considered an antihero of this film instead of one that tries to "fight the system" of the ward effectively to me. He is no Martin Luther King, Jr. in my eyes.
Overall, I found myself resiliently liking this film because of how Jack Nicholson can pull off his jerk attitude but in an impressive way. Of how some of the patients in the ward were there via consent. Of how those same patients could have some party fun, though it is probably not acceptable in ward situations in modern time or other times. And of how Chief was the true hero of this film. Chief saved people from McMurphy and McMurphy from his vegetable hell from the lobotomy. People don't give the Chief character enough credit to me.
If you want me to be completely honest, I feel the lobotomy that was done to McMurphy was a tasteless move. You can't stop a natural sociopath from being a natural sociopath unless you turn them into a vegetable.

I always love Jack Nicholson movies and watch them constantly but
Unfortunately, this movie, and I know how successful it is, I have not seen it
Except today and it was really a great movie as Jack's movies are.Acting, script, filming and directing are all great and they deserved all the awards at the time.The story of the movie is very wonderful and the sequence is excellent in the plot of the movie
From start to finish, which was shocking to kill Jack who
We were happy with his way of dealing with patients and he was positive
I do not find an explanation for the killing, knowing that the Indian man seems to
Wise talking to Jack and listening to him.The nurse played the role in a special way and her temper was very sharp.

This film stands above so many films of the 70s.  It really scores high for realistic acting.  Nicholson's performance is absolute gold.  The film also mixes humour and drama extremely well, one minute we're laughing only then to descend into sadness. Powerful.  The film also has respect for its characters, although not to the point of becoming sappy and being afraid to use them for comic effect when appropriate.  Nicholson isn't the only actor to watch out for - everyone is on form, there's not a weak performance in the whole picture.  Each character is crafted and endearing (or realistically menacing in the case of Louise Fletcher).  Special note must be made of Sydney Lassick as Cheswick, a nice little character and a fine portrayal.  The film is extremely quotable and full of memorable scenes.

reviews.review_title: The true meaning of the cuckoo' s nest!
reviews.content: Excellent film in all aspects. as a viewer, i felt that i was a patient myself. it was interesting to see how the patients became all self conscious about who they were.jack being able to persuade them to change their routine schedule was proof that not all patients need the sort of therapy mental institutes provide.If not in some cases mental institutes help patients worsen their condition due to over medication and irrelevant conversations initiated by the nurses. it was interesting to see for every opportunity the patients had to escape, something always retained them to stay. for most of them, the institute was their home. they would not be able to function in society and may face rejection by others due to their stigmas. their fear of rejection is what kept them isolated in the hospital, not the barbed fence and secured windows. their only family was the ones inside the institute. Jack brought awareness to each individual in the hospital and made them realize they had a voice. when he died, a part of them died with him!the native Chief represents an important factor in this film. natives are the most discriminated people of our history.we see that he to is afraid to escape into the real world because of the racism. when he observes what is done to Jack in the end of the film, he knows he is better off out in the real world. He takes the risk so he can go to Canada where most of the reserves for natives are held. there he will be accepted. Billy killing himself expresses how the doctors and nurses had power to fear and control the patients using their weaknesses in character and personality. it is a sort of brainwash and manipulation tactic hospitals use to overpower their patients. taking away their freedom of speech, will to live is was really makes the patients ill. taking away their self- consciousness and alienating them of their existence. one normal man awakens the ones who are asleep and shows them they have freedom of speech and a chance for change. when his actions begin to work, the doctors fear him, so they shock him until he is a vegetable.this is a great metaphor on how the government has control over the citizens using tactics to manipulate us. making us believe everything we see even if it is not the truth. we as humans live in high secure society, but don't realize it.more and more are political systems are taking control of our freedom to live in order to have complete control our way of thinking and living. this resembles the metaphor behind this film. a good example is president Jfk who was assassinated because he wanted change and good for the society. Same with jack, he is assassinated from his essence as a great human being,to be left with no more identity and self awareness of himself.it easier for the government to stuff patients with pills so they don't interfere with the ideal society they are trying to construct with perfect flawless people.this film expresses how sometimes for some people, illness is socially constructed and not biological related. pressures from the ideal society is what makes them sick. two thumbs up for the written script and performances in this epic film!

reviews.review_title: Novels are always better than their movies except this
reviews.content: I prefer reading books than watching their movies, because I can create everything as I wish while reading. But I do not believe that anyone can create this movie better than its director , players, and all its team.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is not only one of the best films of the 1970s - winning the top five Oscars (Best Picture, Actor, Actress, Director and Screenplay) back in the day when those little golden bookends meant something - it is one of the most socially significant movies yet made about the late-20th century counterculture movement.Based on the 1962 novel by Ken Kesey, Milos Forman's 1975 film stars Jack Nicholson as R. P. McMurphy, an erratic and violent, but fully functioning, sociopath who is transferred from a prison work detail to the Oregon State Mental Hospital for evaluation of his behavioral health. In the ward, McMurphy's confidence and charisma immediately enchant his timid and unstable fellow patients, but his careless nonconformism also butts him up against the iron will of Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher), who rigidly controls the happenings in her wing and doesn't take to challenges of her authority.While McMurphy is often romanticized as a hero of the free spirit, neither Kesey's story nor Forman's film shy away from the character's darker edges, painting a complete picture of the complex paradoxes tearing at the 1960s youth movements. While the cruel severity of Ratched's stern villainy often obscures McMurphy's serious character flaws, making him seem, by contrast, like a liberating angel, he is really a selfish, reckless and dangerous criminal rogue, incapable of operating within a society without causing damage and chaos at every turn.Nevertheless, within Ratched's totalitarian system, McMurphy's rule-breaking is a tonic for the other inmates. It's important, however, that many them are self-imprisoned, voluntarily in the hospital, hiding from the outer world because they lack the very bold qualities that, unrestrained, have resulted in McMurphy's incarceration. Ratched's dominating approach is not aimed at healing her patients, but rather at controlling them through routine, and the central power struggle between her and McMurphy has little to do with their welfare and takes a heartbreaking toll on the most fragile caught between the two irreconcilable extremes.

I am kicking myself for being so unobservant. Films, books, and plays are three different art forms and 'Cuckoo's Nest' has the (mis)fortune of existing in all three stages. None are good examples of their respective forms. This is a good movie but it doesn't deserve to be in the top 10 IMDb list. I think the reason why this movie has so high grade is because people like Jack Nicholson so much. This movie may deserve to be between the top 100, but no way in the top 10.

reviews.review_title: If Looks Could Kill... Oh, I guess they can!
reviews.content: One Flew Over The Cukoo's Nest is still a lesson in casting for any film maker. Jack Nicholson and Louis Fletcher? Ouch! I can feel the tension! Then look at the launching of some familiar names: Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd, Brad Dourif. Great novel, excellent movie!

I rarely give 9's on here. Movies I love have an 8, eh movies get a 7 or 6, terrible are 5 and below, but that's just me. I never give 10's because nothing is perfect, but 9's are the special ones. The movies I give a 9 to mean they are one of my favorite movies. This is such a rollercoaster of a movie. Funny, sad and just downright disturbing at times. A Must see classic for everyone.

This may indeed be perfect cinema!It has everything a film needs in my view. The message of the film is subtle yet clear enough for all to grasp. The main theme (there are many) to me was 'What is madness? Where does the line get drawn? and If McMurphy is mad then what are you?'The issue if insanity is essential for all humans to explore as we may be closer than we think to it at any given point in our lives. Not just old age! But like all great films, Milos Forman skilfully teases us and does not give any concrete answers. Like life itself, all is ambiguous and incomplete and mysterious.The story is warm yet cold, funny yet tragic, beautiful yet ugly, entertaining yet important. How did they do it? That's the mystery of a great film!One thing I know...'at least I tried...god damit...at least I did that.' is the greatest scene and quote in cinema that I know.

reviews.review_title: Excellent Movie Based on Excellent Book
reviews.content: As the protagonist, Nicholson does a great job portraying the complicated Mac: on one hand he is loving, encouraging, and optimistic even to those who didn't draw the best hand in life. On the other, he is violent and self-absorbed.As the antagonist, Fletcher does a great job demonstrating the subtlety of Nurse Ratched's evil: professional, even-keeled, patient and not outwardly disparaging towards any of the movies for the entire film, she nonetheless represents an institution who only pretends to do the job of looking out for the best interests of its patients. When she convincingly states that her ward is up to the challenge of Mac and wanting to improve his situation, I was left briefly surprised that the supposed antagonist actually cared to help Mac. But then in a climactic moment near the end, we see her squash Billy's confidence, clearly a key characteristic he'd been lacking. I thought the movie did a particularly excellent job showcasing the effect Nurse Ratched was able to wield over the young Billy in that scene.I remember the book being incredible, and the same is true of the movie.

reviews.review_title: One of my favorite movies of all time
reviews.content: It is hard to believe that the author of the book this movie is based on didn't like it. It is simply one of those classic movies.First of all this is a very realistic film. Even more realistic than Goodfellas (1990), and that is also hard to believe because of how melodramatic it is. While Goodfellas didn't have that many intense, or dramatic moments (likely because it was narrated over so often), this movie had more than a few tense and dramatic moments, yet it was still more realistic. Why? Because of the setting: A mental institution.Randle Mc Murphy is sent to a mental institution, because of his apparent mental disability (which is really a lie so he can get out of jail.) After spending time in the institution, he bonds with the other inmates, who actually are disabled, apart from one, The Chief, whom Randle makes a special bond with. During his time there, he manages to get them out of the institution, for a few hours, on a fishing trip. He throws a nigh time party, in which they all get drunk. And he rallies the patients to become rebellious and rise against the staff, and one nurse particularly. While Randle represents chaos in this film, Nurse Mildred Ratched represents order. Very strict order at that.What is described here is just the tip of the iceberg of this film. Despite it's severely depressing tone, the plot draws you in, and makes your root for Randle and The Chief. This is one of those few films that I would call, very intense, and very realistic, as many realistic films, contain a lot of slow paced conversations, where as in this there's tension most of the time. For that reason it's one of my favorites and for that reason I give it a 10/10

My 2nd Favorite move-maybe 1st favorite-has so much plot led by great actors that it even bagged itself the best 5 Oscars (picture, director, actor, actress, screenplay). I have always felt that a movie should have a real powerful ending, and this has got it. Best Ending for a movie by far and the way Milos Forman directs the people shows that he either knows the way people act (or the writer of the book does), or it's a true story which I have often wondered. In fact if anyone knows if it is a true story or not, if they would email me telling me if it is or not I would thank them. Because the way he reaches these patients (mostly Chief is in mind here) and the patient he reaches reveals something about themselves because they feel closer to him, it's just great. All- Around great film!

I can't think of any movie that has characters written so well, or emotions so brilliantly felt and delivered as much as this one.Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher were astounding, and the script was incredible!  This film makes the audience root for a very unique and three-dimensional protagonist.  The movie never finds a slow point, and the director ignites this amazing story of a group of "crazy" people who change their lives.This is not your average feel-good movie.  I give it a 10!

This film was a total surprise for me as I became more reserved with much applauded older movies (like Citizen Kane and Zorba the Greek) which did not really live up to the expectation.The acting of Jack N. is absolutely superb; the story unfolds slowly and builds up the necessary tension until the last minute. The continuous blending of the crazy and normal worlds is so well done that in the end I was no longer sure which was which. This is a serious drama but every now and then there are genuine hilarious moments, of which a few are simply brilliant.It's a film worth re-watching periodically. For me it means an opportunity to reflect on our "normal" society/lives and fight prejudice of any kind.

reviews.review_title: Watched this in preparation for Ratched. It's really an amazing film.
reviews.content: There is not a single bad performance in this film. Jack Nicholson acts his ass off and proves why he is one of the greatest actors of all time yet again. Not at all surprised that he won the Oscar for this. Although, I am honestly surprised Louise Fletcher won the academy award because honestly although her performance as Ratched was good, it was something that wasn't overly impressive. While Nicholson is the only actor that I could see nailing the role of McMurphy I can see someone else being capable of being Ratched. Danny Devito is awesome. All the side characters were really good.This film is actually a lot funnier than I thought it would be. I did not expect to be smiling and laughing as much as I was. (I was baked). It's also sad and hard to watch at times. Great filmmaking. The direction was really well done.Overall, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is an amazing film. I recommend checking this out. All the performances and characters are great and the story grabs your attention from the start. I wasn't bored at all. It's on Netflix, check it out. Great ending. Definitely was surprised. Although, I was confused about a few character choices.Excited to see Sarah Paulson kill it ass Ratched. She's a queen.

I was interested to see that at the Oscars, when clips were being shown of all the films that have won the best picture prize down the years, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest received by far the loudest cheer when it was shown. The reason for this must be that people in the film industry, who are involved in film making on a daily basis, appreciate this outstanding piece of cinema and what it took to make it. It boasts a perfect cast who all give flawless performances. When I first saw the film I truly thought that some of the cast, such as De Vito, were actually mentally handicapped. Of course, the two main performances are superb but they are given excellent support by the rest of the cast.The scene where MacMurphy is speaking to the doctor for the first time has to go down as one of the most realistic and natural scenes in the history of cinema.(You didn't weigh the chain did you doc ?) This film is an example of what cinema can accomplish and an inspiration to future screenwriters. It should be on everyone's top ten list.

This movie is something most people have seen, and for those who haven't' seen it, I highly recommend you to see it. The plot is riveting. I've seen many movies in life, but this is one of the very best I've ever seen. All the other "nuthouse" movies that were made after merely had the hopes of surpassing this one in terms of being remembered. Won't happen. Maybe this movie was so great because it was the first of its kind, but it's still amazing. The ending is very sad, but it's also unavoidable. Really don't want to give anything away, so you'll have to watch it yourself.Despite the facts this movie is a drama, it still has funny parts. Overall the movie is something that will always be remembered for causing changes in the mental hospital status. As a bit of trivia, the mental health "profession" actually hated this movie once they heard what it was about. There were even several attempts by the mental health profession to boycott the movie. Again, I advise anyone interested in a good flick to watch this.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies i've seen :)
reviews.content: In One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Randall Patrick McMurphy, is sentenced to a short prison term for statutory rape. Believing he has found a way to cheat the system McMurphy feigns insanity in order to be transferred to a mental institution. Here, he expects to spend the rest of his sentence in relative comfort far away from the work farm he was sentenced to. Instead, McMurphy willingly signs his life away to what he has been fighting against his entire life, established authority. McMurphy's open defiance against authority, in this case head nurse Ratched, becomes a vicious self destructive cycle.McMurphy's condescending attitude towards the ward's policies attracts negative attention and only inspires nurse Ratched to "help him". This help would eventually lead to his lobotomy, thus killing his fighting spirit.

This is an absolutely astonishing film that is without doubt the finest I have ever seen. Jack Nicholson's performance is certainly his best one, and maybe one of the greatest of all time. Yet Louise Fletcher very nearly equals him in a chilling portrayal of a woman so devoid of any emotion she seems almost robotic.I had read the book when I first watched it, so was prepared for the wide range of emotions that would be on display. But nothing quite prepared me for what I would see, I was most surprised at how funny it was, some scenes played purely for comedy.The ending completely floored me, the sudden switch from comedy to terrible, devastating tragedy was shattering. I absolutely recommend this film to anyone and everyone.

reviews.review_title: over all critique of the movie!
reviews.content: I have seen many movies in my life, and have many favorites while others are less enjoyable. Some movies are made purely for entertainment, and some actually send out messages. In the movie, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, the main character, Randal Patrick McMurphy, does enough in the movie that could be taken as a lesson.In the beginning of the movie, Randal starts out in jail for his assault-batter-rape sentence, where he is required to work in the prison farm. After spending a while on his term, he becomes tired of working there, and decides to make people believe he has a mental illness. He is sent to a psychiatric center where he thinks he will remain comfortable, and makes many friends, while serving his term. While no one's allowed to leave the center, he takes all of his newly acquired friends and decides to go out for an enjoyable day fishing. Due to his actions, he was judged by the head of the center and prison. The head nurse, Mildred Ratched, convinces others to let him stay and have McMurphy stay to get therapeutic aid, only because after a few weeks of being evaluated, he was caught as the center knew he was pretending to be ill. McMurphy changes the atmosphere of the center only to realize that he was better off at the prison farm. Every time McMurphy messes up, he goes through the pain of electro shock therapy. From all of his friends there was one, The Chief, who gained his trust and respect since he too was fooling the staff. Later on, when McMurphy decided to break out of the center, he threw a party, where all the patients were drinking and doing everything they were not suppose to. The next morning one of the patient was found in bed with a woman, and from the fear from his mother finding out, he committed suicide. when McMurphy learned about the incident, he attempted to kill nurse Ratched by choking her. He was taken to the shock therapy room, where he had gone through so much pain, he had turned into a human vegetable, and his body was dragged back to his room. Chief could not witness him in his current state, he believed McMurphy had no choice, and it was to reduce his suffering and was better this way so he covered his face with a pillow and killed him, because he believed McMurphy . Chief then used McMurphy's idea to escape the center, that both had decided to do together.McMurphy was better off at the prison, then at the center, where his lie had taken his life. McMurphy's plan was great, his down fall was, that he slacked off to much. He wanted to have fun, before getting out, which cost him his life.Chief played his cards right, and no one suspected a thing from him, and he got away with it. It is better to go through and serve the time for your guilt, then try to get out of it through a lie. McMurphy lost everything while trying to beat the system, but the system beat him. No matter what in the end, a person will still go through punishment one way or another.

reviews.review_title: Mental asylum as metaphor of contemporary society
reviews.content: Murphy, a resourceful convict, pleads insanity in order to avoid heavy physical work and spend the rest of his sentence in a "friendly environment." However, when he is committed to the a mental institution he finds himself in a situation in which sadistic medical personnel abuses and humiliates patients, systematically destroying their self-confidence and self-esteem. When Murphy opposes the authority of the head nurse and other staff, an already charged atmosphere brings tensions to a boiling point, eventually resolving Murphy's resistance by electroshocks and lobotomy.This asylum is an exceptional metaphor of contemporary society. It raises some very serious questions, such as the normalization of the disbalance of power, the political (mis)use of normality and mental illness, the role of repressive mental institutions in maintaining stability of the system, as well as question of obedience to authority and brutal methods that authority uses to preserves its hegemony.One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest quickly gained status of a cult movie and became a must-see for all rebellious ones who felt resistance and the thirst for change, as well as the need to fundamentally re-examine the ideological basis of the world we live in. The movie ranked in the top fifty of the American Film Institute's list and is generally regarded as one of the best films ever made.

This is a great film about how one man disrupted the order of things within a (mental) institution to the point whereby he was punished. It's a sad film by the end, but otherwise it's quite an entertaining movie with lots of heart and lots of laughs. At the centre of all this is Jack Nicholson, who delivers yet another terrific performance as R.P McMurphy - his whole attitude is off the rails and I love it. On the opposite side of the fence is Nurse Ratched, played by Louise Fletcher. A worthy opponent to McMurphy, Nurse Ratched is cold, calculated and basically an all round first class b*tch.To conclude, the writing/screenplay is definitely one of the best ever written and why the film doesn't really go into the reasons why its patients are there in the first place, it does showcase the many wild and wonderful situations patients can find themselves in once there (especially with a character like McMurphy around). Terrific. 8/10 (4*)
A complete marvel Jack Nicholson steals every frame...

reviews.review_title: A few thoughts on this magnificent film
reviews.content: Well, my guess is that by the time i am finished writing this, there will be more than a couple spoilers, so those who havent seen it may wish to skip this review.That being said, i have watched this movie many times now. Strangely enough, i had not seen it until just a couple weeks ago, when i bought it on DVD without having ever learned about it. Somehow i knew i would enjoy it.  To understate my reaction, I was extremely impressed.What truly stood out for me was Nicholson's performance.  I have seen many of his movies, but i believe that this was the first film i have seen of his that took place in the earlier years (well, Easy Rider is another, but that isnt necessesarily a Nicholson movie). Very few actors that i have ever observed have the simple PRESENCE that this man does within this film.  Every glimpse, every facial expression, his body language, even his clothing add to his performance.One of my very favorite shots of the movie is during the first meeting that McMurphy is present.  When he notices Nurse Ratched pestering Billy, the simple, unspoken action of him playing with his card deck is enough to convey more than any piece of dialogue ever could.  The posture reeks of defiance, the eye contact and facial expression reveal his immediate understanding and suspicion of the dynamic beteween the nurse and the patients.  It is no more than, perhaps, 5 seconds, but it truly left a mark on me.Anyway, the real reason that i wrote this is because i had a thought regarding the interaction between McMurphy and the Chief.  It seems to me that the Chief is representitive of the spirit world, and McMurphy is representitive of the hedonistic, purely human world. As the movie progresses, and McMurphy slowly changes his behavior, Chief actually seems to mirror the progression, except, he does it in the opposite fashion.In a way, it seems as though the two characters are actually one soul.  As McMurphy comes into the hospital, he is self-centered, arrogant, and seeks attention.  However, as the movie progresses, his attitude changes, and he develops a legitimate concern and love for the 'patients' that inhabit the ward with him.**DEFINITE SPOILER***Just prior to the first electroconvulsive shock therapy, we are introduced to the fact that chief is neither deaf nor dumb, and is infact a passive observer within this hospital.  Ironically, this moment of growth within chief, where he learns to trust mcmurphy with his secret, is mirrored by mcmuphy's initial steps of psychological and spiritual progression.  After the ECT, he displays a greater interest in others, as well as a subtl appreciation of his position.  Concurrently, Chief, though expressing his feeling of powerlessness, is growing in strength, feeding off of McMurphy's raw energy and enthusiasm.As the next few scenes progress, with the climax of Chief taking McMurphy with him through one of the most compassionate death scenes i have ever witnessed, it felt as though we, as an audience, witnessed the assimilation of McMurphy's soul with that of Chief's.No doubt that this particular interpretation is influenced by the naturally spiritual/enlightened nature of native americans, but even if completely unintentional, the spiritual connection and transition seem to be there.Additionally, when it is revealed that most of the patients there are voluntary, a whole new dynamic is added, not only to the individual characters, but to the interactions between them.   The idea that they voluntarily put themselves in such a place infers that they simply can not deal with leading their own lives, and require the close supervision and regimine that the hospital provides to them.Because of this, it seems that all of the repressed personality traits within each character instead become the dominant traits due to the ability to act as 'strangely' as desired within such an environment.  Once this is revealed, so much of the interaction becomes a 'play' of sorts.**end of spoiler stuff***well, all in all, its phenominal.  i could keep going and going, but i wont at this time.  I simply dont know what more to say.  All of the performances are inspired and moving.  There was not one character who I did not get to 'know' in one way or another. thanks for reading.

Milos Forman's better film is Amadeus. But Cuckoo's Nest still has some great acting and drama. It's a good movie, a dark one, and complex. You're not sure who's the real villain or who is the real good guy. It has its nice moments but overall it didn't blow me away. In the end, it felt like the movie flipped the script too quickly and changed the story just to make it meaningful. The third act is also a little muddled.
The bars were unlocked, the window was open and there was a car outside... he got what he deserved. I have to have 150 characters to submit a review. One hundred fifty.

An anti-establishment film that springs from the disillusioned sentiments of writer Ken Kesey, this film is in my opinion the finest ever made. Though limited in scope, with almost all of the film taking place in the confined space of an insane asylum, like the main character McMurphy, it transcends its limitations and exudes a universal promotion of human freedom.

Mac is sent to the mental hospital after he committed some violent crimes. In the hospital, patients are obedient and allow themselves to be controlled by the nurse Ratched. The conflict between freedom vs control is represented by the two.Aside from violence, Mac is just a nice guy. He cannot understand why the patients don't enjoy their lives. So he encourages them to have fun. Jack Nicholson plays the role with his impulsive body movement and his signature naughty smile.On the other hand, Ratched has a formidable appearance with a tall body and a weird hairstyle like a crown. She shows an obvious desire to rule, not just obligation.Another key character is Chief. You will somehow notice from the earlier that he hides intelligence, by seeing his calm eyes and delicate expressions. Unlike whimsical Mac, Chief's presence is growing throughout the film like subconscious determination.I think the best part of this film is the acting of every other patient. Cheswick, Martini, Harding, and Taber, I can't forget everyone's face. As those who have mental disorders, they look weird at first. But actually, they are just like us, only lacking skills to hide emotions, which we are demanded from society. In their peculiar body motions and expressions, we see their raw emotions and we love them.The best example is Billy, played by Brad Dourif. His stutter is somehow even pleasant to hear. He looks up and down frequently, showing that he goes back and forth between courage and fear. He is too innocent to realize he is a victim of oppression, if not abuse. And so are many other patients.

You can read the plotline elsewhere - I just wanted to add that I saw this at the cinema when it was first released and I will never forget the stunned silence of the audience as it closed.  So many questions hung in the air, but, by the looks on their faces - everyone understood only too well what the message was.  Powerful, thought-provoking doesn't come near....a fine set of performances to relish.

A group of people orgy, a one-man lunatic asylum. In the movie, the lunatic asylum is a place with strong metaphors. Autocracy runs wild, freedom and personality are extremely suppressed and deprived. It is a modeled general autocracy. It uses the sounding banner to deceive and deceive people, depriving people of their personality. A lunatic is a relative definition that requires a certain evaluation standard. In the eyes of a lunatic, those so-called normal people are not lunatics.

While Nicholson gives a bravura performance, it is the players, the other patients, who give this film the charm and vrisimilitude which makes Cukoo an enduring classic. A very young Danny Divito and Christopher Lloyd, as well as Will Sampson, as "Chief", turn in especially charming performances. Of a certain age, the line, "Mmmmmm, Juicy Fruit." can bring a smile to anyone's face.

Starring Jack Nicholson, One Flew the Cuckoo's nest it is a piece of art. At the beginning of the film I've got a little confused, but that was because I was expecting something else. The well-worked plot and the awesome performances make this movie something else than that. The history, the storyboard and the final are simply awesome. The movie tries to got us into a metaphor of life, a critic one. And also invites us to analyze to our modern society, at the end of the day, Who are crazier, us or them?Excellent movie 10/10

I like this movie don't get me wrong, but I don't think it sits with some of the greats like compared to.
The character development is brilliant, pretty much every character has somewhat of an arc.
R.P. McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) seems to have many mini-arcs embedded within one large one going from being in this mental hospital for a laugh and scamming these patients, to actually caring for the other patients and probably needing to be there.
Furthermore, Jack Nicholson is the perfect casting for this role. His ability to show a psychologically unstable man is unparalleled, for any actor ever.
My problems with the movie stem from the understanding of the characters from the writers and directors. A lot of decisions characters make feel forced and needed to move the plot rather than what a character would do.
I understand the director might have done this to show the psychology of the patients however I feel it doesn't pay off here like it does in other movies about mentally ill people, mainly Forest Gump.
Also I did feel at times too many scenes were in there and felt unnecessary, which lost the immersion of the movie.7-8/10 can't decideP.S. Danny DeVito is king

IF the criterion to judge the class of a movie is that how you are impressed in the end then it is one of the most frustrating movie I have ever seen. Although direction is very good, actors (All of them) have performed superbly, but the basic thing is storyline which in this movie is totally disappointing specially looking to the rating of this movie. There is no background or object of storyline. Extremely meaningless ending. In fact it is the end of the movie that virtually ruined each and every beautiful aspect of this movie which otherwise could have been a masterpiece. A beautiful Ferrari destroyed in accident with dirty hogs. This movie certainly does not deserve so high rating.

reviews.review_title: If I'd had to choose a favorite, I'd choose this one
reviews.content: Nicolson really convinces me that even brave, unconventional minds can't stand up to a suppressing regime that legitimizes itself on the idea of intellectual and psychological superiority. That kinda makes me feel sad. But the way his actions motivate others to oppose authority figure nurse Ratched, washes that feeling away instantly and puts a smile on my face.This movie made me experience intense gloom as well as intense joy. That's why when people ask me for my favorite movie I just always name this one.

To me, with this movie, it was good, not great. I'm thinking that Jack Nicholson was basically looking for something to do, to keep his acting chops good, so when something major comes along, he could be better in that role than his last role.

I first saw this movie with my father when I was 13. Not being subjected to all that many 'R' movies, I was excited. Even though I was only at the young age of 13, I absorbed the movie with full understanding. This is probably the best movie Jack Nicholson has ever been in, and is POWERFUL POWERFUL POWERFUL! And if you agree with this while viewing Cuckoo's Nest, just wait until the ending.

reviews.review_title: Cheswick and the loonies under a microscope
reviews.content: An awesome, gripping film. Certainly the best film of the 1970's and probably my favorite ever. This film really gave me a kick in the ass. Salute to Milos Forman, the cast, and crew for turning in an intense, harrowing (but nonetheless hopeful) film that illustrates the very best and worst of people. Since there are many obvious praises (Nicholson's magnetic smart-ass that we all want to be, R.P. McMurphy, as well as the stringent Nurse Ratched, Danny DeVito's as the hilarious Martini and Christopher Lloyd's confrontational, border psychotic Taber, etc.), I think that Sidney Lassick as Charlie Cheswick is not regarded as being as important to the film as he is in actuality. I have never seen in my life a performance that is so truthful and engaging. Looking back at personal experiences with "mentally disturbed" individuals I see a Cheswick in many of them. Both Cheswick and Billy (Brad Dourif) are children in men's bodies. We see them everyday on the streets, men who are not quite tough or hard-edged enough to act as men supposedly should. Look at how Cheswick "just wants to help" or how Billy searches for acceptance under restrictive and scorning eyes. Then look at the slick, pompous yuppies on the streets and how they gave up caring about anybody but themselves long ago. Who would you rather be your buddy? These two guys represent a lot of the naivenes of being a kid that you have to destroy in growing up. Stuff that you miss when you get older. So I get sad when I see Chewick and Billy cuz I know they're the little men who don't understand authority and discipline and are thus punished for their actions. Nice guys they are. All these characters represent a distinguishing quality that makes me actually give a crap about humans. I see the faces of all these guys in countless people every time I look hard enough. RATING: 10/10 -GRIFF- p.s. I'm desperately in need of a wet nurse.

reviews.review_title: Cheswick and the loonies under a microscope
reviews.content: An awesome, gripping film. Certainly the best film of the 1970's and probably my favorite ever. This film really gave me a kick in the ass. Salute to Milos Forman, the cast, and crew for turning in an intense, harrowing (but nonetheless hopeful) film that illustrates the very best and awful of people. Since there are many obvious praises (Nicholson's magnetic, smart-ass that we all want to be, R.P. McMurphy, as well as the stringent Nurse Ratched) I think that Sidney Lassick as Charlie Cheswick is not regarded as important to the film as he is in actuality. Then take the slick, pompous jerks on the streets and how they gave up caring about anybody but themselves long ago. Who would you rather be your buddy?
