I will say that some of the content could be disturbing to those who have not read the book or are not familiar with mental illness. I feel that the movie can be enjoyed by everyone. It is funny, heartwarming, thought provoking, and has its serious moments. I would recommend this movie to anyone who has read the book, has an interest in the mental health field, or who is in the mood to laugh, cry, and think.

reviews.review_title: Message is greater than what meets the eyes
reviews.content: In the book, story follows a man who is sent to prison for rape of a 15 year old girl, this part is not mentioned in the movie.Did not understand and appreciate the message in the movie first. I had to read reviews and articles on the movie to understand that the author was talking about life in general. Its not about the mental asylum only. It was fun to watch Danny DeVito play one of his first roles. Pace of the movie is excellent. Liked excellent portrayal of Nurse Ratched. Some excellent camera angle work can be appreciated. You feel attached to the patients due to their acting skills. Even the ending is not straight forward one has to conceptualize and understand why and what happened. This is one of the great film endings.
Watches this again for the first time in many years. Some films fade as time passes. This doesn't. Uplifting while being so sad at the same time. A classic.
Don't deny a man his basic right to have a goddamn beer and watch the game in the completely lucid lunacy of life well lived.

The film was impressive, bringing about the right words at all costs a lot of dissatisfaction, a man with a knowledge of McMurray, it was clear who is real crazy!, This movie was a great scene, but I'd love the sequel where McMurphy slipped behind the microphone with a slow slider saying: "Wake up," the kids woke up when they took the medicine, then laughed together ... McMurphy could have escaped with Chief but did not do it. He was happy before going, even with his keeper who made Ikaro ... when he said goodbye to everyone's sadness. Why are not you going to be upset when you go? McMurffy could have been back when Billy was in the room with a slowness, but he did not go, even when Billie was killed, he went to Bailey ... McMurfy was a man, but always a hero for his friend.

reviews.review_title: an energetic con man convict is sent to a mental hospital where he changes the lives of everyone there forever.
reviews.content: Not a single fan of film can declare One Flew Over the Cukoo's Nest as anything less than spectacular.  It has all the key elements of a great film.  From story to photography.  From character to performance.  It has a life of it's own.  I have found over the years that there are moviegoers and there are film lovers.  This is a film lover's film.  A film for those who find crying as important as laughing, and thinking important to us all.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: This movie was such an amazing story, plot, theme and group of actors I have ever seen. To have some of the greatest actors in our generation in one movie was genius and it was even more amazing that they were all at the start of their great iconic careers. I would watch this movie every time it came on television and I own the movie on DVD myself. Jack Nicholson did an amazing at acting the way he did and every actor gave a me the feeling that the character they played was actually them in real life. I had lots of emotions in this movie and it allowed me to see how messed up the system of mental hospitals were during that time period. The best part to me was the end because it was a very unexpected way to end the movie and it upset to be honest, but I still overall loved the movie!

If I have to choose what is my favorite movie of all time, I definitely choose One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest. This movie has everything: great performances (by the way, Jack Nicholson is my favorite actor, and his role on this movie is outstanding), a really good screenplay, and the awesome Milos Forman as the director. The parallelism between the mental asylum's life and the real life, will let you thinking a lot. Every character show a different face, a different situation, a different problem. Is totally understandable this movie won the 'Big Five Academy Award', it's a cult film. You must watch it before you die, be sure you won't regret about it.

After seeing the movie in IMDBs top 250 movies list. I watched the movie with more expectations..Its not up to expectations. Story theme is good, but not the way it presented.At the end of movie.. I didn't felt its a great movie.. Its normal regular movie.Actors performed well. Especially the way Nurse talks, expressions, they are the best. Characterization of each and every character makes real feeling.Jack performance is really good. Few Dialogues are simple and make sense.

It's a true masterpiece. Like something that was wrenched from the surreal dreams, images in this movie are dark, funny, disturbing, thought-provoking, and profound, all at the same time. This is truly a movie you can watch multiple times and find new themes each time. When it was released, it had some important things to say. Today, in our society that is scared into semi-paralysis by the threat of terrorists and the overly oppressive response of our own government, this movie is more relevant than ever. If you pay attention, you may actually walk away from this movie with a profound sense of understanding. Most everyone I have recommended this movie to has been deeply moved in some way by it. This movie should be required viewing!

I have rarely seen films so good that I am left speechless.  I could talk about Nicholson's superb performance, the excellent script, the provocative social questions the film raises.... but my "analysis" of this movie would only ruin it.  All I can say is this movie is an intelligent masterpiece.

Recently got a video of this film, which I had seen on first release in 1975, for my son's 23d birthday. Watched it again. Then again. Four times total, each time more engrossing. What a perfect film: story from Ken Kesey, casting, acting, directing. What a powerful and symbolic performance from Will Sampson as Big Chief! And McMurphy: counterpoint between a living human being and the smothering, oppressive, deadening--and murderous--force of society. Scatman Crothers, Dourif, Nicholson are superb. An easy 10. I have never seen a more moving cinematic scene than the final impulsive run to freedom meshing with that unforgettable musical score.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is jack Nicholson best film and one of my all time favorites. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a moving film which should be seen with an open mind and the first viewing should be by yourself so you can take in the film without judgment by anyone else. With an inspiring story of a mental hospital. It doesn't contain any amazing shots but it has an amazing cast which all give amazing performances. Fantastic film. I can't say anything that hasn't been said already, just see it. Worth getting on Blu Ray! I have never seen such a moving film in my life, it has absolutely touched me and left my thinking about the movie for hours it is an absolute must see. See it soon.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's nest was directed by Milos Forman in 1975. The movie's protagonist named Randle McMurphy (played by Jack Nicholson) is serving jail time for a rape charge. While serving his sentence, McMurphy fakes insanity to get switched to a mental institution for evaluation. Thinking that staying in the psych ward will be cake compared to the big house, he is introduced to the movie's antagonist, his enemy, Nurse Ratched. The movie goes on to show McMurphy's actions/behaviors toward authority while making everyday life for the patients more enjoyable. jack Nicholson delivers an amazing performance on screen bringing much needed comedic relief to ease the tension built up throughout the film. The story of this movie is incredible and tells messages that may or may not change the way you think/feel about it. The film is rated number 20 on the American Film institute's 100 years... 100 movies list.

reviews.review_title: Nod bad, interesting but maybe a bit overrated
reviews.content: Well I enjoyed this film, its interesting and wasn't boring. But it doesn't have the depths I mean nothing to think about later, Nicholson is great and so in nurse witched, just doing their jobs, I didn't see wickensy or evil in the nurse she just did her duty. Nicholson is an actor you can't dislike, he brings life into that poor environment, but maybe he should have been more 'bad'.This isn't a perfect movie, the chief 'suddenly' begins to respond, its too easy to escape from this place, the fishing scene might be unnecessary and unrealistic, maybe was shot due to the nice views, but there are many nice scenes. Maybe time also reduces the hype over the movie. I missed some love scene between Rutched and Jack.Not bad but not so great.

reviews.review_title: One of the most thought provoking, heartwarming, yet disheartening films I have ever had the pleasure of viewing!
reviews.content: SPOILER ALERT!!!At the end of the movie when Jack Nicholson had part of his brain removed in order to tame him I was speechless. I thought to myself, "how did we actually do this to human beings!" I thank God that changes were made to how the United States of America, as well as several more industrialized nations throughout the world, have made reforms to their mental health system. And I pray that changes are made where they have not been made. One thing that I loved about this film was the fact that only a criminal convicted of assault and statutory rape was able to be kind to those who had nowhere to go, and nobody to stand up for them. To conclude, I must say that Jack Nicholson is one of the greatest actors of our time and I absolutely believe he deserves to be remembered as one of the top ten actors of all time.

reviews.review_title: A movie to remember (contains many spoilers!!!)
reviews.content: One Who Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is a movie about Randle McMurphy, played by Jack Nicholson, who is transferred to a mental institution for mental evaluation from a prison farm. He hopes to avoid the hard work and relax the rest of his sentence by trying to pretend to be crazy. In the institution he meets a cast of characters such as Billy Bibbit (Brad Dourif), Chief (Will Simpson), Martini (Danny Devito) and quite a few other people on the ward during his stay. The main nurse Mildred Ratched (Louis Fletcher) serves as the antagonist who keeps a firm hold on her ward, while Murphy mixes things up in the ward, really showing everyone how to live outside of Ratched's control.The main theme in this movie is freedom. And not necessarily freedom from the institution itself, but freedom from the mental barriers that exist, possibly because of the institution. Of course everyone in the institution has some sort of mental setback, and they sit through the therapy sessions with Nurse Ratched, but these sort of sessions simply point out their issues, and don't necessarily instill any self-confidence in the individuals themselves, and bury themselves deeper into their issues. Such as when Nurse Ratched gives Billy a hard time when he speaks about the time he told a girl he wanted to marry her, but never told his mother about the relationship in the first place; instead of providing any helpful insight to this issue. This all changes of course, when McMurphy comes into the picture. He brings a sense of life into the institute, and helps instill individualism in each member of the ward, being able to speak up for themselves. Such as the scene where Cheswick speaks up about wanting his cigarettes when Ratched starts to ration them since the boys would lose all their cigarettes to McMurphy while betting on card games. McMurphy even convinces Chief to stop playing dumb and deaf, and finally leave the ward. This plan all goes south, however, when during a party Billy sleeps with Candy and Nurse Ratched finds out. Billy commits suicide after the nurse tells him that she will tell his mother about his escapades. McMurphy strangles Ratched, leaving her in a neck brace. He is however, given a lobotomy essentially making him a vegetable. While McMurphy didn't come in with a mental illness, he did have one now. Chief, seeing how his spirit was broken, knew it was the time for freedom. He freed McMurphy of his body by smothering him with a pillow, then breaking the glass with the large marble counter in the tub room, running off into the sunrise. He gave McMurphy the freedom he would want, and the spirit of freedom was instilled into the rest of the ward, as they cheered on Chief when he ran. While it's hard to say what would happen to the ward after the fact, the spirit of freedom still lives on in all of them, along with the true memory of McMurphy. No one else saw him as the vegetable he became, so the hope and power given to them may convince them to have the self-confidence to leave the ward, as many were there voluntarily.

reviews.review_title: A Great Cast and Amazing Direction
reviews.content: Cuckoo's Nest is one of those movies where you can watch endless times and see something new every time. Every character has their own life, DeVito's "Martini" is one of my favorites. The movie can make you laugh and cry, or smile and want to break the screen, but in the end, the movie is a perfect example of what film can do. Milos Foreman tells the story so crisp and clear it is like viewing a movie in 4K. Nicholson gives hands down one of the most memorable characters ever that has ever been in film and the patients besides McMurphy (Nicholson) are portrayed so well that it is easy to forget that they are acting. It's hard to adapt great books into film, but this is one of the circumstances in which the book is just as good as the movie. A goofy, dramatic, heartwarming film that will be timeless to me and I hope others.

So many people have reviewed this movie, there really isn't anything I can add. But did want to make one comment.If you can watch this film and not be brought to tears at the end of the fishing scene, when the mental patients are proudly showing off their catch as the boat returns to shore, in an outing when they obviously are enjoying themselves in a welcome diversion from the monotony of being held in the institution, then something is wrong with you.There are many great scenes in Cuckoo's Nest, but that, I think, is my favorite one of all.

Firstly, I would like to say, What the hell is wrong with all of you people. The movie sucked, for many reasons. Firstly to any of you who didn't know, this movie was a remake of the book written by Ken Kesey, who refused to work on the screenplay because it would not be told in the same way as the book. If you had read the book you would understand my reasoning. The movie is one of the worst portrayals of a book that I have ever seen. They left so many details out of the movie that were in the book. Two Thumbs down, hopefully this crap will again be remade into something way better than what this is. This should not have been nominated for best picture (1975), and should not have won. The actors who got career boosts from this movie should feel ashamed for working in such a horrible movie and benefiting from it.

reviews.review_title: A crazy good romp through human personalities.
reviews.content: With all the elements of a masterfully crafted film, this title does its part to expose the nature of man and the ends to which he will go and be pushed. Nicholson's role as a patient pretending to be mentally ill seems perfect for him, and he plays the part with humor, violence, and tenderness when appropriate. His antics in the institution inspire real growth and therapy for the other patients, as opposed to the iron fisted order imposed by the loathsome Nurse Ratched, who's name i found particularly appropriate as she was always manipulating the patients. I found her strangulation to be particularly satisfying, no doubt a product of the great performances and writing of the film. Aesthetically not too much caught my eyes from an artistic point of view, although certain scenes, like the fishing scene and the closing scene with the chief walking over the hills as a silhouette, were done with profound meaning. Overall this film works as a commentary and study into the lives of some mentally unstable people, and shows the cycle of craziness begetting craziness.

This was actually filmed at a mental hospital based on real people and behaviors. It's something you need to see. I work at a hospital for the criminally insane and it feels as though some bring it upon themselves. Might as well make it what you want. Just be careful for what you ask for in life.

He was a big boy when he moved to Hollywood and start making some US movies, so am I surprised of this? No, really. It's great such as his older movies from Czechoslovakia. But one of the best as he ever directed in America.

This movie is an incredibly impressive movie and Jack Nicholson is a great actor. That is what first went through my mind after seeing this masterpiece. I've seen many movies, but there aren't much movies which had such an impact on me.

reviews.review_title: Finally have seen it the third time!
reviews.content: The bad nurse who treats the mentally unstable without humanity was existing in reality. Not only the doctors or nurses in hospital, but also everyone within our society should show some mercy to the unfortunate people sometimes. People are very confusing when facing to themselves. We need to give each others some courage to go along life.

i highly enjoyed watching this movie. Jack Nicholson played his character superbly. \I am still uncertain if i think R.P. McMurphy was actually crazy or not. I kind of think he really was faking it the whole time because life was easier in a mental hospital and so was a chance at escape, which he tried a few times. I think the point of the movie is to show that mental patients are not totally incompetent and do not need to be forced into a strict routine. You see in the movie that with a little change in routine, a little excitement, even the patients that are most out of it become more alive and personable. still, it is also shown that too much freedom turns to chaos.This was a great movie with great acting and a powerful message.

One of my favourite. Jack Nicolson really nailed it. Thank director, actors and backup team. Love you guys!!!
By an 18 year old filmofill.

I liked this movie because I know that I can relate along with most other people. I loved Jack Nicholson's acting. I thought that he really played the character well and how the director imagined the part to be done. I think this movie brings up interesting points regarding Mental illness and what it actually is. Just because someone is mentally ill does that mean that they can't function in society and be locked up. I think that this movie did a good job on tackling some of the stereotypes and misconceptions about mental illness all the while taking us through an interesting story with great acting. This is one of the more interesting social commentary films that I have seen.

This is my all time favourite movie of all time! It's based on a novel by Ken Kesey. This movie stars Jack Nicholson as Randall Patrick McMurphy, a man pretending to be insane to avoid going to jail. It co-stars Louise Fletcher as Nurse Ratched and people like Danny DeVito and Christopher Lloyd as mental patients. This is the movie in which they got their starts. Also starring Brad Dourif as B-Billy B-Bibbit. A bit of a touchy subject sometimes dealt with controversy, it still a great find. It won Oscars in all the main categories, the first film to do so in over 30 years. With great acting and a great twist at the end, Cuckoos Nest was is and always will be a hit with everyone. XOXO Betty Boop

So, like my title would suggest, I Am having a difficult time figuring out where to begin with a review/comment about this film. I do not wish to reiterate all the same old things about how great it is, how it won the four major Oscars ( Picture, Direcotr, Actor/Actress), and how life changing it was. Please don't mistake the tone of this for cynicism, because it most certainly is not. I think the reason I am having so much trouble is because what can one person even say about this film? Seriously. Obviously from a technical standpoint the film is first rate. There is no doubt about that. The use of long takes, the gloomy feeling that the director and cinematographer bring to the ward all make for the feeling like something is crawling under your skin.. It is pretty creepy. But then, enter McMurphy (Nicholson), with his rebellious, wise-cracking ways, the I am smarter than you and I know it attitude, and the film turns comical. I did enjoy that part of it, the comedy that is. What I did not enjoy was the ending of the film. A lobotomy, really? The part that bothered me the most about the ending was not the film itself, but the fact that this film was only a small glimpse ( however artistically licensed) into the tragic world of life in mental health care facilities across the country at that time. What the hell were we (people in general) thinking? The electric chair is used to end someone's life, but a small dose for someone who is already clearly defective is OK? Really? That scene is probably one of the most memorable in the film next to the chief's escape and the party scene. The form and content of the film are excellent, as are all the technical aspects. The story moves along at a good speed, something often difficult to achieve in a movie with such a enclosed setting. The lighting is especially effective and the set design/ costumes all ring true for the time. it is very easy to see how both Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher attained their Oscar's, as both performances are some of the best I have ever seen. I would definitely recommend this film to anyone who wanted to see Jack at his finest as well as peer into the terrible world of the mentally ill.

reviews.review_title: still the best English-language movie I saw in last 15 years
reviews.content: When I saw that movie about 15 years ago it was a shock for me who grown in communist country. It proves that you can be free even in jail or mad house as long as you free inside yourself and that idea is the single most important idea of that movie. It's also best Jack Nicolson's movie for me. No matter how bad are the movies he does now, he remains one of the most prominent actors of all times just because of his role in One Flew ...

reviews.review_title: An excellent movie, but it could have followed the book better.
reviews.content: The movie, "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" directed by Milos Forman in 1975, was definitely seven out of ten stars. The movie, based upon the book, One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest by Ken Kesey, is an original novel coming to life. Words from a page are turned into a pleasing visual film that makes you sit on the edge of your seat. As a classic novel, the book does not follow the original written novel as closely, the main character changes from the book to the novel, and the emotions held within the novel are less-existing in the movie. The movie does not follow the book closely, leaving out key-events such as; the black boys seeming excited to take patients temperatures, or the event in which Mr. Harding's wife visits. Both of those events are not present in the film. The main character changes in the film, in the film, the main character is McMurphy, a wild man who is avoiding jail, while in the book, Chief Bromden is the main character; Chief Bromden tells the story through his eyes in the book, and this is not present in the film at all, instead Chief Bromden is rarely present within the film. Lastly, the emotions within the book are less-existing in the movie. In the book, mostly the emotions held are less pleasant and humorous, while in the film, the director tends to lean towards humor in the film. All of these reasons given further explain my reasoning for the rating I have given this movie. The movie does not follow the book, and after reading the book, this is disappointing, while the characters and their point-of-view changes as well, also the emotions shifts from the novel to the movie.

reviews.review_title: Don't know what to say...awesome movie
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's nest was unbelievable. Well it was very believable because of the good acting, but you know what I mean. With stars early in their career most importantly Jack Nicholson, and others like Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd etc. This film's plot was very well written and very interesting. I couldn't take my eyes off the screen and hit on a soft topic and portrayed the realities of what mental hospitals were like, more of a prison than a hospital.The movie was well paced. It didn't rush through important scenes but didn't drag and give too much detail. The editing was tight and well done. Besides for the editing, the script was well written. Each and every line was needed and perfect for each character. The sternness of nurse Ratched, the smart remarks of Nicholson, and the silent Will Sampson. The mise-en-scene, supposed to be a hospital, depicted the harsh realities of the hospital with the prison bars and very controlled environment.If you want to see a spectacular movie with Jack Nicholson in his early prime then this is the movie to watch. It has supreme acting, a hard heart-wrenching plot to swallow, and a tightly edited movie that does not rest for a minute and keeps you thoroughly entertained.

reviews.review_title: Best film ever made about disabled people and institutions.
reviews.content: While Jack Nicholson, Brad Dourif, and Louise Fletcher take top honors for their portrayals in this film, as they should, the whole point of the film as an expression of outrage against how people are marginalized in our culture, was made by Christopher Lloyd's character.  Mr. Taber (Lloyd) drops a cigarette in his pants cuff unknowingly, and it sets the pants on fire. When he reacts to the burning and danger by jumping around and yelling, he is dragged off and tied down.  People who are handicapped or mentally ill cannot express anger or fear or desire or even pain, without it being seen as a threat.  The real handicaps here are the "normal" people in the "helping professions."  Best movie of all time.

A movie of a bygone era. Probably oldies of that period who are still alive may enjoy this. Very depressing and meaningless script. Drama artists have got a good scope to show all their theatrics in this type of movies. That may be the reason this won Oscars in first place. Utterly hopeless.

This is one of those movies that I remember the moment after the credits rolled....even though it was about 35 years ago. This film took me thorough the whole range of emotions - humour, sadness, anger, pity and more. Every actor in this movie is incredible, with JN giving us a tour de force of a performance. To watch this film and not be moved - you would have to be dead inside.So please, do yourself a massive favour, and go watch this movie. It will be in your head for days afterwards, I promise. It hasn't dated at all, it could of been made yesterday - except now they would never make a film like this, unless it was some small indie production. But that's another story.Go see.....now!!!

I usually do not comment on movies. This excellent piece of work shows how insanity is actually a society and not a medical problem. Society decides who is insane and makes sure the individual feels insane and guilty! Especially the less "romantic" approach and character development give this movie a very real feel. It does not mask what putting away the "looneys" really is - a willful act of society to warrant conformity of the masses.Many philosphers deal with the role of insanity in society but this movie lets you grasp the problem with your senses not just with your intellect. It shows without veil what living in an asylum means even if the conditions of holding the "inmates" improved.This movie is a definitive MUST SEE!

reviews.review_title: Greatest american film to date (possible spoilers)
reviews.content: Wonderfully acted,great story, and by the way anybody who says this film does the book injustice,is missing the point. There are so many memorable scenes in this picture. But these were the best EXAMPLES: when mac teaches martini to play blackjack,when mac gives his interview to the warden, and when mac tries to teach the chief to play basketball. Jack clearly shows why he's the greatest actor who ever lived. If not the best, certainly the most charismatic. The ending is both tragic and powerful. I do think the direction was lousy, but who cares? One of the few, almost perfect films.

The fashion, most of the music, the TV and the politics of the 70s may have been a little sucky, but the movies were on key throughout the decade. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is one of the main highlights, a brilliant adaptation of Ken Kesey's brilliant book. Nicholson is as magnetic as ever, while Louise Fletcher earned her place amongst the recent American Film Institute list of villains. The script is deceptively light most of the way, but it takes a sudden dark turn towards the end, giving us one of the most beautiful endings ever. All round, this is a towering movie.

"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" (1975), based on the novel by Ken Kesey and directed by Milos Forman earns a 8 out of 10 star rating by me, one reason being how closely the movie relates to the novel. If were to not have read the novel before watching the movie, I would have gave this movie a 10 out of 10 star rating. I feel that the movie left out important scenes that were made very important in the novel. Another reason why I would give this movie a 8 out of 10 star rating is how the characters compare in the novel and the movie. Each character seemed to be different in the movie than they were in the novel. Although I am giving thi movie a 8 out of 10 star rating, I would recommend watching this movie, preferably without reading the novel prior to the movie.

reviews.review_title: Holy Hell I love this film.
reviews.content: I could go into great detail about what every shot means; eg. The film opens on a wide shot of a beautiful landscape, a car in the distance, we watch as the car makes it's way towards us and it offers a moment to reflect on the freedom of what we are seeing, for we will soon be incarcerated with mental's all around...But I'll just stick to the main thing that moves me about this film. For me this film is all about a word, a word which I've never understood, I've asked many people throughout my life to explain themselves when using this word, that's a lot because people throw it around sometimes like it means something, but no one has ever been able to even try and explain what in the giant hole in the ground it means. The word is 'normal', we've all had our normality questioned at some point, whether it's talking, walking, eating, sleeping, jumping or uni-cycling across the Grand Canyon. This leads people, some more than others, to question if they are 'normal', some people don't realise straight away that 'normal' is a bullshit word made up by bullshitters to bullshit the bullshitable.The film covers Randell P. McMurphy (Mac) , a smart ars con who get's himself put in a mental asylum thinking it will be easier to serve time there than in prison. He meets a group of characters who are so different yet most of them are the same, they are all terrified of the world. Insert an extreme extrovert in with a bunch of extreme introverts and you know it's going to be fun. All the characters are brilliant and fascinating and I could right separate reviews for them all, but let's stick to the film. The film only leaves the confines of the asylum a few times but for the most part it is in one area, the ward, so it's dialogue that drives this film and each scene is a revelation into the mind of the other characters, right from the get go we have a firm idea of what Mac is all about, as he is uncuffed and transferred from police custody he jumps in the air whooping and plants a smacker on the unamused officers cheek. Right from this point I thought "Yep, I like this guy". We are introduced to our first crazy, Chief, Mac attempts conversation but is told by Billy, a young boy with a stutter he is a deaf and dumb Indian. The rest of the characters we get to know through 'therapy sessions' conducted by the films 'bad guy', Nurse Ratchet, if the name Ratchet doesn't give you a clue, she is the controlling and oppressive Head Nurse who seems to take quiet but extreme pleasure in driving this group of men under her heel, in this film both she and Mac meet their match in each other. The first act is Mac trying to annoy Nurse Ratchet, objecting to music and trying to change schedule in order to watch baseball, he meets resistance not only directly form Nurse Ratchet, but the men he finds himself trapped with, having been fed drugs and calmly beaten into submission they are unable (at first) to smell the freedom offered by Mac. The turning point in the film comes when one of the guards reveals when taunted by Mac, that unlike prison, he will not be released until the powers that be (whom include Ratchet) decide he is sane. This presents a problem considering the fact he has made people think he is insane in order to be committed. This leads us to the most powerful point of the film (for me). Mac confronts the other patients for not telling him this was the case. It is then reveled that most of the patients are in the hospital voluntarily and can leave whenever they want.This for me is the heart of the film, most of these characters have deemed themselves insane and are hiding themselves from the world. Now while crazy people do indeed exist, these guys merely think they are because of societies selfish and mean nature. Instead of embracing bad experiences in their lives, learning, dusting themselves off and moving on they took it as a sign they weren't fit to live as everyone else does. Billy is the prime example of this, a stutter will make anyone self conscious and he tells stories of a love life which stutters like his speech, he is not insane, unless you count wearing your heart on your sleeve a reason to break out the butterfly nets, but from my experience a great many people will tell you that is a wonderful characteristic. So he commits himself thinking it's for the best and Nurse Ratchet, instead of helping him, indulges this belief for her own bloated ego and allowing him to deny himself all life has to offer out of fear.We all know the end shot of this film, even if it's through the Simpsons references it's got over the years of Chief breaking through the window and running to freedom. Chief is the biggest introvert (literally and figuratively) that has ever been, choosing not to speak, cutting himself off from the world and just not taking part. (Aside from brushing the floor) But in meeting Mac, he sees the error of his ways and offers hope for us all by finding the strength to break free from societies conventions and labels and small mindedness. That's why I love this film, it remind me of the word 'normal' and the fact this an insane world, and I'm proud to be a part of it.

reviews.review_title: I wouldn't call say it's my favorite film in the genre, but I would say it's a film fit to be a classic
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest has a wonderful message, an amazing villain, and one of the most trouble-making protagonists in the most root-worthy of senses I have ever seen in moviedom. R.P. McMurphey is put in a mental hospital, where he must rebel against the evil establishment. A classic story of will versus the meanies. Essentially a tragicomedy, we get a film that works in both exposition and exploration of the mental hospital concept as it relates to the free-spirited protagonist, newly inserted as a patient, as well as the other patients, who are men, bought down by the wo"man". This is the stuff classics are made out of, though I do not think it's the definitive piece in the asylum genre. The film really doesn't operate on the same level that a lot of other piefces in that genre, do, focusing more on on stuff more about the soul than the "psyche". I think that's what lends the film it's whole flavor, but if you be looking in the genre, this is satisfying in a different (more life-affirming way). I wouldn't call it a personal favorite, but I would call it superb work.It's also anti-psychiatry, like myself, and I gotta give it that. Comparing other mental hospital films to this is unfair, however. Besides the setting, I cannot recall a single mental hospital film out there with the guts to be like this film. This film totally is a different animal from something like say "Girl, Interrupted" or "The Snake Pit" or many other films which have bits like that. The film is about the affirmation of the human spirit against a seething institution. I'd say that this movie has more in common with prison movies.

reviews.review_title: IS IT TIME TO RE-READ THE TALE OF THE 'NAKED KING', LADIES AND GENTLEMEN?
reviews.content: I think this movie is great, I think it deservedly got the Big Five Oscars, and in general for me it is one of my favorites. But after reading the work of Ken Kesey, I willy-nilly had to take a more objective look at the work of Milos Forman, as a film adaptation of the novel ...

I would have enjoyed this had I not read it beforehand.The events in the movie are completely changed around to the point where both plots are almost completely incoherent.The central themes are almost wasted, and it seems like the movie is just simply another (Star Wars-esque)fight of good vs evil.Poor Kesey!

reviews.review_title: Timeless movie, even our grown daughter likes it.
reviews.content: My new husband and I saw this movie when we were first married and we both discuss and remember it 30 years later. The characters are real, like the neighbors next door instead of unbelievable. Of course Jack Nicholson was and is still a great actor who after all these years pulls in the crowds. For a short while, I truly believed he would be typecast into "crazy' roles from that point on. His mix of crazy and humor is the true mark of an Oscar winning performer. His dreams to crash the place and escape were well acted out and believable. Having seen this movie on the drive-in screen almost 30 years ago, I would still pay to see it again.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: The first few times I watched the film I didn't like it. Then I had to read the book in high school and didn't because it was almost like the movie. But Jack Nicholson is great he adds the normal and realistic believable quality not just to this film but to many of his other films as well. The story line and the acting is portrayed very well and it's all smooth and all the characters fit together. It's a great story to show that some people in institutions may not be crazy and it just takes one person to show them all that.Louise Fletcher as Nurse Ratched was perfect and acted so well and showed that she wanted to be the one in control and as McMurphy tested her authority she began to become unnerved by the patients.

I always wanted to see this movie because of the good references I had, also because it has as winners the best actress and actor in the same movie. It's worth seeing. The performance of all the characters is very good. You will hate the nurse!

reviews.review_title: one of best Jack Nicholson film
reviews.content: This movie remains possibly THE finest psychological drama I have ever seen, mixed with both outrage and subtle comedy. You can look at Jack Nicholson's face and know exactly what he is thinking. He has zero unconscious bias against anyone and just wants everyone to find a way to enjoy life. Not to mention how amazing that it debuted supporting actors such as Christopher Lloyd and Danny deVito. This movie also made Nurse Ratched (sounds vaguely like wretched, or more like ratchet, a tool that clamps down but doesn't let go!) an icon for cruel treatment. Interesting that this movie was released just five years after Reagan signed the Lanterman-Petris-Short Act to end long term involuntary incarceration of mental patients.They just don't make movies like this anymore.

reviews.review_title: It's a love it or loaf it film.
reviews.content: How surprised I was to witness that the vast majority of the book's important details and themes in "One Flew Over The Cuckoos Nest" was not taken into consideration. For example, Nurse Ratched (acted by the lovely Louise Fletcher) was almost the complete opposite (in the looks department) compared to the one from the novel. I had the head Nurse pictured as a grotesque and oversized female who would easily be mistaken for a man. Despite this minor flaw, the entire cast (most notably Jack Nicolson and Louise Fletcher) were very well acted. Nicolson's portrayal of a lively slob, McMurphy, is very convincing and who could not forget the calm and collected portrayal of Nurse Ratched Louise Fletcher so cleverly put together. Other notable superbly acted characters to take note of are Chief Bromden, Cheswick, Harding and Martini...all of whom were exquisitely acted.The film takes place in the urban area of North America, far, far away from any other source of civilisation. I must admit that I was very impressed with the cinematography, scenery and settings used for the film...it had me fooled that the film was only made three years ago (let alone almost 26 years ago)! In the middle of nowhere lies a large institution populated by ward keepers, nurses, doctors and of course, the mentally ill patients. It becomes obvious that any source of life (as in excitement) in the ward has never occurred...until McMurphy stepped in. The only non-mentally-ill patient of the ward (which is the most obvious thing in the film), McMurphy brings back the much needed sparkle into the ward...as well as challenging the iron-gripping power Nurse Ratched holds so forcefully towards the ward.Sentimental...certainly. Funny...definately. Exciting...not really (not that it's important anyway). Watch the film, it's far from disappointing...certainly!

reviews.review_title: The acting is excellent, but the writing doesn't live up to the book.
reviews.content: Well, as has probably been mentioned a thousand times, Jack Nicholson is brilliant in this film.  His character is so well built that you forget it's Jack and Randall P McMurphy become real to you.  The supporting cast is excellent as well.  Nurse Ratched is portrayed perfectly as a manipulative control freak.Of course, the acting is where the greatness ends.  The direction is decent, but nothing special, and the writing is just terrible.  After reading, and loving the book, I just couldn't like this movie.  Ken Kesey's novel is nothing short of superb, and the plot of the film adheres to the plot so poorly that it loses so many of the things that were great about the book.All in all, the movie falls far short of the book.Acting: 9.5/10 Overall: 5/10

I had seen One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in the top 250 on this site, and I looked at the plot, stars and year and I thought it would just be one of the many old, long and boring films.One day I managed to pick it up cheap, as I wanted to watch it just out of curiosity, to see what it was actually like.It turned out to be one of my all-time films. Before I watched it, I was actually rather unfamiliar with Jack Nicholson (the main star) and he actually turned out to be quite a good actor.I like the film so much as it is funny, well made, simple and contains good actors and plot. I can now see why it has a position in the top 250, as it deserves it! worth the watch - 10/10

reviews.review_title: The Greatest Motion Picture of All Time
reviews.content: This movie was the most touching movie I have ever seen. Nicholson's character was so free and spirited that you couldn't help having a feeling that you were the one in the movie following his lead. The supporting cast, especially Brad Dourif, all should receive a huge pat on the back for making a masterpiece out of this film. Dourif makes you laugh and cry as the young, stuttering and suicidal Billy Bibbit. Danny Devito and Christopher Lloyd have good supporting roles too. Louise Fletcher is superb as the evil yet soft spoken Nurse Ratched. This movie definitely shoots for the stars and beyond with two well deserved thumbs up. I would recommend it to anyone who wants to feel every emotion that they have inside of them in the time span of 2 hours and 10 minutes.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over Cuckoo's Nest. Movie v Novel
reviews.content: The book "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" by Ken Kesey and the film produced by Milos Forman did both an excellent job in performance but the film lacked very important detail that the book had. The film lacked character development and also the point of view of Chief Bromden was lost. I have decided to analyze both the film techniques. The film ineffectively captured the characters development in the play. For example, Chief is a mysterious character that all the patients have led up to believed was deaf and dumb. Although his placement in the film did not suit the placement he had in the book much of it was ineffective. Information such as his childhood past was vital piece of information for the concept of the story. It was never talked about or sparked at in the film. Chief's problems on why he is in the ward are forgotten in the film. Another example would be McMurphy; he was looked as a very rude and crazy man in the film. The book however did capture his craziness and wild side towards Nurse Ratched but that is not the all-around persona he had in the book. McMurphy character in the movie leads you to believe that he might be crazy because you don't see as much development he's still the same guy that stepped first foot in the ward. The film ineffectively captured the point of view. The point of view difference between the book and film is that the film has made it third person rather than the original first person. The book displays a first person point of view in the eyes of Chief Bromden. The film however grasps the book in a third person point of view. This is understandable because it would be rather hard to have a narrator who is supposedly deaf and dumb be our main focus point. It is a disappointment to know that Chief's story did not get touch upon in the film but the film did a good job in cooperating different perspectives in the movie. The movie and film are both excellent creation and both have their downsides but the reader should read the book because it provides very good detail and more descriptions in its final copy.

I remember when I first watched this movie as a kid, at my friend's house, how much it revealed to me about mental health facilities and the inhuman treatments and abuse many patients used to face.Now, rewatching it I am able to grasp some of the more subtle points that I may have missed as a child, such as chaos versus order, and inside (inside the hospital) versus outside (outside the hospital). These themes are shown throughout the film, specifically pertaining to showing chaos vs. order. One specific scene pits the chaos within the facility against the order of the facility, the nurses, using classical music to create order among the chaos. Of course, as it happens, the classical music fails to create order, instead it plays loudly over top the chaos adding to it.

"Milos Forman's" directorial masterpiece, also known for "Man on the Moon" & arguably his best motion picture "Amadeus". "Jack Nicholson" was a fantastic choice for this role, keeping me captivated from the moment he appeared on screen. The movie also includes, "Christopher Lloyd", "Danny DeVito" and "Brad Dourif". The film portrays the disturbing truth concerning how patients were treated in mental institutions back in the day, telling the tale of an inmate who desperately wants to break out and be free from the nonsensical practices with in grounds. The mental institution is presented as a prison opposed to a facility for the mentally unwell. "Milos Forman" did a realistic job of making that contrast powerful and important to the viewer. I was compelled from the opening frame, never taking my eyes off it. This film is a moving, cinematic experience, one of which I wouldn't miss out on. Every actor gives a stellar performance, the characters written to perfection, every section of dialogue and every shot is absolutely perfect. Great pacing and many unforgettable moments. 100% watch!

reviews.review_title: Brutal and sweet, in a way
reviews.content: A peculiar (and very realistic) view of how an individual can influence and change the environment around him in a certain way.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: No matter now or in the future, the madhouse and the head nurse disguised in various shapes lurk around us, flying over the madhouse is always meaningful.
Never see like this type film before. It is definitely one of my favourite movie. Because it different not like every movie. Mostly about acting and screenplay. We never expected climax .

reviews.review_title: Should be in any film lovers top 5
reviews.content: What can I say?  Its a true classic and with the Godfather, the best film of the 70's.  I can't believe it took me this long to finally see this film (just finished watching the film today)!The films true strengths lie in its exemplary cast, who are at turns, hilarious, tragic, and downright poignant in their actions.  This coupled with the film's powerful message makes it a film that easily surpasses something like the ovverated Shawshank Redemption (of course its different- but they share similar themes- freedom, institutionalisation, the corruptness of the seemingly unaccountable institutions).I really can't reccommend this film enough.  I'm just ashamed to say that it took me so long to see it...
A group of people's carnival, a person's madhouse.

This is in my top 3 movies of all time. Everything about this story is great. The acting is phenomenal, and the story of perseverance and repression is beautiful. The way the film is directed is unique, and creates a bleak ambiance. Bo Goldman wrote a phenomenal script, even if Bromden isn't narrator. The fishing scene was always my fathers favorite, because as they break farther away from the institution the more they begin to grow and heal. Nurse Ratched is the restrainer, bridling nurse, Mac's opposite. The ending scene is the culmination of McMurphy himself, and is one of the best scenes of all time. The movie is wonderful. A Must see.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: The film "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" was hilarious and I really enjoyed watching this movie. I heard of this movie but I never got the chance to actually watch it. Jack Nicholson was awesome as he normally is. I think his character made the movie to what it is. He lightens up the film and gives it a little flavor. I also feel that he helped out the rest of the people that were in there to and brought their self-esteem up. This movie showed what a mental institute is about and it shows you the real thing but with Jack Nicholson it makes it interesting to what. All the characters played their roles so well and you actually believed that they weren't actors, and that they were real. I would love to watch this movie again on my own leisure time. I defiantly recommend it to others!

Jack Nicholson never fails at portraying a great crazy person. From this film to his many others his characters are always out there. I loved he his character made you question the facility and what really is crazy. Anyone could go crazy listening to that music and repeating the same old thing day to day. He brought something new and alive to these people. He helped the patients see things in a clearer sense, building tension with the staff. It was great to see the characters show who they really were as human beings not the mentally insane. Nicholsons character brought them closer together and showed them the beauty in life. It was funny but also had its heart felt moments. He gives these men a new passion for life. The ending was great. It showed how much he had changed that one persons life and what he had taught them. Do not be afraid of life and living. Great Movie!

This is one of the very rare time-less movies; even though it has been released 6 years before my birthday, it is much more actual in content than many other movies of our time. Despite the fact that Nicholson latest films (except As good as it gets) aren't very brilliant, this one is the ABSOLUTE BEST MOVIE OF ALL TIMES. The cast is simply amazing, Lloyd, Sampson, DeVito and the touching character of Billy ....... and being honest, who didn't want Nicholson to get rid of that nurse at the end ? The finals scene showed the greatness of the movie once again, powerful and drammatic !I absolutely loved it and it's a shame that almost noone of my generation knows it

"One flew over the cuckoo's nest" depict expertly what happens when chaos meets order. The great clash between nurse Ratched (Louis fletcher) and Randall Mcmurphy (Jack Nicholson) shows us that when law and order get confronted, it can become cruel and strict in order for it to preserve perceived order.The movie also depicts different mental illnesses in a rough but very real way and shows us that life on the inside can be just as tough as life on the outside, when it comes to living in a treatment facility. Most of the occupants does in fact choose to live within the doors of the mental hospital, rather than live outside in the free world.The way in which director Milos Foreman envisions the world of crazy, is depicted especially beautiful during the fishing trip. I also enjoyed the way in which classical music is used during "medication time" which I viewed in a metaphorical in order for the patients to return to normalcy".Overall, I really enjoyed the movie, and I appreciate learning more about what it is like to live with mental illness. The movie takes a realistic standpoint and reflect societal norms well, and the camera/sound/cinematography is well choreographed.My rating: 82/100.

This movie is just incredible.  It leaves me motionless from beginning to end, and I can't say that about most films.  Totally encompassing as the drama of the situation plays out in front of you.  Forman's best work as a director, and equalled by the script and cast.

reviews.review_title: Im ready to die for this film.it is my life.
reviews.content: go watch this. i have seen it more than 40 times. it contains life. u will cry n at the same time u will be happy. its the special quality of this classic. do not waste time reading reviews just go and see it u wont regret. it is multi layered. each scene can be understood differently. its the best movie ever made. the ending will make you speechless.no one can say that this film is over rated.according to me it is under rated.i do not want to go in to the details of this movie because if i start it will contain so many words you will stop reading this comment.it won five academy awards.it is timeless.direction is flawless.i became a fan of jack after this movie.

This is a fine movie. I enjoyed watching it. The cast is very good and it's filmed nicely, don't get me wrong. However, it is IDENTICAL to the book. There is no variation. There is so little actual "adaption" in it it actually began to annoy me slightly. If you've read the book you will find no surprises whatsoever. So why not just read the book? There are no clever cinematic tricks or interpretations (which can be so interesting and work so well when adapting a book to screen.)If you want to see a clever and interesting adaptation of a cult 1960's book see David Cronenberg's "Naked Lunch". If you want it straight off the page and onto the screen, see this.
It's a small space where you don't believe in tears. The Times can not tell the sad, it is abandoned by the gods of the zone. If even freedom is taken away, if even sorrow is taken away.
Whether now or in the future, madhouses and matrons lurk around us in various shapes, flying over madhouses will always make sense.

What's different is that the film tells the story of a normal person in a mental hospital and a group of mental patients who try their best to escape from the insane asylum. This is the brilliance of the film. From the perspective of normal people, they look at and even integrate into the world of mental patients, which brings great appreciation and dramatic conflict to the film.
It was one of the worst movies I've ever seen 😑😑

A fascinating study on mental illness above all else, "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" offers a disturbingly piercing and complex glimpse into one's mind and of what exactly constitutes a psychological disease. Everyone knows about Nicholson's charismatic turn as McMurphy, the supposedly sanest person in the asylum but there's so much more here if one digs beneath the surface and straight into the secondary characters. Where Brad Dourif excels as the impossibly sensitive and introverted youth unable to take a stand on anything. Besides him we get all sorts of disturbed conditions ranging from people who frequent the asylum as refuge from their lives to others who are utterly unable to deal with the world in the most basic of ways. So while taking this as the saga of one man while he struggles to remain sane is affecting enough, couple it with the myriad shades of humanity that surround and interact with him and the end result is a thoroughly envolving experience.

Based on the novel Ken Kesey, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest centers around a criminal named McMurphy who, in an attempt to escape spending more time at prison, pleads insanity for his crimes and is therefore sentenced to time in a mental institution.
First off, the plot is extraordinary. Personally speaking, I hadn't seen this kind of movie to offer the same joy and meaning through its phenomenal storyline before. Here the story should not be valued only at face value. Though the story is portraying a crazy guy rebelling against some crazier nurses, getting deeper into the plot, it somehow offers a model of our society. There are symbols everywhere; for example, McMurphy is kind of a guy who enters a group of people and changes their perspective about their surrounding. Or the nurse behaves on behalf of cold leaders or simply bosses as their thorough concentration is sticking to some stupid schedule while taking others emotional needs for granted. McMurphy depicts a personality who is ready to sacrifice himself for his beloved ones, and his great goal it is to make them wake up from the lies they are living in. That being said, no need to mention that Chief is symbolized as the majority of people in a society who, in spite of the strength they have, stay quiet and pretend to be deaf and idiot. Unbelievably beautiful it is to see how McMurhpy is trying his best to make this fooled people happy, both mentally and physically.
Without any doubt, the cast is perfection, especially Jack Nicholson, whose phenomenal performance pushes the envelope. However, I'm of the opinion that it wasn't his best performance ever as his job in Shining was mind-blowing. And about his character, McMurphy, the insanity portrayed in his character is mild enough not to be necessary for him to be in that place, nevertheless that's not a justification to consider him completely healthy and I think it was one of the points, that alongside the well executed performance of Nicholson, divides opinions. Plus, the other cast team performed a really good job as well. To be honest, once I though they had indeed hired some patients as the performance they offered were extremely realistic.
The highlight of this movie was its appalling tragedy. Let's face the fact; we all somehow expected something sad to happen to our protagonist. The wild and aggressive looks of the nurse Ratched and the warren were all whispering about getting closer to their last resort. However, having been a terrible tragedy, then there are people inspired by characteristics of our hero and ready to set themselves free from the cage the institution has made for them.
It's never enough talking about this masterpiece and all the words have already been said before. To simply put, an incredible picture certainly it is and hardly you can find one single error. A must see for everyone.

This movie really did leave an impact on me, but the kind I did not expect.I was going into this movie not knowing much about it; all I knew is that this is a must-watch title, featuring amazing actors and a good production. But I have watched it now and I most certainly agree that it's very deserving of the praise that it gets.The movie surely made me think about the biggest ideal of mankind - freedom. How the movie portrays McMurphy's view of freedom, how he changes opinions of other patients, and leads them to freedom. It asks us the same question as the characters, like doctors and nurses, in the movie are asked - Is McMurphy really crazy?So...Is he crazy? All he wants is freedom: freedom to watch sports whenever he wants and to have relationships, to walk freely, maybe go fishing. Can we blame someone for wanting to live according to his own desires? We empathize with McMurphy, maybe because we can all understand that desire to live freely. And also we grow to hate the person who takes it away from him along with the character,and that is probably nurse Ratched. Yes, she isn't fully responsible for all the things that happened to McMurphy, but she is a visible obstacle for him, keeping him away from what he wants. She plays with McMurphy and drives him to insanity, all so he can't ever get what he wants.The true desire, him being so sure of himself and being confident, gave other patients hope, but it affected the Chief most. We can see that in the ending, which was absolutely beautiful. I can't lie, it teared me up.Also I want to mention that the music was AMAZING, Jack Nitzsche really portrayed the feel and the energy of the movie very well, with beautiful sounds of the cuckoo. I want to say this is a big contribution to film music, especially in the 20th century.Amazing movie, a must-see film, 9/10

As an excellent Hollywood film, this film has achieved a high degree of integration of commercial elements and artistic value. The film tells the story of an insane asylum. Films that are successful at the box office have to find an opposite for their protagonists. It is precisely this special point in the original work that the film director forman emphasizes in the film, and builds the overall framework of the film on a kind of confrontation, which makes the film more like a confrontation in the form of performance. The two sides of the battle stand out, one is the manager represented by the head nurse, the other is the manager represented by McMurphy. In this kind of confrontation, though the patients are weak as a weak group, they show the most exuberant vitality in the film.

reviews.review_title: This movie was well acted and well made
reviews.content: "One flew over the Cuckoo's nest" is one of Jack Nicholson finest movies ever.  The acting was perfect by everyone and the plot was pretty cool too. it was also kind of cool to see all of the actors so young like Christopher Lloyd as Taber(Back to the future), Brad Dourif as Billy Bibbit(Childs play,Voice of chucky and actual person in the beginning)and Danny Devito as martini.  This Movie was great and i suggest to every to go and see it.  The acting was perfect and they have some cool scenes.  My favorite was the boat scene.  I give This Movie 8.6 out of 10 stars

reviews.review_title: THE best film of all time.
reviews.content: It has to mean something when a film ranks #8 in the IMDb Top 250, wins the five most prestigious Academy awards and is still considered underrated. Upon first watching the film, I was sceptical and half expectant of it being mildly overrated. The film is as close to flawless as any other film I have yet watched, and that includes some IMDb favourites, such as fellow masterclasses Shawshank Redemption and the first two Godfather movies. The screenplay and directing of the film is sensational. I have not yet read the book, or seen a play adaptation, but it is something I would very much want to do. The scripting is quickly-paced, but this never becomes it's downfall and simply adds to the sheer insanity of the film itself. Though, the velocity of the film itself does halt when need be - thus, making the more tragic, dramatic scenes even more touching and heartbreaking. The directing, from the excellent Milos Forman, is also something to shout about very much. An Oscar well deserved! Though, the film's stand-out of many strong points is the acting. Within a large and extensive cast, there is not a single bad actor and a handful of outstanding ones. Jack Nicholson, playing the hot-tempered convict Mc Murphy, and his usual psycho routine are as convincing as ever. As is, Louise Fletcher in her role of Nurse Ratched, without a doubt one of the greatest film villains of all time. She's callous, unpredictable and a role not many actresses would be able to succeed in doing so to any positive effect. Of course, the supporting cast, (and the "nuts" as Mc Murphy playfully dubs them) are outstanding. It's brilliant to see pre-stardom talents, such as Christopher Lloyd, Danny DeVito and the undermined Brad Dourif really go into there roles. Some lesser known actors, such as Sydney Lassick as the child-esque Cheswick, William Redfield as the opinionated Harding and the mesmerising performance of Will Sampson as the unforgettable Chief. All the latter three actors, sadly, passed away within years of the film's release.In short, an unbelievably great film - if you were to watch any, make it this one!

This Primo piece of cinematography is the hope I've been waiting for. Ken Kesey's amazing story could not have been adapted in a better way. This is one of the very few instances where the book is not as good as the movie, everything down to the ending to detail and characters. This movie is very well done in multiple departments and This might be my favorite movie of all time.

I can only think of one movie adaptation of a great novel that was worse than this film, and that is "The Color Purple". They both suffer from similar problems. Both novels focus on the internal experiences and perceptions of the main characters, and rather than doing something creative, the film-makers simply tell the story and leave out the point of view. In the novel the entire story is told from the point of view of one of the patients. Sometimes he is drugged, sometimes he is in a fog and sometimes he's thinking clearly. To the reader it is as if you are experiencing being incarcerated in the asylum. All of this is lost in the movie. I really recommend reading the book and forgetting about the movie. Or at least read the book FIRST, you'll thank me later.
...although a difficult task, if I had to pick one film as the top of my list,this would be it.....when it came out, I watched it nearly twenty times in theaters...the best

reviews.review_title: This movie is the greatest ever!
reviews.content: This movie is the best ever made. It has comedy, suspense, drama and murder. A awesome dialogue without too much swearing. Also the best cast you can ask for. Nicholson is the best actor to date! All in all the movie is the best!!

reviews.review_title: One of the best Jack Nicholas movie ever
reviews.content: I've watch this movie like three times and it's such a good movie I'm a big fan of Jack Nicholas he a really good actor . A lot of his movies are really good and some are ok but really good though . This movie is really good the writing and the plot is so good . Everything in the movie is good so if you haven't seen this movie you should watch this it's such a good movie.

This American Drama is definitely another history maker. It takes an unbelievable topic and turns it into a gripping story. A criminal who is sentenced to time in jail convinces everyone that he is indeed insane and therefore sent to a mental institution. He thinks it will be all comfy and cozy but he sure is in for a "surprise. What's not interesting about that?! It causes the audience to love it even when it's wrong. It is outrageous but it works, mostly because of Jack Nicholson's wit. Nicholson's part really makes the movie, and although I haven't seen an overload of his movies, I think this is the best part he has played. The movie ends with a "downer" but it works and life goes on.

reviews.review_title: One flew east, one flew west....
reviews.content: "One flew over the Cuckoo's nest" is, with no doubt, one of the best movies out there. It is the peak of the New Hollywood era, with The Godfather as it's only equal. At least, thats my humble opinion.The story is about Randall Patrick McMurphy, played by Jack Nicholson in one of the best performances of all time. He is a smalltime criminal who is sent to a mental institution. While there he soon turns the place upside down. You see, McMurphy is a free spirit and soon becomes a bitter rival of Nurse Ratched, played by Louise Fletcher. The big nurse is nothing short of a tyrant corrupted by power. She rules her patients with an iron hand, that is until Randall enters the place.Both Fletcher and Nicholson got awarded for their roles but in my opinion all the actors are magnificent, even if those two are the ones who shine the brightest.But this movie is not only great because of it's actors. It is a great story worthy of being told about human rights, the importance of freedom and how power corrupts. But that is only the way I see it, you may have a different view. Any way, there is no reason for you not to see this movie. It is a great cinematic tale. And the fact that it has one of the greatest endings scenes of all time doesn't hurt either."But at least I tried, God dammit. At least I did that" - McMurphy

I've seen One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest more times than I can remember and each time I view it again I'm struck by the parallels between it and the 60's hit Cool Hand Luke.  Jack Nicholson's McMurphy is very similar to Paul Newman's Luke in that they are both in a place where they don't really belong.  McMurphy wasn't really crazy and Luke was really only guilty of destructive mischief.  They also become the life of their new homes showing their new friends and fellow inmates that they are only broken if they choose to be broken by their jailers.  And they both suffer the same fate....In watching One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest its hard to imagine a film more deserving of the Oscars it received.  I must disagree strongly with a previous comment by Brandon (horrormvfn@aol.com) who referred to Louise Fletcher's Nurse Ratched as "soft but strong willed."  I consider her to be more of a psychopath than anyone in the movie.  She has her ward running in a way that suits her and she isn't going to allow anyone to disrupt it. Just as McMurphy sets out in the beginning to get under her skin she resolves to destroy him to show who is really in control.  If Nurse Ratched were a real nurse she would be guilty of malpractice for the things she does in this movie.The ensemble cast of OFOTCN is a real treat to behold.  If you haven't seen this one and choose not to you can't consider yourself a real movie fan.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: With a strong class view, this film satirizes the negative phenomena in the real society through allegorical and cautionary symbols. This film is the representative of American social and political films in the 1970s. Director milos forman excelled not only in his portrayal of the romance of the original, but also in his delivery of a rebellious theme in classic Hollywood language. Although the film adopts the subject matter of mental patients, which is often involved in Hollywood movies, it has deep moral meaning and sharp irony, rich in teasing color, and the narrative level is perfectly combined with the metaphorical level.
A masterful work of art. Jack Nicolson gave his career best performance. Really felt the vibe. Jump up and put it in the basket chief.

All of us are probably rebellious at heart, and only like to see someone who can break the rules. But the heart of most people is timid, so in the face of the power always cowering do not dare to resist. McMurphy is definitely the special one. He has a free soul. In spite of his violent tendencies, his laziness and his cunning, he had a burning heart, otherwise he would not have twice delayed his escape from the gateway, leading to his tragic end. Fortunately, his sacrifice was not futile. It was he who awakened the chief, and it was because the chief understood him that he did not spend the rest of his life in an insane asylum without any dignity after having his frontal lobe cut off.

reviews.review_title: How can a movie be so complete?
reviews.content: For a long time I was so eager to see this movie, and one evening I couldn't wait anymore. Me and a good friend went in to the city and rented "One flew over the cuckoo's nest".After watching the two hours and 9 minutes long movie, I was really so impressed, that I couldn't wait to see it again, so some weeks later I bought it on DVD. After watching it a couple of times, it made me realize how spectacular it actually is. I don't think I've seen such a complete movie, it almost got everything a movie can content. I don't think there's a single thing that could have been different, for making this movie better. The set, the characters and the story is all so magnificent, so near perfect."One flew over the cuckoo's nest" is one of my top 3 favorite movies, just as Jack Nicholson and Milos Forman goes on my list to, for being some of the greatest men in entertaining ever. All the Oscar's this movie was given, they're symbols of how perfect this movie is. I will say, that this is probably on the top 5 movies of all time, so it gets my full credit.10/10

Assessment:
Why? Does this movie get so much hype? First of all, all the yelling, hootin', and hollering was ridiculous. I had to keep turning it down, it was so loud. Unnecessarily loud. Second of all, what was the storyline, the point? There wasn't one. No cohesiveness. Too random. Third of all, Rached had barely any screen time, and she wasn't over the top mean and all that. Like, at all. I was expecting scenes with her being a tyrant. I don't get it. She didn't do crap to them, except follow and carry out the simple rules. Fourth of all, the acting was pretty good, I'll give it that, but that's all I'll give it. The standards must've been pretty low back then. But, I've always heard throughout my 44 years of existence, how amazing this movie is and whatnot. Meh. At least i can say that I have seen it (take note, it's not, nor ever, I SEEN, don't forget the HAVE) and I can cross it off my list. Definitely giving this one thumbs down.

This film is such a really great heartfelt and feel-good film. I had some laughs a little here and there but jack Nicholson was so great in this film i loved him in this film i think the writing was great. So yeah this is a must watch film it's a classic i really recommended it.

reviews.review_title: Yes, I gave one of the greatest films of all-time a 7
reviews.content: Let's start off with the positives: truly remarkable performances by every cast member, tastefully morbid comedy, heart-warming scenes that depict the human need for freedom and earthly indulgence - I don't need to go into too much detail since those of you who have already seen the movie already know why it is considered to be a cinematic masterpiece, and those of you who haven't probably already have some idea of what the hype is all about.Since this movie was released in 1975, it wouldn't be fair for me to judge it solely from the point of view of a millennial, since I believe that the rating of a movie is significantly contingent upon the time in which it was released. As such I will refrain from making any references to what a more modern audience looks for in a movie.McMurphy to me wasn't the hero everyone seems to extol him to be. He did want the best for his peers, yes, but at what cost? He took them sailing, allowing an inexperienced fellow patient to take control of the boat, without regard for everyone else's safety. He was instrumental in several riots and licentious acts within the institution. He was defiant, intractable and just plain obnoxious. I understand that many great films do feature lead characters with villainous qualities and that's okay, but the desired reaction - by the director, of the audience, to the said leads - is usually one of hatred. The movie presents itself in such a way as if we're supposed to regard McMurphy, a criminal, as the hero - and Nurse Ratched as the villain.Every plot synopsis and summary of this movie labels Nurse Ratched as the villain. Am I missing something? Was it simply because she was an ironfisted authoritarian who donned like one facial expression the whole movie? In my opinion, the same traits that point to her being the villain made her the perfect disciplinarian to the deranged and belligerent. Her style is a reminder that reformation and restoration needs tough love. I don't think she deserved to get strangled the way she did, but that was one of the great scenes in this movie.Overall, it was an entertaining movie with much to learn from. It goes without saying that these are my two cents, and I have written this review in the hopes of encouraging more objective discussion of our movies.

S*p*o*i*l*e*r! This movie is a-m-a-z-i-n-g! It is compelling and amazingly powerful. Jack Nicholson does an amazing act playing Randle Patrick McMurphy(a.k.a R.P.McMurphy), who gets sent into a mental hospital after (i don't remember what he did). He brightens up the place for most of the patients, but for the 'evil' Nurse Ratchet he is making it hell. At the end Billy Biggins is found dead with blood dripping from his body. That's when McMurphy violently attacks and starts strangling Nurse Ratchet believing she was responsible for Billys tragic death. Later, you find Nurse Ratchet with a thing around her neck. And you find out that they've taken a piece out of McMurphys body and made him, to put it simple, mindless. So Chief suffocates him with a pillow, knowing now that he can't escape with him. After doing that he picks up the fountain thing, throws it out the window and runs away. An amazing finish!

reviews.review_title: One of the few movies I consider the best.
reviews.content: This movie is extremely realistic. It demonstrated that an honest individual who is funny, who defends himself, who enjoys life, who is always himself is often punished and destroyed by other people... It's only one the strongest impression about this great movie among others I have.
