This is neither comedy nor tragedy but is a tragicomedy which makes it even more realistic since our life is just that... Another strongest idea: good intentions in fact are horrible, they may lead to deadly consequences like we saw in this masterpiece...

reviews.review_title: Chief did 'that' to McMurphy because he thought McMurphy was ignoring him.
reviews.content: Chief killed the unresponsive McMurphy because he thought McMurphy was ignoring him.

From an actors perspective, this is a must-see film. The way Jack and Nurse Ratchett can seamlessly snap between crazy and bizarre is amazing and illusive on screen. The characters aren't static either, we see some normal people amongst a bunch of loony-bins which makes it not so predictable, despite the somewhat obvious name. I think in terms of script, there were some pure gold in terms of lines and words. I found myself taking notes and finding it nearly impossible not to go away laughing about some of the catch- phrases! I think that anyone hoping to act should watch this for this reason. If you are not an actor or performer, make sure you see it anyway. You will be purely entertained, so much so. There are many haunting laughs/looks/scares and it could give you an awful fright!

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is my favorite movie of all time.  I never really agree with the Best Picture Academy Award winner, (c'mon, Forrest Gump?) but this movie was well deserving.  You know the only thing better than this movie?The book.

reviews.review_title: An eerie, powerful, nourishing drama that is something to scream about.
reviews.content: The film begins as a comedy, when the plot is revealed and the bulk of the film is underway, it turns a bit darker.  The story begins to twist and spin in the most unexpected direction when finally all hell breaks loose and the audience is lost in a twirl of dramatic awe.When R.P. McMurphy fakes insanity to avoid prison, he screws around and has fun with the big joke.  But then the tables turn as reality is exposed to our little goof off and he resorts to wildness.This is not only the story of total irony (enrolling into an insane assylum healthy but then slowly turning mad, and more I could say that would spoil the movie) but of passion, tragedy and the will to live without a loved one to know your flaws.An excellent, emotional classic.  10/10.

I watched "One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest" many years ago but only just re-watched it today on DVD. I've now seen it twice today, once with standard soundtrack and again with the soundtrack consisting of commentary from the director and producers. Frankly I'm disgusted at myself for not seeing this movie more often - this is one of the best pictures of all time, in my opinion. Nicholson has never made a better picture (though I do think that he's made a good living playing McMurphy ever since) and Fletcher epitomises the kind of eveil that goes un-noticed because it's there 'for your own good'. The film is ultimately bleak, though, in its statement that spontenaity and personaity will be punished by destruction - either physical (like Bobby) or by forced conformance (like McMurphy).Forman surely has taken this from his experience behind the Iron Curtain.9/10 - not 10 because of its hopelessness.

reviews.review_title: one of the best movies, I ever saw
reviews.content: In 1976, February I fled Ceausescu's Romania for Israel. In a week time, one of my friends took me to see "One Flew Over the Cuckoo Nest". I was shocked, and till now, more than 20 years, I still think that, except "The Godfather Saga", it's the best movie ever made. May be you will be surprised, but my opinion, is that this is the best ANTI-COMMUNIST movie. Simply it shows, what crimes can be done in the name of "taking care of the well-being" of your subjects. Looking at Mrs.Fletcher as head nurse, I was thinking of Ceausescu. I am pretty sure that the director, which like, me left the "communist paradise", was thinking the same way all the way long.

I usually hesitate to review any movie based on a Book,musical or any other medium before knowing the source material. However I can say that despite not reading the book, One Flew Over The Cuckoos nest is an excellent film that is sure to entertain any fan of movies. The plot follows Mick Murphy, a convict who on his last couple weeks of his sentence pretends to be insane so he's moved to a mental institution as he figures it'll be more comfortable. Well after several instances of disobeying the cold Nurse Ratchet,he learns he's committed to the institute and Nurse Ratchet isn't going to let him go. That's the main jest of it but a lot of time is spent getting to know the other mental patients and and their interactions with Mick Murphy, the most interesting one being Chief, at least for me. The cast what can I say? One of the best cast films ever in my opinion. You see many future stars in there early years including Danny Devito,Christopher Lloyd and more. Of course Jack Nicholson's here and delivers one of his best performances to date. I won't spoil the ending, but it's a nice, bittersweet ending to a film that's harsh but never ceases to entertain. Definitely in my top 20 favourite movies. Certainly one of the finest films I've ever watched.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies ever made. A true masterpiece.
reviews.content: "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" has won the Grand Slam of in the Academy Awards of 1975 (Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Screenplay) against stiff opposition and this is not for nothing. This movie, directed by Milos Forman, is a true masterpiece of human emotion and its themes of individual liberty creativity are universal and far-stretching. Although this movie is about a mental hospital, its themes are applicable to everything in our daily lives. R.P. McMurphy, superbly portrayed by Jack Nicholson (definitely his best role) who "fights and *ucks too much" is classified as mentally instable and sent to a mental asylum, exactly in the ward of Ms Ratched. Ratched is a control-freak and very old-fashioned, but she truly believes that she is helping her patients to get better. She is not Evil with a capital "E" and this one of the themes of the movie: How human beings can do harm to others without even knowing, actually thinking they're doing the right thing. McMurphy, fond of his personal freedom and creativity instills a sense of liberty and rebellion into his fellow ward companions, whose character is entirely imprisoned by the Ratched's engulfing persona. He gives them a confidence boost in their own abilities and tells them (in most cases rightly so) that they're not "crazier than the average man in the street". We get to know that the patients are staying willingly at the hospital and if they want they can quit. McMurphy is shocked when learning this, and so is the audience viewing the film. We ask ourselves - "why are they staying here, caged?". McMurphy tries to make his new friends liberate themselves and pursue a new active life. He is willing to risk his own freedom in order to achieve this goal - and in the end, he pays hard for it, although his aim is achieved. At the end of the movie, we have mixed feelings and strong emotions - we can both cry and cheer.The acting and direction are top-notch, and the music at the end gives the ending an edge you'll find hard to forget. "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" was based on a book of the same name, written by Ken Kesey. Find it and read it. And for God's sake, buy this movie, see it and cherish it for all your life.10/10 - I just wish more movies like "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" were made.

One of the coolest films made, I've watched it a fair few times since i was a kid, and have never been bored when re-watching it. It goes to show how good the film was that lots of main actors in it made a success in acting after taking role in this movie, which reminds me about good old cheswick, he made the cuckoo's nest for me i think. Martini was also a great character, I've loved every movie I've seen starring Devito.Jack Nicholson was made for the part as McMurphy, nobody else could have played the part more convincing than he did. To act a film set in a nut house takes an incredible amount of patience from both the directors/actors to learn how to act mental.This film in all aspects was funny, witty, heartfelt, dramatic and quite realistic as all the way through the film you are either mad, laughing, or have a lump in you're throat at something or other.

This was a genuinely good movie, but if you read the book by Ken Kesey the movie was a rather large let down. Nothing can sum this story better than the book. Personally I would recommend reading the book. It tells a much more in-depth and touching tale. But the movie is a good substitute if you can not read the book. The movie tells the tale of old McMurphy only, while the book looks at the perspective of the old Chief Bromden. The movie does not do the Chief justice. It does not fully portray his character like the book does. The movie did have good acting though by Jack Nickolson which helped give a sense of reality to the story. The horrors that occurred in the mental institution are not exaggerated. The horrors of Lobotomy and Shock Treatment really did occur in some mental institutions. Overall I would just like to say this was a good movie, but one should consider reading the book.

I loved this film, the acting is superb by all, it has its fun moments, it's sad moments and is just one of the best films I have ever seen, jack nicholson is absolutely brilliant in this, going from sane person to complete madman in a split second, also glad to see danny devito in this even though it is not a staring role for himJust the way all the characters connect to take on the nurse had me laughing all the way through, also there are some excellent dramatic sad moments that will leave you crying and frustrated at the same time, this may just well be the best film ever madeI would highly recommend it to anyone 10/10

reviews.review_title: One of the most fascinating movies ever made, and...
reviews.content: One of the most fascinating movies ever made, and an example of cinematic perfection, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a timeless masterpiece that all should see.  It never lacks in pace, it is always an entertaining picture.  The performances make the film incredibly realistic.  Deserving of every oscar it won.RATING: 10

reviews.review_title: people who are trying to be critics... STOP!
reviews.content: i can't believe that a number of people here have written how much they disliked the movie. i wouldn't be commenting here if it were not because of those who kept saying that the book was better than the movie.PEOPLE, DON'T BE BOOK FASCIST!although the original concept of the film came from kesey's book, let us not forget that print and cinema are distinct and different from each other. each medium has its own specificity. if you were media practitioners you would have known this and would not have been ranting and commenting the way you did.what you read in a book cannot be exactly the same as what you get from the film, and vice versa. very much like culture and anything else, assess the merits and demerits of a certain film by its inherent characteristics, not by what you see or don't see from another object like a book.so if you're out to bash the movie just because you think that the book was better, why don't you just shut up and think about what i just said.

reviews.review_title: Well this film certainly makes you wait for nothing
reviews.content: After having seen this film because it was so high on the top-list I imagined it would be entertaining and smart.Could I be more wrong. There was no brilliant scheme in the mind of the main character. Just another retard in a mental institution. And then there is this "evil" nurse who "wins" the movie. Now why the hell did I just waste 2 hours watching some stupid bitch control weak men?more details: So basically some of the characters in this film were kinda cool. I especially liked the girls visiting the mental hospital, and the American-Indian patient. And the main character most of the time. The rest of the patients were basically lazy, unentertaining boring characters with confidence and/or social problems. Like you would expect to find in an institution of this sort.And the ending sucked balls
Everyone needs to watch this Classic! It brings out emotions ALL of them !
Great movie still holds up well today. Cinematography top notch, acting amazing from whole cast, directing on point, casting fantastic. Couldn't ask for anything better.

I watched this movie 3 yrs ago for the first time and I watched it more and more It was fantastic
10/10
Has his pursuit of freedom failed?NO,at least he tried

reviews.review_title: One of the best drama movies ever made
reviews.content: What's to say about this movie? Great direction, great actors , great script.It rightfully won the top 5 Oscars and it is definitely worth seeing.The film depicts the story of a man who got closed in an asylum because he was considered crazy.Although he was just a danger to the system by his ideals and beliefs.During the film though we understand that he is mentally stabled (NICHOLSON'S CHARACTER). Even though his extremely egoistic character Nicholson , finds a way to get in the psychology of every person in the asylum and make them happy in some way.The ending may seem upsetting at first but the director will not let you down as always

By the time movie ended, I was speechless.. The amazing way human emotions were captured. What a way to bring to the screen, the human psyche. The story starts off as an entertainer, with the build up getting more and more intense with each frame, but that is the underlying theme.As the story moves on it becomes a perfect blend of entertainment and heart rendering narration. The problems that the inmates of asylum face, living in the institution, not understanding what is happening around, and living in a world of there own. Making the asylum a reality. The bus trip scenes highlight the kind of disconnect these people have from the outer world and how there world is so restricted to there own set of walls.Jack Nicholson as a rebel looks exceptional and the climax absolutely stuns you. I bet the auditoriums were dead silence by the end of the movie. Not just Nicholson, every single person has done absolute justice to the roles assigned. Its not easy to act crazy, but it surprises me how strongly, every actor has displayed the character. I guess its a must watch for everyone.

***May contain spoilers***"One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" is a great movie that deserved applauses around the world. Nicholson deserved the "Best Actor" Oscar for his performance as R.P. McMurphy and the screenplay was good too. The only thing I didn't like was the fact that Louise Fletcher won the Oscar for "Best Actress." Nothing against Fletcher but her performance wasn't that great as I expected it to be.I've never read the Ken Kesey novel but it must be a masterpiece if the movie is.Overall, this was a very depressing movie. I didn't know that Jack Nicholson was going to die and I almost cried when Chief left the building. But I can see why he did the things he did. Billy was another sad character.This is a **** film and one of Nicholson's best.

I recently saw OFOTC'sN for the first time.  I have not read the book by Ken Kesey.In my opinion, Cuckoo's Nest showcased some brilliant acting, but I honestly thought a lot of the movement of the story was sort of ham-fisted in its obvious allusions to the Bible.It becomes clear fairly early on that the McMurphy character (played by Nicholson) is essentially a Christ figure or Christ-like figure.  When McMurphy takes 12 of his fellow sanitarium inmates on an impromptu fishing trip, the overtones implicating Jesus and the 12 disciples could not have been more obvious . . . save perhaps the protagonist being given the initials, "J.C."As I watched McMurphy receive his ultimate fate, my feeling was that it was absolutely unrealistic and unbelievable.  Why would a law-breaking, vivacious, life-loving man accept the role of sacrificial lamb, other than to mechanically further his role as redemptive Christ figure?  I remained wholly unconvinced that a man like McMurphy (at least as depicted in the film) would truly act in that way, eschewing his own personal freedom.I felt that the movie was well made and that the acting was top-rate (watch especially for a great performance by a young Brad Dourif), but the way the story plays out ultimately left me feeling unfulfilled.
I can say without qualification that I would not watch the movie a second time.

On the AFL's top 100 movies, this one placed twentieth, and deservedly so. It was the brutally real depiction of mental institutions and their inhabitants. Jack Nicholson did a masterful job as the sly criminal who thought a trip to the nut house would shorten his sentence. There is a host of would-be superstars in the movie: Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd, Brad Dourif,and other semi-notables. What really brought me aback by the film was the flip in our vision of MacMurphy and "Chief" by the end of the film. It really made me wonder if there was a loose "Of Mice and Men" (John Steinbeck) connection going on. Euthanasia seemed to be suggested and the fact that Chief was much like Lennie made me think a bit...the end result might just be a modern twist.

I have a great deal of favorite films, but if I must choose one absolute favorite, it would have to be this one. Jack Nicholson is one of the most superbly talented actors of all-time. I enjoy watching so many of his films. (Keep up the FABULOUS work Jack!) I don't quite know what else to say except "wow". The story is excellent, the acting extraordinary. (I promise myself -as I do everytime- that I will not cry the next time I watch it)---that's a big "yea right"

reviews.review_title: You don't have to blow things up or sink a ship to make a good movie.
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a film that speaks to what is best about cinema.  It is an engaging story that makes its point without handing it to the viewer on a silver platter.  It puts you in a place that you normally wouldn't have access to and exposes you to numerous individuals that make us feel like better people for having known them.  Jack Nicholson's performance is superb as is the young Danny DeVito's.  The move toward independent film is most likely a direct result of films like this whose depth of emotion keeps the viewer glued to their seat until the credits role (and maybe even a little longer.)

There aren't many movies that I would rate a 10/10. This movie is incredible. I don't know how it has taken me this long to see this movie, but it's now one of my all time favorites. It has one of the best endings to a film i've ever seen. Everyone should see this movie.

reviews.review_title: The story of a man who is sent to a mental hospital
reviews.content: It's a pity we don't see such movies more often.... It's a great film with great performances. Jack Nicholson here gives maybe his best performance ever. And even though the film and script were shot/written about 30 years ago it is still so current. I'm sure same or even worse conditions can be found in some of today's mental institutions.

This is a truly powerful film. Its main focus is on its characters, and human nature. It is beautifully directed and acted and is wonderfully taken from the book/play. I recommend this movie to anyone who likes a good drama full of the sadness and intensity of a mental asylum. Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher play off each other so brilliantly and is supported by an amazing supporting cast. Milos Forman is one of the better underrated directors out there and dose such a beautiful job of getting in depth in the characters and their problems. Everything is great about this film. One of the only movies i have ever almost cried at. I love this movie and i think you will to.

The film is very violent. Effect on the psyche and Jack Nicholson simply delicious!!!!!!!!!!!10/10 Picture - primarily benefit the actors and their game - deservedly received the highest critical acclaim. First of all, it should be noted mastery of actors who have played major roles. Vincent Canby called the game of Jack Nicholson's "brilliant", noting that the actor while not quite pulls the blanket, giving colleagues on stage opportunity. Oliver Parker said about Nicholson's character as one of the best "real" characters in the history of cinema, comparing it with Marlon Brando in 'Streetcar' Desire ''

reviews.review_title: A film that makes an audience give in to choosing a side concept that would not be conventional in view of what has been common for our entity since our beginnings.
reviews.content:
Who would stop at a mental hospital to avoid the penalty of imprisonment? This change in direction of the story alters the lives of the characters and has a great impact on the film, making a memorable narrative among one of the best.
In this film the intriguing relationship between a violent criminal with a depressive stutterer, with a nervous man, with a lovely crazy man and with a great dumb and shrewd man, makes us question whether the people inside could survive in the real world, making the idea of a perfect world possibly in a reflection of the hospital where there is madness and chaos.
As the film progresses, some patients learn to have self-control of their problems defined as diseases and delay by specialists. The stranger in the nest allows patients to have a new perspective and experience of the outside world, different from the experiences they have obtained since their birth accompanied by traumas and colds, which counters the professional thinking that is gradually seen by the public as stagnant.
One of the best aspects of this film is the accuracy of the time period. At each cut we observe different types of therapy and medicines being tested on patients to make them more acceptable to society, but a problem always happens next, unlike the cuts where we see their socialization with the stranger in the nest, who then it always generates satisfying laughter, bringing more questions that follow with the tenuous line of thought in relation to the idea of perfect society and insane people not acceptable.
Regardless of whether the characters are sick or not and with the final events that are worrying and that makes us unsure about the authenticity of the arbitrary proposal of the story, the film in which it brings great uncertainties puts us in front of a new conception, which is something that exists in a few films, making it a wonderful and exceptional work, which makes the public give in to choosing a side concept that would not be the conventional one in view of what is common for our entity since our beginnings.
This movie is very good. I like it, everyone I know likes it. Jack Nickleson played his role like crazy!

reviews.review_title: One of my all-time favorites -- love Jack Nicholson character!
reviews.content: Was introduced to this movie by a Literature Teacher at a Community College. The movie was great!  The book was even better!!  The movie makes a few changes in the original story, mostly in the point of view from which it is told.  The "Chief" narrates the book, but the movie concentrates more on the Nicholson character -- Randal.

People may say that Citizen Kane is number one or Casablanca or even newer films or animated ones. But Milos Foreman's One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is the best film EVER made. It is a tragic and hilarious. Touching and moving. It is both drama and comedy and balances it well.Nicholson gives the performance of his career he deserved his award as did Fletcher. True this was Nicholson's film but he certainly was not my favorite character. That title belongs to the character of good ol' Charlie Cheswick. He was warm and moving and equally naive. Cheswick stole just about all of the scenes he was in.This film usually has to suffer the debate of whether this or Jaws was better. Yes Jaws changed the summer blockbuster, was Steven Spielberg's masterpiece and is remembered more but the Academy Awards was 100% right in choosing this as the best picture of 1975. It is by far a superior picture. Not to say Jaws is bad but this film is the king of the motion picture industry.The bottom line is this is my favorite film and will always be because of it's authenticity ( real mental institution patients were used) and it's tragicly funny story. In my opinion it is the definitive masterpiece, classic and number 1.

This is one the best movies best movie by the ever made and in my opinion the best Milos Forman movie by far( i mean Amadeus is great but this is just movie making at its finest) and also the best role played by jack Nicholson for me, he's performance in the movie is masterful. Forman just shows us how great of a directer he is , i mean from the beginning to the sad yet poetic ending this movie just grabs us from start to finish and never lets go.The screen writing is great,the acting excellent and the directing masterful. There's this scene in the movie which is for me one the most beautiful scenes i have ever scene (me being a movie addict) I mean when Jack does the imaginary play-by-play commentary of the 1963 World Series to the group, who are not allowed to watch the game on TV. It is a poetic sequence and Nicholson goes crazy with his delivery, describing baseball with such passion and enthusiasm.This movie is by far one of the best movies ever made and its incredible that it has such power for an audience 33 years later, 5 out of 5,ASTOUNDING!!!

reviews.review_title: This may be the best movie of the decade.
reviews.content: This may be the best movie of the decade.  No film matches it in the strength of the performances or emotional impact.  Seeing the conditions of the mental institutions of the day are shockingly portrayed, and it is a testament to the medical society at large, that they have brought back the use of electric shock therapy.

This film contains excellent actors, and the writers were thoughtful enough to include dialogue from the book by Ken Kesey. Although they altered some bits, they made a wonderful film. This film is a great visual aid for the book.

reviews.review_title: Not sure why it's so popular
reviews.content: Had a terrible day at office, so decided to wind down with this classic which was on my watchlist for a long time. I had high expectations from this movie. I mean it is ranked 18 on IMDB top list, so there has to be something riveting about this movie, right? Entire 2+ hours went into that search. It's not a bad movie, not at all. I loved the nurse's character and her performance. You will also feel sad for the patients that go through the tyrannical abuse. The ending is sad and makes you ponder. And that's it. Seriously, what is this movie doing in the top 20 list? I think I'd have liked the movie better if I didn't have very high expectations riding on it due to its high rating and number of oscar wins. May be it was one of its kind when it came out in the 70s but now it's more of an above average drama movie.

I am talking about everything. Everything is great in this movie, but it lacks one important element that always satisfies me when I watch any kind of movie.NB: Because English is not my native language, perhaps I didn't understand the main idea of the movie. If so, please correct me. Until now however my review is a bit objective.Jack Nicolson rocks as well as every other thing. The missing element is the lack of resolution.The movie goes well, it tells you what's the problem is about. However, it does not solve the problem! Which means that the message is incomplete. Every movie must offer the problem to find the solution for it, but in this movie Jack Nicolson had the problem being sick, and all the time I've been expecting how he's going to get cured there. Though, I was disappointed.Probably the movie was meant to be realistic and surprise you with un-expected endings, but it's not about that. I noticed the problem the message of the movie is trying to reveal, where is the solution? That Jack Nicolson died? Is that it? Because of this crucial missing element, I couldn't give this movie more than 7. Perhaps the message is: Life Is Tough, but we all know that don't we? But when we watch a movie, we try to know something new about life; for example, how to solve Mc Murfy's sickness, in real-life cases.

After reading the book, I decided to rent the movie, just to see how well it was translated for the big screen. In fact, it totally screws around with the plot. People die in the middle of the book(Cheswick drowns), and at the end of this movie, he's still alive! That was a big part of the novel! McMurphy doesn't steal the bus to go fishing, in fact, it was suggested as a field trip, to which Nurse Ratched agreed to if he brought enough men.This movie is one of the worst adaptations from a book I have ever watched. This movie does not deserve all of the praise it gets. If anything, Jaws or Dog Day Afternoon should have taken home Best Picture of that year.
1/10.

reviews.review_title: A combination of hilarity and humanity
reviews.content:
Mixing mental health with humour is a tough brand to sell, though One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest provides an accessible and compassionate blend of the two. From the moment Jack Nicholson's McMurphy, convicted for statutory rape but not necessarily mentally ill, arrives at the state mental institution - grinning menacingly with his fetching woolen hat - you immediately get the impression that there's going to be a combination of hilarity and humanity.
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest may have been released in 1975, though it could have entered production years ten years earlier had a copy of the original novel not been confiscated by customs while en route from Kirk Douglas to director, Milos Forman. Thankfully, realising the book had been intercepted years earlier, Michael Douglas was determined that his dad's dream would eventually reach fruition, and the director eventually received a copy, and the process began...Surprisingly, McMurphy, settles into his new surroundings with relative ease. The audience are taken on a hilarious journey as McMurphy has a remarkable curing-like affect on his fellow patients. But he can't pull any wool over the eyes of his nemesis, Nurse Ratched.This film is one of the greats: heart-warming and emotional, yet full of humour and colour. It's difficult initially to predict how things turn out but, with hindsight, the film's resolution seems the only appropriate conclusion.

This film remains Jacks best work of art (As good as it gets included), Foreman done a great job too, but with such an outstanding cast, it was impossible for him to do anything less. Although i am not taking anything away from him. I have recently read that it was actually filmed in a state mental institution, and that Jack turned up there two weeks before it began shooting and actually mingled amongst the inmates. He ate with them and actually sat in on a couple of electric shock treatments, the kind of which he endured in the film...(Robert De Nero eat your heart out) and did you know that the head psychiatrist was the actual head psychiatrist in the institution... as were the rest of the inmates. One flew over the cuckoos nest in my opinion was and will always be the best movie ever made...it just goes to show that not every film needs to be high concept... to be a high success.

reviews.review_title: I know it's considered a perfect picture....
reviews.content: But I never really loved it. I saw it as a child (bad parenting on my mom and dad's part) and I could tell it was too mature for a 12 year old and it was disturbing. Of course I did t really get it.I don't think Fletcher was THAT great in the role. Ellen Burstyn was offered the part and turned it down and I think she would have been better.

This hypnotic film is wonderfully layered and ambiguous when it concerns theme. Nicholson is terrific (obviously, need one more movie junkie say that?). Danny DeVito really flaunts his acting skills here, giving us an undeniably memorable character with Martini. I was also surprised by Chris Lloyd, and Louise Fletcher is absolutely horrifying/terrific in this role.
The writing is top-notch; no subplot or suggestion goes unanswered. Every bit of dialogue, every irrational/mentally ill action seems strangely to fit. You can take from this movie what you will - see it as an attack on the inadequacies of the mental health system, a statement on what qualifies freedom, an inspiring tale, a depressing turn of events, a reflection on the chained and perhaps tainted human condition. It is all of these at once, and that is the beauty of it.

reviews.review_title: 10/10 Must See! Brilliant and not expected!
reviews.content: I saw this movie for the first time when i was young, because my uncles said;Hey mymen you got to see this one! And i asked is it about what? shut up! watch that and then talk to me! i saw it and i loved it so much!At the moment i've seen the movie more than 4 times and i still love the story , the acting , and the characters.The ending is superb and not expected!But what makes the movie awesome is the acting of jack Nicholson , Louise Fletcher, Danny DeVito ,Christopher Lloyd and Brad Dourif, but jack Nicholson , i do not have words for acting.THIS IS A MUST SEE! Don't LOSE THIS ONE !ONE OF THE BEST MOVIES OF THE XX CENTURY, and deserves completely a 10, more exactly a 9,1!

Since the very first time I watched this many years ago, to present day, OFOTCN will remain in my top three favourite films of all time.The chemistry created between each actor. The understanding of each scene. The all important deliverance of those scenes. Absolutely terrific. And lead by the one man who could not be better suited. Jack. A true pioneer.If I was told that the world would end today, and that I could only watch one film before then, this would be the one. Strange you might say. But for me, this one had a big impact on me when first wanting to become an actor. I admire and envy those involved in the making.The cast and crew involved were the perfect ingredients for this wonderful story.

Greatest Movie of all time. I will never for the first time I saw this movie, I was so young, and it left such an impact on me. Evan id i have not watched it for years it still seems like i saw it yesterday. It is when I decided Jack Nicholson was and still is my Favorite actor of all time.I don't know why I have to write so many letters for this review as I feel this movie does not need a lot of waffle.So, I will talk about where I saw it and that was at the Chelsea picture theatre in Chelsea, this was a little local theatre that was on station street in Chelsea.I also saw the shining there and have you checked the children.
It was a wonderful film ... I think it is one of the 10 best films in the history of cinema ... without a doubt, the history of this film will never be forgotten.

I had never seen the movie for I was born the same year (!)It is one of the best movies ever produced in my opinion. It is too bad that today's film producers don't often create quality films like this one.
My all time personal favorite.  Shocking how many people of my generation have failed to see this.  Nicholson's finest performance by far, and Forman's best work as director.

When I saw this great movie, at the age of 24, it moved me so much it was disturbing. I wanted Nurse Ratched to die so badly that I could hardly stand it. I'd never been so enraged by a character in a movie, before or since. I found everything about the movie to be excellent, especially the acting which included so many future big names in its cast.

Jack Nicholson plays what is possibly his career best in this cinematic gem. In his trademark role as an unpredictable and slightly manic outsider, he plays an offender (Randle McMurphy) committed to a mental asylum, where he attempts to brighten up the regimented and empty lives of the unfortunate patients.A powerful moral current runs through the film, and the viewer becomes very involved in sharing McMurphy's frustration at being oppressed by the system, with its allotted medication times and electrocution for those who step out of line. The result is a very moving story, where you enjoy the highs of McMurphy's efforts (fishing trip, the World Series, party), but are contrastively disturbed by the lows.The characterization is excellent, and portrayed very well by a strong cast including Christopher Lloyd and Danny DeVito. The script allows this diverse selection of individual talents to come across very well.If this film doesn't hit you emotionally, then you are a psychopath and should be locked up for intense sessions of therapy yourself. This flick is made of powerful stuff. Really.
Such real performances from the whole cast, so good that you forget they're actually acting!

If you haven't already seen this movie, I would HIGHLY suggest that you do. When I first watched this movie, it grabbed my attention from the very first shot of the car slowly approaching into frame to the very last with Chief running to freedom. As soon as it introduces the group of patients playing cards together you instantly fall in love with them, with the amount of charisma and chemistry they have between them, it makes it hard not too. The first and second act of the movie was so uplifting and just puts a smile on your face the entire time your watching. But once the third act starts, it has completely different feel. It goes from uplifting, light-hearted, and fun. To tragic, hostile, and gains an air of melancholy around it. But this movie portrays both styles so well and puts them together so effortlessly, that it becomes that more effective when viewing. If you ever do watch this movie, I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

What a film! It's fantastic.No fantasy, no action, no Sci-Fi, no Thriller
Just great acting, great story, great script and great ending.So it's really classic.Jack Nicholson is unbelievable, he is the best actor ever for me. I can't even imagine that he was acting not behave on his real personality.Louise fletcher also made very good perform.At first I didn't understand the ending, but when I read the explaining I really amired the writer and the story. It has a meaning.

McMurphy has a criminal past and has once again gotten himself into trouble and is convicted by the court. To escape labor obligations in prison, McMurphy claims insanity and is sent to a ward for the mentally unstable. Once here, McMurphy endures and witnesses the abuse and degradation of the oppressive nurse Ratched, who gains superiority and power through the failings of other inmates. McMurphy and the other inmates team up to take a rebellious stance against the atrocious nurse.

This movie was based on the 1960s misconception that conformity is at best weakness and at worst insanity and rebellion is true freedom. Problem is you can't rebel against the devil. At least ten percent of an entire generation destroyed themselves with drugs sex and rock and roll as alternative to being straight (a hypocrite) a condition many of that generation considered the worse form of evil. Truth is the entire 60's generation was exploited by sleazy people who knew how to market it and had no altruistic motivations at all.As for authority - it often wants you to rebel so they can put you in jail or mental institutions. There would be no police without criminals. All the Jack Nicholson character had to do was play along a few weeks and he would have been let out. He couldn't stop his behavior thus wasn't free. Although he was a good influence for the other inmates he got himself killed. If you rebel the system has you where they want you.

This was one of the first movies I actually remember seeing. It truly opened up my eyes to cinema as a whole. When I started watching other movies, I kept trying to find ones that made me feel like this one did. 10/10

The things that made the movie so good was when the main character and his friends were caught getting on the fishing boat, he said these are my friends, Dr so on and so on and when you saw who was called doctors, the movie made it seem like they were real doctors and not from a mental institute. It also was interesting how the one the guy in the movie that always said hit me while playing a game of black jack could win so many cigs just by saying hit me and when he learn blackjack even more he got better and better. Also the actors also play mental people very well indeed. So the movie practically said sometimes you can't always know right away that those people were mental.
A masterpiece. The words can't describe this soulful story.

reviews.review_title: Who'll be the one finally flying over the nest?
reviews.content: The whole movie kept low just to keep the climax high. Takes time to hold on to the characters. Strong acting by each character.

One of my favorite movies. Extraordinary performances and the story touched me deeply.
Very very emotional film.

I watched this movie first when I was a student - one of those days when only few people had VCRs in our country. Now I'm 46 and I still love this movie. The play of course is magnificent and it's very rare case when beautiful material was so elegantly used as art of cinema. Everything is so well done, I have hard time to reveal a tiny drawbacks even after watching it so many times. Characters are so sharp, such an ensemble of Dante's world, and such a brilliant collections of stars - never before or after I had and impression - this was right team to play superb play. Camera does perfect job, music - the very last tunes especially is outstanding. The movie makes normal person crying (at least in soul) but this is so catharsisal!.. Thanks everybody who made this movie for mankind!

Very often, the desires and actions of a sane person can pass for madness. In pursuit of new life sensations, he is able to harm not only himself, but also others. If the mundane and boring existence is already beginning to get pretty boring, why not try to add some zest to it? For Patrick McMurphy, a professional slob with experience, such a highlight was the rest in a psychiatric hospital at public expense. Communication with mentally ill people can pretty cheer up and bring variety to personal life, therefore, posing as a madman, McMurphy, though with difficulty, still ends up in a psychiatric clinic, as a patient.

reviews.review_title: A good example of how to create a real movie...
reviews.content: Milos Forman directed this movie in 1975. In this film it breaks down the acting to psychological levels, giving the audience a mixed message to think about what these characters are doing. The message is 'what is real and what is not real'. The characters are method actor's becoming the role of their character but it does not stop there. The actor's are also revealing to the audience within the movie that they are faking their insanity. This effect has repercussions to the viewer, diluting the stereotype of people and plants the notion to the viewer, what is real? Shakespeare brought to are attention centuries ago, 'All the worlds a stage, the men and woman are merely players.' This quote pertains to 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' for the shear fact that we do not always no who is telling the true. And what we perceive people to look like and act a certain way are not always true of who they really are. I will explain the scene were Mac discovers for the first time that many people are lying about their mental illness. It starts in the hospital with nurse, Mildred Ratched and nurse Itsu. They are starting a meeting in group therapy. Mac has been busting nurse Ratched balls for a week. Mac raises a question about when he can leave and finds out that he is unable to because he is a criminal but 3 people in the group out of the 4 can leave at there own will but just choose not too leave the mental-institution. Mac says something to the effect that Billy, Martini, Doc and Harding have been letting him bust nurse Ratched's balls, and that they knew Mac was not able to leave because he is a convict. The reason Mac is in this institution is because he was acting and lying to get out of work detail.I think Billy committed suicide because nurse Mildred Ratched is dangerous to Billy because she is a friend with Billy's mother. She exploited his mother against Billy whenever he disputes her. In Billy's eye he sees himself as a boy not a man. One reason is a man would be called Bill. Another is Billy cannot do wrong in fear of disappointing his mother because he is a mommas boy. And now that Billy has had sex, which is one of societies acts of becoming a man, and the total fear of Billy's mother finding out that he is a man now. Because the nurse says she will not keep quiet. Billy feels that he has no way out but to kill himself.The character Chief is acting and lying to every one, as a deaf-mute but more than half way through, we the audience discovers he was just lying. We find this out in the scene where Mac and Chief were sitting on a bench in the hallway to get electric-shock-therapy for acting out. This is the first time Chief speaks in the film when Mac offers Chief a stick of juice-fruit gum. Chief take one and says 'Thank you'. Mac is astonished and shocked that he has been faking being a deaf-mute all this time. From here on out Mac and Chief have made a bond to stick together to get out of this place and go to Canada. In retrospect, what is making these characters lying to just about everyone? Faking symptoms just to get attention whether it is negative or positive, it that crazy in itself, or is it just portraying a time is the U.S. when they had no real identification of who is insane and who is not. I think that is the real reason of the film, who is insane and who is faking there is no real way to tell because the mind is so complex is it hard to tell real from imaginary.

So although i was talking with a friend about this i thought i would bring it to IMDb. One flew over the cuckoo's nest, is supposed to have many religious metaphors. Do you guys agree? i thought this was a little weird but I'm not sure anymore. My friend said that his teacher told him facts like 12 people on the bus is like the 12 apostles and that McMurphy pretending to have a lobotomy but snapping out of it is like Jesus coming being resurrected. My thoughts on the movie: It is a great movie, let me restate as in top 25 movies ever made material, nevertheless my only problem was the choice to focus the screenplay about McMurphy instead of chief, the main character of the book.Suggestion Read the Book and See the movie then decide which you like better for yourself.
Jack Nicolson is so good!!!!! It's hilarious. The show resonates with me as I work in mental health and the characters did an amazing job.

reviews.review_title: I'm human. Just let me be one !!
reviews.content: For me, this is inarguably one of the greatest films the American Cinema has ever produced. There are many reasons:ACTING: Thoroughly deserving, both Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher won Oscar for their performances. The rest of the cast did as good as them both.DIRECTION: Excluding the technical aspects, Milos Forman directed as good as any one. Each and every character was given its proper time to be developed and perceived by the audiences. He was able to successfully show that the only regular way of life a human must follow is to follow an irregular path regularly. The movie makes us believe that we are humans, we have desires, we need freedom: of thoughts, of actions, and most importantly, of perceptions !!THE TITLE: The allegorical title of the film "One flew over the Cuckoo's nest" means "Cuckoo's nest" as the hospital and the "one who flew over" it is "McMurphy" (my dear Jack). The name is allegorical as well as deep since Cuckoo is the ONLY bird that doesn't have its own nest. So is the case with the patients that do not own the dwelling but still they're the cuckoos with a nest(hospital).A bit about the 2 main characters:NURSE RATCHET: Her main purpose seems to be keeping her patients weak, in order that she can mold them into what she wants them to be - good, docile "rabbits" who can be sent back out to fill their places in society quietly.McMURPHY: An "uncivilized" brawler, and is curiously honest, for he never pretends to be anything other than what he is. It is his ability "to be himself" that differentiates him from other inmates.He is his own man which sets him apart from the frightened, repressed group of men who have placed themselves voluntarily Under Nurse Rached's authority.FINAL SAY: As they say the audiences like happy endings, well the movie has an exception here either.It neither makes you gloomy nor very happy i presume. What it does is: see for yourself!! Without a doubt in my mind, 10 out of 10!

reviews.review_title: The movie does flies over the cuckoo's nest
reviews.content: This was my first VCD collection which I owned. The feel of this movie is very very electric indeed. Especially the high voltage clash between Nicholoson and Ms. Fletcher. For me the high point of the movie is the way the entire story telling, the brilliant cast and their performance merge seamlessly with the theme of the movie which is at the backdrop and gets unleashed only in the end with the Chief doing what he does in the end. The book is equally emphatic. Brad Dourif shines like a gem and so does Mr. Devito.Awesome movie indeed.Avinash.

It's a great movie.
I love it. I will watch this movie again and again.

reviews.review_title: The Ending Made Me Want to Cry
reviews.content: It's a beautiful movie. Until I see Citizen Kane, it's my best movie ever that isn't The 1933 Invisible Man. All the actors do a fantastic job in their performances, including Jack Nicholson as McMurphy and Louise Fletcher as Ratched. What got me most though was the ending. McMurphy was a figure people could look up to, maybe sometimes literally. Seeing him smothered to death with a pillow was the first time I felt tears in a movie in a long time since The Book of Life, and that was a fake-out I cried to. I promised my mother not to cry at fake-out deaths again. Not only was this real, but he was like the greatest guy you could have as a friend. But it wasn't just that part of the ending that made me want to tear. Chief escaping in his place was the most happiest thing to ever happen in a film ever. Especially with the triumphant score in the background. This made me want to cry both tears of happiness and sadness. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest was, is, and always will the most beautiful film ever. If you haven't watched it, what are you doing? Get up and stream it right now, and, like me, you will see why it won all five major Academy Awards.

What exactly is madness? A state of mind that is anything but normal? An understated vice that resides in most of us? A consequence derived from adversity, pain or deprival? The victory of this film exists in stating that whatever madness might be, it does not justify the treatment meted out to people who are deemed mad, unfit and dangerous by the society. For, these people are perhaps as imperfect as the very rigid framework on which our society functions. Driving these heavy points home is perhaps one of the best films of our times.Jack Nicholson essays the role of Randle McMurphy, a man whose utter lack of resentment (or whatever appeared of it)and liveliness, while he's held as a convict for the assault of a woman, is mistaken for madness by the law. He's consigned to a mental asylum for treatment. For no other reason apart from his being sent to the asylum, he's branded a lunatic just like every other patient, by the doctors and the warden alike. The asylum, with its lifeless atmosphere disappoints an unassuming Randle and with his endeavors, characteristic of a person who wants to make the most of life, he brings himself closer to the patients & injects enthusiasm into the otherwise moribund life they lead. As was expected his manners are not to the least appreciated by Nurse Mildred (Louise Fletcher)and Randle soon realises that the patients are victims of a prejudice that surpasses the actual gravity of their conditions. So much so that the dignity accorded to the people in the asylum is not of patients but that of criminals.With his uninvited but justified rebellion, Randle helps the patients acquire some self-respect. His peers in the asylum slowly start coming out of the aftermath of the hopeless treatment that had them convinced that they are nothing but a burden on society. He makes them conscious of the individuality which they never thought they possesed.The irony in the film is that where the doctors failed, Randle succeeds in repairing their souls to a great extent and perhaps in the process saving them from going deeper into the predicament society had created for them. In fact one of the memorable moments in the film is when Randle forces a fellow inmate, who had hitherto acted dumb, to talk. Even as Randle fails to escape from the asylum, something he had decided upon doing, the film still savours to the ideal of liberation by showing that due to Randle at least one inmate realises the futility of being in the asylum and finally escapes.
'One flew over the cuckoo's nest' is perhaps the best satire i've ever seen. Along with Jack Nicholson, Louise Fletcher, Danny DeVito and all the other actors acting as inmates dish out laudable performances. The narrative of the film is superb and its depressing portrayal of social stereotypes ends with an inexplicably ambiguous but definite message of hope. It is a must watch for all Jack Nicholson fans and for all those who have no qualms about witnessing the painful impact of society's prejudice.9/10

Having been a medical assistant in many hospitals, I can tell you that is one of the first films that depicts what it's like to be in a state hospital.
Even though the movie is over 20yrs old, it has still me thinking about the patients in these hospitals.
Directed by Milos Forman ,One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is about an ex-convict named Randall McMurphy, played excellently by Jack Nicholson who fakes insanity to get into a hospital to avoid trouble from the law.Little does McMurphy know that this hospital will more trouble for him than the prison he was in.When McMurphy is brought in he meets all the patients in the ward which include Mr; Martini played by Danny Devito (in his film debut) ,Christopher Lloyd who plays Taber (also in his film debut), Billy Bibbit the stutterer played well by Brad Douriff.McMurphy thinks life is going to be swell in the ward but when he sees everything the patients have to go, including obeying the rules, not watching the World Series, drinking medication, and being told what to do day in day out, he starts to cause trouble.The hospital is partially run by Mildred Ratched who is the head nurse, and who plays the villain of sorts in the movie.When McMurphy is fed up with the rules and verbal abuse of Miss Ratched he decides to take matters into his own hands and decides to take the patients out of the ward and experience things in life, they haven't experience before.
I don't know if I want to reveal anymore because there are many people who haven't seen this picture in years.I myself haven't seen it for over 10 yrs until I saw it on DVD.But I will mention things on the DVD that are not on the VHS that will definitely get you're attention.The DVD provides a complete history of the film including how it won 5 Academy Awards including Best Picture.The DVD also has biographies of the cast and crew which include Jack Nicholson Louise Fletcher, Michael Douglas (who coproduced the film). Milos Forman , Danny Devito, Scatman Crothers who is best remembered as Louie from the "Chico and The Man " show with Freddie Prince in the 1970's.This is just a superb film that is very important if you want to study filmaking, but on top of that it takes you inside these hospitals and shows you things you wouldn't see if you visited these hospitals on an ordinary day.A must see.

This Amazing film breaking so much records..and he well deserved, this really is the most special escape film ever made..the others are might be brilliant and great too..but there's something Only about this film..and about Jack Nicholson that make this film so hilarious and funny..or kind of adventure..however..it's my Favorite..Without shadow of a doubt this film should be at this rank at #7 even higher like #5..the storyline are simply perfect..the acting is really something unusual, Jack Nicholson every time make this so difficult to choose which Performance are better..or which his film are the Best..but this..is definitely "One of his Kind"..his acting are Brilliant..the whole cast are just great Multy Talented actors collection..Danny De Vito Also..was Awesome and Lovely..in my opinion..and Jack's Shark Smile..Simply Amazing and Unfogettable..This film is probably a Showcase for Jack Nicholson..his outstanding Performance that Open the Gate for his Incredibble Career and made him an Top Class Actor..his others early performances like "Five Easy Pieces" or "Easy Rider"..or "The Last Detail" or.."Chinatown"!! are Great too..but this one will always be the Top Class Performance.. i think he is the Best Actor in the World at the Years 1979 - 2006..in my opinion he is the Best actor Ever..after Marlon Brando..I'll show you my All Time Top Performances List, check this out..1.
