My first review. Stumbled across this today & makes me want to watch again. Actors fabulous, story interesting and fits right in with today's society of mental illness running rampant today. A remake could be redone I think, but hard to beat these actors.

reviews.review_title: Occasionally Heart Warming, Sometimes Terrifying, Often Funny, Always Brilliant!
reviews.content: One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest is for me Jack Nicholson's best performance of his career - and we if we look at Nicholson's phenomenal career, that is certainly saying something. Nicholson's turn as R.P.McMurphy is one of the all time great cinematic performances. There are so many different elements to his character it is amazing that Nicholson actually manages to pull it off. He is funny, edgy, angry, dry and almost any other personality description you can think of. His entrance to the film when he kisses the guard on the cheek remains for me one of the great film entrances, and always has me laughing!However, the supporting cast should not be forgotten. Fletcher, DeVito, Lloyd, Dourif, Redfield and first time actor Will Samspon all give great performances as the supporting cast - blending insanity, confusion and friendship into the film very well! But this is Nicholson's movie, and he steals the show!There are scenes such as the boat trip which are incredibly well done - and a credit to the director Milos Forman. That scene, as well as others left me with a broad grin spread across my face.However, be warned, this not movie is not all light hearted. There are some very powerful scenes, such as the final showdown between Nurse Ratched and McMurphy, which even now having seen the film several times, I find hard to watch. Without spoiling the ending, there are other upsetting scenes in this film - and anyone who finds themselves upset or feeling sorry for mentally handicapped people should approach this film with caution, as not everyone in this film is an actor.Nonetheless, this film is truly a masterpiece, though I would suggest it is not to everyones liking, it is certainly a film that everyone should make the effort to see! 9/10

I just watched this for the 1st time and I thought it was horrible. I am usually rather open minded but this movie was depressing, confusing and, I think, I just plain didn't get it. Nurse Ratched was completely evil, they gave McMurphy a lobotomy and then the chief killed him--I so badly wanted McMurphy to rise above and get out or something--something other than being mentally neutered then killed. The acting admittedly was good (I mean, come on, it's Jack) but I really don't know what all the fuss is over this movie--and it won 5 Academy Awards?? Was this the only movie up for best picture?? I know, the horrors of not loving this most revered film. Perhaps, perhaps I am missing something but holy cow this movie was crap.
There's no interesting story, no strong villain, the main character isn't likeable, but obnoxious, despite the fact I love Jack Nicholson

I wanna first state off that I have currently been watching top rated movies on IMDb's "Top 250" list. Being a majority of movies being older than I am, I have quite a few to watch. In "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest", Jack Nicholson plays one of his best performances in the character RP Mcmurphy, a man that is admitted in a psychiatric asylum for being nonworking towards his prison duties. He plays a rather very believable character. Getting to the story, Mcmurphy thinks the patients have no control over themselves actually working towards leaving the place because of the head nurse. Mcmurphy notices this and wants to show them whats beyond the white walls of this psychiatric asylum. I don't want to give away more of the story so i'll stop there. Overall I liked the movie, I like movies that have a meaning and reason that people should start doing. Like under estimating that the "crazy people" around us are not capable of our regular human activities and should be kept away of the public. Jack Nicholson's portrayal of Mcmurphy and how he thought differently was a major satisfaction and showed me that there should be more people like him out their. The only thing that couldn't leave my mind was how disappointing the ending was for ME. I don't approve of what they end up doing the people in mental hospitals. I don't like how bad things happen to good people. Overall I liked this movie, It was a good time. -James

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a great look back at the decade of the 1970's. It brings back many memories for some, I'm sure, and it has that old grainy look to it that is very fitting for that time period. It has music to match that feeling too. It is just the kind of movie that could be very nostalgic. But it feels a bit dated for those same reasons, so it is not as good as it could otherwise be. And I have to say it is also a bit sexist. Some of the things that happened in this movie were justified, but there are things that they could not get away with in a movie today.

reviews.review_title: Classic that is still very powerful
reviews.content: Directed by Milos Forman and is about Randall Patrick McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) who gets transferred to a mental institution, the mental institution is ran by Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) who oppresses her patients and so the high spirited Randall is forced to stay in a very closed-minded hospital. Jack Nicholson gives an outstanding and charismatic performance as R.P. McMurphy and really sells the role extremely well but most of all I cared about his character despite his flaws and Louise Fletcher does a terrific job as Nurse Ratched and so does everyone else in the film. Mental illness is shown in a very realistic way and the movie itself feels so real, the lighting in this movie feels so natural and it adds the the authenticity to the film, the interactions with the patients are very convincing and a lot of that has to do with the directing of Milos Forman and the performances. For me personally there was not one moment where I felt like the movie dragged and I found the movie very compelling. "Power" is a pretty big subject in the film, Nurse Ratched is very power hungry, Randall views the patients as powerless, Randall powers over the authority or even at the more subtle moments when Randall was fighting one of the guards Chief viewed him as powerless so that's why chief came in and tried to help him, it is something that occurs a lot. From the beginning shot it shows nature with Native American like music playing, in my opinion the music symbolizes the patients with what sounds like someone crying. At the end of the film the music plays again also showing another shot of nature but in a less crying and in a more uplifting tone to show that the patients are not suffering as much now that Chief has broken the window and escaped free. The classical style music the nurses play I think symbolizes power as it powers over the patients which forces them to shout. R.P. McMurphy gives the patients joy and self-esteem as the film progresses and he cares for the people around him for example when Billie committed suicide he could have just left and went off to Canada but he decided to stay and choke Nurse Ratched or even before that when he decides not leave leave at the end of the party because he knew the place would be back to the same if he just left. Nurse Ratched is a villain who believes what she is doing is right but in the same time the film does a great job in making you hate her as she tries to strip away the manhood and distinctivness of the patients. I loved Chief's character development throughout the film, at first he starts out as someone who decides to not speak and pretends to be deaf because he does not want to interact with anyone and he still did (except in front of Randall McMurphy) for most of the movie but as the movie goes on he gains courage from Randall and he gains the courage to escape and utilize his strength which was his strong muscles, the first time he utilizes one of his strengths (which was his height) was in the basketball game. The scene where the supervisor comes in and the patients and Turkle hide is an extremely funny scene but I also felt anxious in the same time thinking if they were to get caught. Let's also not forget the fishing scene where it shows them finally getting to live freely and handle their own and not be in the institute. One of the themes many people may get from this film is societies approach to people with mental illness and you certainly can look at it that way but the even bigger picture is rebelling against the opressor as shown in the movie McMurphy refuses to submit to the institution and he decides to stand his ground to a system that is not doing what is right. This is a film I highly recommend, the film is great in both emotionally and aesthetically and if you haven't checked it out you should.(btw I haven't read the book)

The film tried to present the madness in 2 ways: one of them is in a common view, which is sent to the madhouse, due to their mentally disable; while the other is that like the character of Mc Murphy (acted by Jack Nicholson), who got passed in the mental test, but having some extreme and abnormal behavior.Those two manners, also to be discriminated by the society, needed to have a mutual support to each other. Their group power tried to challenge the absolute authority (the celebrities include the chief of nurse, and the doctor of the madhouse). The patients are like to be jailed, without any right that normal guy should have: no sex, no option for taking medicine, and no chance to watch the ball game due to the fixed rule of the house. They are just children to be taught, any action which is treated as an abnormal (in the view of madhouse operators) will be punished. Is it really being an ideal place for them to recover? Or even be suppressed?The story tend to let us get the deny answer of this. Self-treatment is better and so Mc Murphy introduced all of the patients to the fish boat owner as Dr. A, Dr. B..when they were escape for their vacation. Besides that scene, another points for supporting mutual healing or self-healing could also been found by Mc Murphy speech to the chief (ask him try to play basketball. Of course, it was a surprise that the chief had no mental disability when the movie was going on) Such encouragement had 2 purposes: 1st point was to show the magic held by another mad man, who could heal the self-closing chief, as all of the doctors in the house have already given up to do so; 2nd thing was more important, it was the clue to guide the ending of the story.The story completed in the way that changing impossible to possible. Mc Murphy was the leader to emphasize the spirit of trying. He knew the washing tray was heavy enough for him, but still tried to move it. Also, he usually persuaded the patient to escape; it actually means the continuous spirit for fight to the destiny, the power and the guys who discriminate them. No one can tight them, as ling as they were willing to turn them down. The chief had done it and escaped away. Is his freedom good for him? Not really, he may fail to adapt the environment and got dead. But who know else? At least he got a new live rather than a ridiculous survive in the routine jail house, even it is more dynamic.

This is one of those movies that you watch, and a couple of years later, you watch it again, and continue to watch this movie throughout your life, when you are in the mood, and feeling it is time to watch it again. This movie is a masterpiece of a movie. If you have not seen this movie, I highly recommend that you watch this movie.

Who is good and who is bad? Well first I have to say that the direction of this movie is excellent, and has no equal, it is what I consider a Stanley Kubrick movie, from its views and ideas. Well lets get to it, Mac Murphy is a rapist, a man who doesn't like rules, and doesn't like the authorities faces, and will do anything to be a fascist towards them. Yet he is claiming he is crazy and runs away from the society of corruption that he built, by manipulation. And gets stuck with a middle age nazi like women, whom, if you have read the book, has control over any one and will beat any one if she wants to. There is the idea of who is the good guy and whom is the bad, who is crazy, and whom is not, who is the real fascist, well I'll tell it to you, Mac Murphy and ratchet, they both represent the hate and the corruption in the world today, it's existence and life. When Mac Murphy tried to pick that sink he was unable, he couldn't reach freedom, and enlightenment, but the death and dumb Indian did, if you read the book, the world was spoken from his eyes, he manipulated everyone, he is the bad guy, so is everyone, the whore, the dead kid, the black boys, mc Murphy and ratchet, teachings of anti everything.  And yet there is levels again like fascism, Mac Murphy turned out to be a vegetable, by the strict orders of ratchet, him going against societies illnesses, and then crushed, I disagree with the minority that believe this movie is crap, cause craziness, is a representation of corruption, and it was not Billy whom was corrupt, it was miss ratchet and every son of a bitch who walks on the streets, it isn't the crazy people whom are crazy but the sane people whom are.

The ultimate legend of all movies. The movie that changed everything. Jack Nicholson appears after his first big role in "Chinatown" and shines. Milos Forman`s creation has to be praised- a mixture of drama and comedy fulfilled with deep emotions. Forman presents a whole new world, a world behind "the Wall". There is one enthusiastic person who tries to destroy, or better, avoid this barrier, but finally fails. Like the political scene in the middle 70`s in Europe, two different worlds separated, causing so much pain and trouble for a ordinary person. Inside "the Wall" the regime dictates and jepardizes the basic thoughts of democracy and freedom. Formans great talent to find a balanced story, which enters deeply inside of you; and a remarkable cast of Nicholson, Fletcher, DeVito and Redfield all together make a winning formula.This film is the real prototype of all the modern movies made after it, from the "Rain Man", the "Deer Hunter" to the modern "Girl. Interrupted".Forman and Kubrick led us into a new era of film, as the real leaders of modern Cinema.This is the one of ten or tweenty movies you MUST SEE. 10 of 10

reviews.review_title: The greatest Movie Metaphor of all time
reviews.content: Who among us is not in their own "insane asylum"? What keeps us from achieving all that we wish? Why are we afraid to free our spirit? Why do we live vicariously or anethetize ourselves. In this stunning movie, JP McMurphy is committed to a mental ward. When he discovers that his fellow inmates are there voluntarily,he is dumbfounded. MacMurphy makes them laugh and he makes them begin to think, much to nurse ratchid's dismay. They hold him up as a god, and for the first time they begin to take small steps toward independence. They eventually drain MacMurphy of his spirit but not before one of his disciples decides to overcome his fear and take action in one of the most breathtaking endings in movie history.
I cannot remember how many times i have watched this brilliant film!! Fantastic acting by each and every actor participating!!!!

Wow!  I can't believe it's taken me this long to see this movie!  I really enjoyed it:  Jack Nicholson is superb (his many facial nuances really grab me), Christopher Lloyd is amazing, Will Sampson is great, and Danny DeVito is stellar (I'm sorry, but for half the movie, I wouldn't even believe this was Danny because he did such a fascinating job!).This movie gets you right in the heart.

R. Mcmurphy is a prisoner he acts as if he's crazy to escape from penitentiary.
Then he is taken into a mental hospital
To figure out whether he's crazy or not, and this mental hospital has really strict rules, and it's an imperious and authoritative hospital, and Mcmurphy tries to spend his days there.

This Film Is one of the best films i have ever seen in my life, i don't recall there being a single bad actor in it, and it's such a good thing to watch after the film i remember crying after mcmurphy strangled ratched because i knew about his lobotomy, age rating wise i think this film would be ok for around 14 year olds.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest movies of all time
reviews.content: Possibly one of the most depressingly haunting films I have ever seen. Sheer brilliance in all aspects; particularly, the acting. With brilliant performances and a story that will play with your heart, this movie is a classic in every right.

For me, the 1970's really was the greatest ever period for films: The Godfather 1 & 2, Taxi Driver, Jaws, Star Wars, Halloween, Dog Day Afternoon, Mean Streets, etc. I could go on forever. But this one still stands out. Has anyone ever given a more involving, believable, bloody perfect performance than Jack does as Randall P. McMurphy? The whole cast are great, of course. What ever happened to Brad Dourif (apart from Bride of Chucky)? It's the greatest mix of pure sadness and riotous comedy ever. If you're a human being, you can't fail to respond to this masterpiece. The perfect ending: tragedy tinged with a glimmer of hope. The best films these days, like Seven, just seem better to us because there is no competition. Back in the Seventies, they probably would have suffered
Simply one of the best films ever made, a powerfully disturbing film whilst very entertaining backed up by superb acting performances.10/10.

reviews.review_title: Prepare to be nailed to your seat for 2 hours!
reviews.content: Get ur popcorns, fluff up the couch, order that pizza and drain your weasel coz for the next two hours you watch this movie, you just can't take your eyes off. A riveting performance by Jack Nicholson arguably the best in his career, and a touching story-line and screenplay all makes this the perfect movie in every sense. Not just Nicholson but each and every character lived their part throughout the movie. Unlike some other top rated movies, the story is extremely simple. And that too adds to the overall experience. Anyone who is facing difficult time through their lives can relate to this movie with ease. Not just that, this film also criticizes the make up of our modern day society, whats wrong with it and sometimes, whats right. Im not giving away any spoilers for you have to see it to believe. This movie will be playing in your head silently in the background for quite a long time after you watch it.

reviews.review_title: Read the book, it's far better than the movie!
reviews.content: Fortunately not many well written books end in good movies (Forrest Gump or The Lord of the Rings are well known examples that it's possible to make a good movie) - so nor here. The director took out important elements from the text or changed it that way, that the characters presents not the way they (in the book) are. Also the "Big Nurse" isn't that diabolic as in the book (because of missing confrontations between her an the "new dangerous patient").If you read the book, expect that you'll be disappointed. If you haven't read the book yet (an probably only watched the movie) read it...and get a much better impression of the things Ken Kensey wanted to say in its great text!

It seems when you get an actor to play someone with a disability, and they do it very well, you get a popular film (e.g. Rain Man, Forest Gump). One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest has half a dozen actors doing this extremely well. That's about all that makes it a good film though, as there isn't any significant plot - only a 'good' sad ending. The language is pretty bad, and the words 'Christ' and 'Jesus' are frequently exclaimed - often in the same sentence as the f-word, which made me cringe, personally.
This film isn't really my cup of tea, but if I had to rate it in terms of the acting, I'd give it 8/10.

This is the best performance of Nicholson,and of DeVito too.It's hard to say that the people in the hospital are acting,they are so real looking. I think it's the ultimate presentation of mentally ill individuals that you can see on a movie. A REAL,unforgettable chef-d'oeuvre!

reviews.review_title: If you like movies that make you think...
reviews.content: This is your gift from God, thinkers.This movie takes on the challenge of bringing the life of the mentally unstable to a full view for everyone to see. Everything goes on as normal (as the movie portrays it): Nurse Ratchet and crew monopolize the mentally ill in this 'institution' until a certain Mr. McMurphy comes in, rebellious, lazy, but also smart enough to get around, and almost sees the place as an easy target.I'm going to skip to the end for a second because that's where all the uncertainty comes up. McMurphy sees one of his new friends dead (did he kill himself? That question may have just come from me not paying attention) and he turns on Nurse Ratchet, trying to choke her. After all the trouble he has caused, this is the final straw. They do 'something' to morph McMurphy into what they wanted, so now he is more ill than the rest of the mental patients. Right at this moment, I stopped the movie. I had already seen the very end where the Chief kills him and runs off on a different occasion. So many questions popped into my head.I don't want to ask one without asking them all, and asking them all would break the 1,000 word limit, but watch the last half-hour, and really think about it. Who was the bad guy? McMurphy or Ratchet? That's question 1 of over 50 I thought of when I saw that part.Be ready when you watch this movie. It will leave a lasting impression.

i think that this movie is not as simple and easy to understand as it appears for the first time.and also it's not a comedy (or maybe black comedy).i think the director wanted to tell us lots of things and to send messages to us (not only a story about some mental patients in a hosp.and the brilliant thing (beside the genius Nicholson)is the director made his movie so that any level of audience can understand it easily.
I used to visit mental hospital. I was wondering sometimes, if there are really people, who shouldn't be there like McMurphy.

reviews.review_title: A moving and funny film that can make you smile, laugh and cry
reviews.content: This has to be one of my all time greatest movies, Jack Nicholson is just marvellous as ever and it always makes me laugh to see Danny de Vito as the child like one. It also shows how everybody came to like Murphy so much towards the end when they were all rowing before hand. I think this movie is great and recommend it to everyone and anyone.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, is without a doubt probably one of the most influential movies, that inspires any director.The characters are bold and have a lot to tell us in this amazing yarn. You can see from the First few minutes that Jack Nicholson's character, Will bring a whole contrast of things to the mental institution.I Especially liked "Chief". In which a man as tall as a mountain, tricks everyone into thinking he is def. Throughout the movie, Randel (Jack Nicholson) stays true to his cause, a rebel. Who lives on the edge.I strongly recommend this film...

When first seeing this movie it became an instant favourite and to this day will defend my argument that it is best movie that has ever been made. It is the best casted movie that i have ever seen with everyone playing their roles so well and each actor comes away stealing the scene. The movie is genuinely funny with real human humour played throughout. It shows the harsh time of a mechanically run mental hospital which is interrupted by the social reality of RP McMurphy. The movie leaves you pondering on one question, Is RP McMurphy crazy or normal? The harsh reality of it is, that we today can't clearly define between the both so can't make a real judgement. Nicholsons performance is undoubtedly the best of his career and deserves a standing ovation every time it is seen. So if you have never seen this movie, rent/buy it kick back and let it bring you through (not to use a cliché - but really makes sense in this instance) a roller-coaster of emotions as you fall in love with this film as you laugh until you cry and cry until you smile.

reviews.review_title: Of course - one of the best
reviews.content: It's a shame I decided to watch this movie right after I read the book. I couldn't appreciate it. I watched Jack Nickolson's performance, but I couldn't help myself fighting with the director's decision not to include the Indian's character in the movie. If you read the book you'll see how important he is. And you'll understand that last scene much better. Also, I imagined the nurse being much older and creepier, but I guess this does not have to do with Milos Forman's point of view. I don't want to sound like this, but I really can't help myself, because the book is my personal favorite. Yes, the movie is really good, but I highly recommend you to read the book. It contains a much bigger insight over the cuckoo's nest.

One flew over the cuckoo's nest shows a Jack Nicholson quite right for the character of Randle McMurphy, it is easy to fall in love with the characters of the psychiatric center, each of them has its very peculiar way of being, We see a Danny De Vito before being famous. This movie shows us that wanting too much control to keep right in a person can also be harmful, the ruthless nurse makes him an easy character to hate. We could summarize that "McMurphy" is represented as the freest man who acts against established authority, which constitutes the great act of freedom, or rather, the essential human act. Indeed, he is the only individual within the great mass, who thinks that the act of disobeying and being free is the act of reason. But in this world, freedom has a cost and above all in such an authoritarian system. In general a movie that ends up liking, a brilliant overall performance and a entertaining story.

You may not understand why the movie is named so even when you finish the movie. Reason being "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" was poem chief remembers from his childhood. This part from the original book is removed in the movie, keeping the title.But Whats there in the name. This movie certainly has a lot to offer. These are the kinds of movies that inspire tomorrows film makers to grow themselves.Excellent Plot, superb performances by each and every actor. Hats off to the author, director and performers.I recommend you not read much about this movie, as it may bias your thoughts. Just go and watch this piece of art.

Absolutely Amazing. My favourite film ever. For one film to have so any career best performances by everyone who is in it, it shows the greatness of the picture. Jack puts his spin on the James Dean type character, and does it better than Jimmy. The film puts you through every emotion. From an amazing novel develops an even better movie. The film accepts the viewer into its wacky bunch of comic-book characters and you become friends with them instantly. Amazing Direction and Photography. Many laugh out loud moments as well as emotional ones, this resulting in a personally epic emotional roller-coaster movie. Must see for anyone.

Whether you liked or disliked this film is down to personal preference. However In watching the film I found it to be intriguing in the fact that it bridges the gap between the Western narrative and the classic Gangster narrative. The opening and ending shots of the film are reminiscent of Shane, a film where the Westerner is a mediator between two forces, the Homesteaders and the cattle ranchers.  The character Mac does the same thing, he is 'sane' yet mediates between the 'insane' and the 'sane'. Another interesting point in connection with Shane is that Billy, takes the role of initiate-hero.  Following Mac around and near the ending asserting his independence. However, once set inside the mental hospital the narrative structure changes. It becomes the classic Gangster film structure, the rise and fall motif, where in the individual through trying to assert his individuality rises to the top of the pile, Mac as the leader of inmates, yet through some flaw in his character architects his own fall - his unwillingness to leave Billy and his resulting lobotomy.  In this it follows The Public Enemy. Through this bridging of troubled waters the film addresses the questions of individuality, the confines of society and the bureaucratic superiority of authority. It puts the question of sanity very clearly.  No-one is 'sane' or 'insane', its defined on which side of the wall you are on.  Nurse Ratchett is as insane as her inmates, Mac is as sane as the patronising Doctor.One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest is a disturbing film, it is NOT funny, although you will smile, it is NOT sad, although you will cry.  It is life, distilled through a lunatic asylum throwing our own hypocrisy back at us.
First time seeing this movie. I can completely see how it swept all of the awards. From start to finish, everything was perfect. No doubt one of the best movies I've ever seen!

Perhaps if I had written a review around the time of this film's release I would have scored it a deserving 8/10. The fact that, decades later, it has endured as a quality piece of film making that continues to tap into our deepest sentiments, scores it an extra point.
Although in places it is forced to change course from Ken Kesesy's source material in order to comply with film format, it does so with tact and satisfies all the book's intentions of its cross-examination of society.

reviews.review_title: The movie brings the feeling of isolation and depression
reviews.content: Definitely one of the best movies ever made.Unique and disturbing,Forman gave the world an immortal saga of lunacy and delirium,deprivation of the modern society through the hospital system,fascinating sense of humor,Kafkas processing of a individuality,perfect music and deeply carved characters.Anyway,it gives a different answer to the cliche-question:Are the real lunatics in the hospital or in the outdoor world.A balanced answer to this question is the Nicholson role of MackMurphy.Although the end is a bit confusing-it is not clearly explained about the psychological puissance of one character (Chief) that gave him the power to make that flight over the "cuckoos nest".

reviews.review_title: Jack Nicholson and this movie are excellent
reviews.content: Excellent movie. After seeing Jack Nicholson in As Good As It Gets I said to myself I need to see One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.  After watching Cuckoo's Nest I can see why he won best actor. Also enjoyed the performances of the other people as well. This is an inspirational movie. I also enjoyed the music in this film so much I bought the soundtrack on CD.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975).This movie gives us an amazing performance by Jack Nicholson. The Acting and Directing are I'd say an 8.The music is quite suiting and light in this movie.For anyone who's looking for an interesting drama film and has the time, this movie is worth your time.One problem with the film is that it's quite long and at times, draggy. Make-up wise this movie doesn't stand out. However the characters are very difficult and amazingly performed by all of the actors and actresses in this film.

reviews.review_title: The movie did not do the book justice
reviews.content: I finished the book a few days ago and immediately went get the DVD since the book was mind blowing. I was even more hyped when realized the movie has won five Academy Awards. As it turned out, however, I was greatly disappointed, as many fans of the books had echoed. I want to start by stating I have ever expected the movie to follow the book entirely, for it is understandably impossible to cram a 300+ pages story into a 2 hour movie. The main issue I have with the movie is that the director and actors had totally misinterpreted the characters and the core issues the writer of the book wanted to convey.Nurse Ratched was this machine-like ex-army nurse who represented the oppressive and dehumanized aspect of the modern society; she allowed no one to disrupt her absolute power in the ward and was depicted as a manipulative and tyrannous person in the book. Yet in the movie, she was cold-hearted and sort of oppressive alright, but one who essentially seemed to have the patient's best interest in mind. Who, as a matter of fact, was sort of the victim here, having this random guy messing around in the ward.And McMurphy. Oh boy, he was the ultimate hero in the book. Flawed and imperfect like the rest of us, he came to the realization that his initial rebellious acts against the Nurse out of selfishness became a ray of hope among the patients. He then came to challenge the Nurse on behalf of the patients, in hoped that by defeating the Nurse, the patients would heal from their sicknesses. In the movie, Jack Nicholson captured the free-spiritedness of the character but no further. His action seemed to be motivated by amusement rather than self sacrifice, which, imo, completely ruined the purpose of the book. Of course, the movie itself is not bad at all, there were some substantial acting, certain messages worth reflecting. However, if you want to capture the true beauty of the story, I strongly suggest you to read the book instead.

Of course if Nicholson is in a movie you may expect more than this movie includes. Only i can consider the date of the movie why everybody gives this much high votes. I only like this movie because there are no special effects,computer made scenes or something like these. It is purely acting but unfortunately OVERRATED.

I think i've seen this movie over 40 times. It doesn't ever seem to get stale. Upon the first time watching it the performance of Jack Nicholson dominates, however with repeated viewings u start to notice just how brilliant all the other performances are. Nurse Ratchet has to rank as one of the all time movie villains and Milos Foreman,s direction is absolutely brilliant. This movie succeeds equally as a comedy and a drama. I still get a lump in my throat every time i watch it. If you haven't seen this movie, watch it. If you have seen it, watch it again. It gets better every time. If you don,t like this movie, you have no soul.....or taste.

Man oh man, where do I begin? This movie really was cool. I mean, Jack Nicholson was SENSATIONAL. The wit of Nicholson's character is just wonderful. You really gotta love the chick who played Nurse Ratchet. she really got the role down! made you just wanna kick her in the head, and that's the idea. in case you haven't watched, this flick is about a guy who wants to avoid jail time, and he does so by going to an insane asylum, but gets a lil' more than he bargained for. if you haven't seen this, I highly recommend it. This flick gets the Chico-Thumbs-Up, the Recognized Symbol of Greatness (NOTE: only products, people, etc. that meet the High personal standards of Chico earn this prestigious award.).

That was a great movie of all the time. Their story was perfect and nicely performed. All played an excellent role.I start crying at the scene that a healthy man converted into insane one. I liked the very last scene when Indian follows the same scene that his friend imagined. It takes me to land on their own. Thanks to IMDb and their users. Thanks a lot!

This film really made an impact on me when I saw it the first time. Jack Nicholson is incredible in his roll as Randal P. McMurphy, and was rewarded with a 1975 Academy Award for best actor. The movie was awarded a total of five 1975 Academy Award. This movie ages with dignity, see it and see it again!

reviews.review_title: A classic that everyone should see.
reviews.content: I really like this movie.  I've seen it three times and each time I discover something new.  Its theme certainly resonates in any time period.  The whole cast, and particularly Jack Nicholson, deliver fine performances.  It's a classic and a must see.

This film is above and beyond any other film of the 70's.  Jack Nicholson was in his absolute prime when he made this film with Milos Forman.  What makes this film so wonderful is how it shows that there really aren't any good guys or bad guys just people, but slowly the film evolves.  We see that Nurse Ratched is the villain without her even realizing it.  She thinks she is helping these patients but she is destroying their potential. Nicholson sees this and he steps in trying to liberate these doomed patients and the outcome is unforgettable.

Every time I watch this film I get a new perspective on life. I learn to appreciate the small things most people take for granted: watching a ball game,playing cards, and going out on a date with a girl. These are basic pleasures of life but these characters in this story are denied these pleasures. Finally one man stands up for his rights , that man is R. P Macmurphy. Mac as his friends call him is portrayed with great gusto by Jack Nicholson, who gives a haunting portrayal as this inmate who wants out of the nut house. Milos Forman directed this film and it is master work . This is great film to watch when you think life sucks  because Mac managed to make a  nut house into his own private paradise. An all around brillant film

One Flew Over the Cukoo's Nest: well-acted, compelling, funny, and symbolic, but 5 main Oscar- worthy? I don't think so. Nichols gave a masterful performance (as he usually does), and was well-deserving of his award, but though Louise Fletcher was very effective as the cruel nurse, I didn't think her performance should garner a best actress nomination, let alone a win in the prestigious category. At best I think it could possibly have deserved a nomination for best supporting actress, and, in my opinion, that would be generous. Very solid ensemble cast, almost any one of the patients on the ward could've been nominated for best supporting actor. The story worked well, I was intrigued from the start. I loved all of the scenes with the ward meetings; the performers seemed to feed off one another and they all worked very well. Cukoo's nest also had its humorous moments and its surprises, and of course the psychological struggle for power between Nicholson and Fletcher, but ultimately failed to wow me. However, I still recommend it, it is without a doubt still a very well-made film.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's NestIn the story One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest, the author writes about a man named Mc Murphy who tries to trick the system into believing is mentally ill. This man Mc Murphy believes he will be spending the rest of his sentence here, but little does he know that he is in for a rude awakening. At the beginning of the movie the author makes Mc Murphy's character seem somewhat mentally challenged. As soon as he arrives he starts yelling and screaming and his actions bring people to the conclusion that he is mentally sick. The author does a really good job of having the actors play the specific parts they are assigned to. They all play their parts with a lot of emotion bringing the audience to think that they really are sick. When Mc Murphy gets comfortable, he starts to observe and starts to chat with the other patients. The author makes it seem pretty easy to live in a mental hospital. All these patients look pretty normal, but in reality they each have their own individual sicknesses. In the movie the main conflict was with Mc Murphy and nurse Rached. In the movie the groups of patients always have to follow a daily schedule that is provided to them, but Mc Murphy does not agree with this so he decides to try to change their daily schedule. Mc Murphy tries to change the group meeting for another time so they can see the world series and the only way they can do a different activity is that the group has to vote, so Mc Murphy tries to convince them into watching the series, but all of them are scared to speak so he is the only one with his hand raised and of course majority rules. At this point the author makes Mc Murphy seem and act like a child, a child who is trying to convince the other children that it better to see a show than to be in a group talking about something boring. Well Mc Murphy tries it again the following night and this time he does convince others, but he needs one more vote so he can win and watch the World Series. It took him along time to find the final vote, but when he was about to tell nurse Ratched about the vote she said it was over and his time was up. Mc Murphy acts like a child by not giving up and throws a tantrum by acting like he is watching the World Series with his fellow patient friends. The author's purpose was to show a conflict between patient and nurse and that everything is not always okay. Once the doors close no one knows what goes on only the patients, but then again no one will believe them because they are mentally ill.In the story One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest, the author writes about a man named Mc Murphy who tries to trick the system into believing is mentally ill. This man Mc Murphy believes he will be spending the rest of his sentence here, but little does he know that he is in for a rude awakening. The author does a really good job of having the actors play the specific parts they are assigned to. All these patients look pretty normal, but in reality they each have their own individual sicknesses. In the movie the main conflict was with Mc Murphy and nurse Rached. The author's purpose was to show a conflict between patient and nurse and that everything is not always okay. Once the doors close no one knows what goes on only the patients, but then again no one will believe them because they are mentally ill.

The movie exists to show not only how corrupt and poorly-constructed society's approach to the "mentally unstable" is, but it creates characters that we have all met in life and shows how the McMurphy-like figure that we all wish we had fights for freedom of choice and basic human rights. In addition to the movie's great spirit, the acting is fantastic. Jack Nicholson is at his best and Danny DeVito can be seen in his very first acting role ( which he absolutely triumphs in ). And of course, there's the unforgettable Chief Bromden. The directing by Milos Forman is very well-done, as the camera-work is excellent and follows the pace of the movie perfectly in how it is used. What really impressed me was the editing, especially as far as the use of audio goes: some parts just made me go "...wow." My only complaint is that I believe the movie could've been slightly more effective if it were based more closely on the novel at certain points, but the modified point of view of the film does make a great point; anyone who has ever hated their job, been accused of something, had some person so self-righteous and convinced of their own authority and dependency on order get in your way, or attended the American public school system at any point in their life should be able to identify with this movie.

I've seen One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest many times and each time it speaks to me through a different voice. Today I watched it. I had no intention of watching it but I watched it and it was as if I'd never seen it before of if I had it was in a different life. When RPM call her Mildred after his electro shock, the reaction on the assistant nurse and Mildred are so subtle yet profound yet I'd never noticed it before. There were many instances like this today. This film is limitless in it's giving and also it's heart.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over The Cuckoos nest
reviews.content: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's nest was a product of Kesey's time, he used to work at a mental facility. Also, he used to take medicine and he experienced how to be in a mental facility. The story center of attention is on Randle McMurphy, where he transfered from a workfarm to a psychiatric hospital. The two main characters that stood out the most for me was Patrick McMurphy and chief Bromden. The psychiatric hospital is based in an all men asylum. A movie like this expresses how unsympathetic life can be in a mental hospital or other types o facilities.Randle Patrick McMurphy is brought from a work farm to a mental facility to be examine of a mental illness that he can have. McMurphy is an all loving type of guy, and very charismatic. He was charge of child rape but never been convicted of. He decided to change the routines of the patients by watching the World Series on television, running the card table, playing basketball, and by organizing a fishing trip. He wanted for everyone to be treated as normal such as pleasing their needs. A major point of the movie was when he says that, he just is going to be for one hundred and sixty five days. It was not true because the nurse had to tell him when it was okay for him to leave the facility. At that point, he noticed that he should have stay at the workfarm. Also, when at the end he end up being like one of the rest because he is a near negative vegetative state to its most elderly patients.Another character that impacted me was chief Bromden. In the beginning, he acts as a dumb deaf person but in the end he ends up being the most the most intelligent and loyal to a friend. The Chief Bromden is a Native American that has been there since World War II. He knows all the secrets of the mental institution since everyone thinks he cannot hear. He was a potent man of over six feet tall but he sees himself very small compared to McMurphy. McMurphy teaches him to believe in himself and to regain self respect. In the end, he helps McMurphy by killing so he wont have to suffer as being vegetative.

I can watch this movie time and time again. Nicholson has a stellar performance here. Also shows at how mental health facilities are, in truth. It has happy, joyful moments and dark, sad ones. My perfect combination.
Only one sentence is enough for stating my review: This film is better than "Shawshank Redemption".
The movie shook me to the core.I experienced all kinds of emotions at the maximum possible level while watching it.
A solid 10 for Jack😎 that's all there is to say about it.

This film is my favourite drama ever. Hard hitting and thought provoking.....this film highlights the enormous failings of our metal health systems, which were (and probably still are) not curing or encouraging recovery....but containing and controlling.In this movie we see our main characters optimism and rebellious ways start to help the other inmates improve and recover from their problems....In the end we see our leading lady playing the nurse not only undo soem healthy recovery ..... but actually prey of his insecurities and drive him to a terrible end. Our lead man loses it and I felt all his anger and could see myself acting as he did in shear rage.....this is one of the strongest most emotional moments of any film i have ever watched, but brilliantly the gloom is tempered with a glourious ending of sublime hope.A remarkable story, brilliantly played by all the cast.....superb
Honestly it's just one of the best movies I've ever seen. JUST WATCH IT

I was left speechless at the end of this intense thrill ride through the eyes of the "mentally challenged". Inside the walls of a hospital, this story plays out through very multi-dimensional characters you just can't help, but to love. But the ending... Let's just say, probably top 2 best movies of my entire life. Left me soul-searching.

The movie has a deep meanings and a lot of symbolics about the social system,Evil and goodness, order and chaos, power and freedom, and of course there was a clear idea about minds control by using authority.
Also I just love Jack Nicholson

reviews.review_title: The movie was okay, but the book was so much better.
reviews.content: "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" (OFOCN) is a movie that was released in 1975; it is based off a book bearing the same name by Ken Kesey and directed by Milos Forman. I would just like to quickly note that I read the book; had I not read the book, I may have thought that "OFOCN" was a good movie, despite the recurrent plot choppiness, but since I read the book, I believe that it is only an okay movie. The movie does not follow the book very well. The main idea of the plot was still there, but there are things that were important in the book, but left out in the movie. The character interpretation left something to be desired. Sure there were good actors- Jack Nicholson, Louise Fletcher, Danny DeVito, and Christopher Lloyd- which made the movie better, but the personalities of their characters, especially those of Nicholson and Fletcher, were completely different and altered the plot a little. Another thing that was not close to being accurate was that the entire book was narrated from the main character, Chief Bromden's, point of view, complete with his hallucinations. In the movie, McMurphy is the main character, and Chief isn't even seen for most of the movie. I feel that the director could have done a better job with that; they could have used a voice over, so that chief could still narrate things from his point of view. Also, many of the important events that happened in the book, did not happen in the movie or they switched the characters that were in the events. The book was written to show how people with mental illness live and how they were treated at the time, which was shown in a deep way through the character personalities, the way they interacted, Chief's narration, and the events that happen in the book. Since the movie changed a lot of these things, I believe that the story lost its depth and its underlying meaning; it just became a movie about a sane guy disrupts a bunch of "crazy people". Lastly, the movie jumps around a lot; they leave out some details that leaves you wondering, "What caused this to be happening now?" Overall, I recommend that you either read the book or watch the movie, not both, though I would recommend the book over the movie any day. The movie itself has good actors and a fairly strong plot line, but does not follow the book it is based off of very well. All in all, I would give OFOCN a 5 out of 10.
I love this movie. Wonderful adaptation of a novel.

reviews.review_title: A Climax stoping half way of a fantastic movie.
reviews.content: A good movie, as the other following comments might have informed you about wat the movie is about, i find it a nice story with allot of humor and drama combined. Other people told me it was a fantastic movie, others told me i had to be psychologically prepared for it, others told me its a movie i have to see. I did, i thought it was a great movie,but the end surprised me. I had the idea the end was the middle of the movie and there was much more to expect. Seeing the credits and the way Chief brake out, i found out it was the end of a good movie. Being one of the few people giving an unsatisfied comment on this movie i still really liked it but, do not get your hopes up that it'll be a fantastic great marvelous movie. Beacaus your fantasized idea at the beginning of the movie is always greater then the movie itself. 'Ignore what others have told you, and you will find loving this movie more then i did' I will see this movie again another time without thinking it has just started and ill enjoy this movie from the very start.

I would rate "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," directed in 1975 by Milos Forman, 9 out of 10 stars. The actors in this film were very well casted. All the actors looked and fit their part. I don't think they could have found better actors for the characters in this movie. The characters were easy to connect with and relate to. Jack Nicholson does an excellent job playing the role of the stubborn McMurphy, and Louise Fletcher does a good job playing the role of the mean and scary Nurse Ratched. Watching them two bicker and compete against each other during the whole movie was quite enjoyable. The movie was pretty well paced. None of the scenes in the movie seemed rushed to the point where you wouldn't be able to understand what is going on. My favorite scene in the movie is when McMurphy brings the women onto the ward and they cause chaos during the night while Nurse Ratched is gone. The only thing about this movie that I did not like is that it does not follow the book completely. There are some scenes from the movie that are included from book such as the fishing trip and McMurphy and Chief Bromden getting sent up to Disturbed. Some events not shown in the movie are Cheswick's death and Chief's hallucinations. Chief also was not very prominent in the movie as he was in the book, which was kinda disappointing. Because of this criteria, I recommend watching this movie. I think it is one of the greatest films ever made.

Wow. I was moved by this movie. Amazing actors and actresses, great story. Keeps you thinking. Just wow. Let me put my thoughts in words.First of all actors. Oh my god at first Jack god damn Nicholson ladies and gentleman, I've never seen such a good actor group in the same movie. Legendary actors play as side characters and they do an amazing job of course. There isn't a single time I thought "Huh... That seemed off." actors that play as mental ill people are so natural you don't ever doubt them. Actresses that play as doctors are such real characters. Male nurses are so real aswell. You can feel their emotions, what they must feel like. You connect with every character.
In general I'm gonna give acting a 10/10Storyline is amazing aswell. There were a few times I felt boring but still the movie did an amazing job on story.This movie is so ahead of his time. You can watch this movie in 2020, 2050, 2090 doesn't matter this is a must watch and a masterpiece.

Ken Kesey would take mescaline and go to work. That he labored in a mental institution explains the impetus for the film which can be summed up with one quotation, "Whoso would be a man, must be a non-conformist."I seriously doubt Kesey had Emerson in mind, but rather,himself. At every turn presented in life, Mr. Kesey choose the other path...many times even if it did not exist.Perhaps he recognized that sometimes it is better to swallow principles and survive. SPOILER But then he had to'ruin' it with the final liberation of the chief.I've read the book, saw the play in Greenwich Village (1972)and of course the movie. I think the adaptation was very well done, Mr. Keseys' remarks, notwithstanding.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies I've ever seen
reviews.content:
Excellent production excellent actors I really love
Jack Nicholson is one of the favorite actors to this day I still see a movie of him and I love his partipacion is my idol.

6.8/10 "One Flew Over A Cuckoo's Nest" is a serious, but sometimes humours movie based on the book, though you can tell several differences that I did and didn't like. The first part that I didn't like is the pacing. At first the pacing seems pretty normal, but during the end, which I won't spoil, has an extremely fast pace. My second issue is how the movie sometimes goes way off the book. In the book there are certain events like Cheswicks's death, or that Chief went fishing with them that happened in the book didn't happen in the movie. For my third thing, I did like the actors that were in it. In the movie Jack Nicholson really brought the movie to life, and brought some of the parts in the movie rememberal. In the ending, while the movie had its flaws, it was a humorous movie that you will remember for a long time.

Jack nichelson what a actor
A sad ending it could bring him to out againts kill him but it was one of the best movie i havee ever seen it made my day i just laughing & crying.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest received a 6/10 stars due to the combination of the plot and the acting in this classic movie. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's nest was directed by Milos Forman, and the story was written by Ken Kesey. The plot was very iffy from the beginning due to key events in the story missing such as: Chief didn't have any role compared to his role in the book, Cheswick did not drown himself, and the Doctor not going fishing with the patients. Lastly it felt like the only thing going well for the movie would be the perfect acting of the characters, they literally made this movie good. Other than that the director missed many opportunities to make this movie astounding with his acting crew, but choked with the plot of the story.

reviews.review_title: one flew over the cuckoo's nest
reviews.content: There's a lot of debate about this film being a masterpiece, but I don't think it matters that much. Other films are not recognized as masterpieces, but they catch the viewer and become loved. "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is just such a film. I first read the book and then watched the movie. Of course, something was changed in the cinema, but the main idea was conveyed. I watched it many times, but this does not mean that I understood everything and clarified it for myself. This is a movie that, no matter how much you watch it, will provoke you to think and even realize yourself again and again.I generally like films with the theme of a psychiatric hospital. In this, the main character, a rather strong and freedom-loving person, ends up in a psychiatric hospital. He is a criminal, but quickly realizes that the prison regime and the sick leave are still different, and why not pretend to be a psycho, for this reason. In general, he is normal, but he has his own cockroaches in his head and the fact that he does not consider it necessary to hide them, and leads doctors to think about his inadequacy. But no matter how much they observe him, they cannot recognize him as a psycho. McMurphy has his own demeanor, he is daring, freedom-loving, he respects others, if they respect him, he can only pass for an insane person at the first impression. However, then you realize that he is more perceptive and smarter than all the doctors put together.
This is a wonderful film about the yearning and beauty of freedom. A lunatic asylum has a very special beginning, and the ending makes me sad and feel great.

Quite simply, a movie that draws you in and provokes all kinds of emotions. You feel such a strong empathy for the plight of the patients that you find yourself willing them revolt to rise up against the system. Only Jack Nicholson could've played a character as strong and vibrant as McMurphy, and a better supporting cast I have yet to see to this day. Whilst watching this film I cried both tears of laughter and tears of sadness, and through the tears I found a sense of some immense but undefinable human truth trying to reach out to me. "Astonishing" is a word that I do not use lightly in any walk of life, yet in this case it is the only single word that I can find to describe this truly remarkable film.

"One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" is one of the best movies I've seen. This film is totally flawless in every way. It is very raw, emotional, and very real. The cast is simply perfect. Jack Nicholson is incredible as McMurphy, and Louise Fletcher perfectly plays, what is probably the most cold-hearted, villians in film history. Nicholson and Fletcher totally deserved the Oscars they won. Anyone who likes really powerful and thought-provoking dramas will love this classic film.

wow, my friend told me this was a good film so i expected it to be. I must admit, yes it was, i liked it. But the movie did not meet the expectations that I had. I read on the site that it was a "masterpiece" or something like that. At the end of the movie I couldn't understand why it was a "masterpiece." Don't get me wrong, it's a good movie, I liked it a lot especially Brad Dourif's performance, but simply, I just found it "overrated." Not masterpiece, overrated.

I love this film, it just has everything.. actually just thinking about it makes me wanna go and watch it again now. Jack acting is superb and really believable. What really grabbed about this film is its almost uplifting quality that makes you want to go out and do something positive, well it did for me anyway! One thing I would say is once you watch this you wont be able to read the book without seeing and hearing jacks character which makes it very difficult to get into, maybe thats just me though. What more can you say really? I love it and earge anyone to watch it and defy you not to be extremely moved by this great story

In "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," by Milos Forman, followed the book, but not in the way of Chief's perspective and the music was powerless compared to the rest of the movie; however, the movie had talented actors. In the book, it was very detailed and more menaful to read rather than watching the movie that left out or didn't convey the details that were very known in the book. The movie is in a different perspective rather than the book and I don't feel the movie was as effective than the book. The music, was very drab and didn't get me into the scene that it was playing in because it didn't fit the scene it was playing in. In the beginning, the music that played was very displeasing to listen to. One the rather hand, the actors, especially McMurphy who was played by Jack Nicholson, really portrayed their characters of the movie. Along with McMurphy, Ms. Ratched, Martini, Billy Bibbit, and Chief were the characters that stuck out the most to me with their acting because of how well they showed their characters to be. The other characters of the movies seemed to be just background people to me. Overall, the movie was mediocre compared to book because of the details that were left out that I was looking forward to see.

I was impressed how old this movie was but still hilarious to watch. I enjoyed every bit of it because it kept me interested to see what was going to happen next. Being that I'm only 22, an older movie does not keep my attention.I think the actors did an awesome job acting as if they were really crazy. I honestly could not take on a role like that seriously without laughing. The actors made me feel as if this story was true and if so they go through a lot having to staying in a mental institution like that one.I would definitely recommend this movie for someone who is looking to watch a comedy and to show kids present movies that are shown on today television are not as funny as the one's that were shown years ago. This movie could also be an example to younger actors today to help them continue movies filled with laugher.

This is by far my favorite Nicholson movie. It includes an amazing cast that includes actors such as Danny DeVito as Martini and Christopher Lloyd as Max. The entire cast is great and the movie is just one hilarious line after another. Jack Nicholson nails the character because you don't know if he really is crazy or just acting crazy. It won each other big 5 at the golden globes and is by far won of the greatest films to be made. The character Randle McMurphy loves steering up a mess and the Nurse Ratchet played by Louise Fletcher is one of the greatest screen villains she literally comes off as a coldhearted person like the character was intended to be. Overall it is a complete joy ride and a movie that everyone should see.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest films of all time
reviews.content: I don't know what else I could say about it. Skillfully directed. Maybe Nicholson's best performance. Brad Douriff was incredible. The whole cast is terrific.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Film Critique
reviews.content: I feel that the film ineffectively uses the two techniques of characters and acting. When the movie first started the only three characters I could recognize right away were Patrick McMurphy, Chief Bromden, and Nurse Ratched. After viewing the film for two days it still took me awhile to figure out who was who in each character. Billy Bibbit was easy to identify by his stutter, but Harding was hard to distinguish. It took some time to see which character was who.The characters' acting was not that great in my opinion. McMurphy's actor was very thin and didn't look built enough to play that character. His temper towards Nurse Ratched was perfect though. Chief Bromden was the main character who's actor fit him perfectly. Aside from being an Indian man the actor was great at keeping quiet through the film and also his body structure fit the character. Nurse Ratched in my opinion was to calm and didn't react to some of the situations in the film like she did in the book. She was also described in the book differently than what her character looked like in the film. I would recommend both the book and the film for anyone. I really enjoyed the book. It starts off slow, but it is worth it when you get to the end of the novel. The film was also enjoyable. It contain a lot of humor and fit the book pretty well. There were minor differences in the movie that weren't in the book, but it makes the film more interesting. If you do decide to read the book, you should see the film as well.

reviews.review_title: A smile with a great lesson.
reviews.content:
One those rare movies which make smile from start to end.
It describe perfectly how one's life can be changed in a second by others error.Wonderful movie and make it to the top ten movies ever watched by me.
This is simply the best film ever made. If you disagree, watch it again and again until you don't.

This film is a pioneer of films to do with mental health disorders. I get so nostalgic when I see this film and remember back to the good old days when films were made right. Jack Nicholson knows how it's done. I gave it a 9 in the hopes a modern film will top it and get a 10!

reviews.review_title: To watch at least once in your life
reviews.content: This is the representation of life made by a movie. A story that is able to touch specific feelings in everyone's personal experience of life. One of my favourite actin performance ever made by Jack Nicholson.

This is a ''rare'' Class A movie that surely deserves 10/10.It's a film that will influence anybody deeply till the rest of their life. Every scene is so alive and so natural and you get carried away by the acting. You almost feel like you are one of the characters, or you want to be one of them at least...because they're having so much fun in their roles and they're putting so much enthusiasm at every moment. It's not like they are acting, they literally are living in that mental institution!! Jack Nicholson's best movie in my opinion and he shines throughout the movie. He plays the role with his flesh and mind and soul(with everything he got), he made every effort to help this movie stay a masterpiece forever. In other words, every time you watch the movie, it gets better and better, you start to appreciate the details of the film more...It's not like Fight Club or Memento, (or any other flashy good movies of 1990s and 2000s). Young generations should avoid judging the movie by comparing to movies of today. This is one of the best movies ever made.(Of course not better than Godfather Series or Kubrick's movies between 60s' and 80's) Everybody MUST SEE it at least once in their lifetime. I have already seen it 4 times. I absolutely fell in love with it.(The only other film influenced me this much is of course Godfather).I've watched it over and over again 3 times in the same day. Don't forget to watch the making of the movie too! It's a brilliant movie, in its magical psychological atmosphere, you can find life itself with its ups and downs.So be prepared to laugh at one moment and cry the next.

reviews.review_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
reviews.content: Milos Forman's "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" film describes a nature of rudimentary society.The mental hospital symbolizes the society.In this film we can see how they treat mentally ill people.They always try to protect them and treat them as patients and they never try to think out of regulations.Surprisingly McMurphy come to this hospital.McMurphy has no insights into the nature of mental illness, which is his blessing. He's an extroverted man and he always sees his fellow patients as his teammates.From that spirit he makes them very happy and he is the life force to them.He teaches how to think out of the frame.It is the best way to cure mentally unstable people but the hospital crew do not understand that reality.So hospital gives him a lobotomy, which put him into a vegetative state, rendering him silent and motionless.That is the true nature of rudimentary society.If there is a man who thinks differently ,society do not trust him.They all blame him and they force him to believe in conventional society believes.
One of the best of all time. I prefer comedy's but this was still a quality entertainment film none the less.

The movie is OK; however there is lot of the book that is left out. After reading the novel i had great expectations for many of the characters that then left me disappointed. However, the acting is pretty good and the main point of the novel is still seen throughout. At the risk of coming across as a hipster, to anyone who hasn't read the book this film is great. i definitely recommend it to anyone interested in mental health and how it was dealt with in years gone by.I personally don't agree with how the movie ends. The novels depiction of chief Bromden killing McMurphy was heart wrenching and really leaves an impact. The movie does not really show how difficult the others on the ward felt about Mcmurphys lobotomy.

Although this movie is based on the timeless classic by Ken Kesey, the film comes alive with the artistic skill of Mr. Brad Dourif, who plays Billy. Physically, Brad portrays Billy just as Kesey would have done himself.  The puffy hair and psychotic chewing on his necklace adds to the craziness and only makes Dourif's character more believeable.  As one website quotes, "he has a face and a style that one never forgets."  Dourif obviously did much research to become Billy: the stuttering is truly masterful.  Nothing could have added to this movie more than Brad Dourif's acting.  If you see "One Flew" for any reason, see it for him.

The story takes place in a time where non-conformity was punished harshly. Since being ostracized by society helped with a feeling of isolation, people like Randall McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) were sent to mental institutions for evaluation. With petty crimes under his belt and a short stint in jail to do, McMurphy thought that this was a way to do easy time. Once there he meets the embodiment of conformity, Nurse Ratched (Louis Fletcher). Her name not coincidently putting in one's mind the words ratchet or retched. Through the interaction with the other patients, the audience comes to realize that we are not much different than those that are in the hospital. This will make one ask the question, "Why are they really there?" This is even addressed by McMurphy when he states that the group of patients that participates in the discussion groups are not crazy. It's obvious that some on the ward require help but the main group that is focused on may not be as "ill" as society says they are. They film goes on to support this by the realization that the patients are voluntary. This seems contradictory but when society makes certain behavior abhorrent, the person affected will feel that they belong there because society says that they should be. The allegory continues with the battle between Nurse Ratched and McMurphy escalating into a near riot to see the World Series, an impromptu fishing trip and the final party/failed escape attempt. All the while McMurphy cultivates a friendship with Chief (Will Sampson). Chief is thought to be a deaf mute but he reveals that he is not to the only one he trusts and cares about, McMurphy. This friendship is shown at the end of the film. After Chief finds that his friend has had a lobotomy, he knows that his friend would not want to live like this. With great love, Chief smothers McMurphy. McMurphy's friendship was also the catalyst for Chief's escape. Chief had realized through his friend that he was a "big" man and that freedom was his only course of action.The theme of non-conformity as mental illness can also be seen in Girl Interrupted. While on the outside it would seem that a mental institution was an appropriate place for some of these young girls, it is also apparent that help was not given and the only thing they had to hope for was freedom.The key to the film's greatness, outside of the story itself, is the dialogue and editing. The dialogue is true to the meaning of the film. Anger, sadness, hope and fear are all contained in the words and inflections. The editing served two purposes in this film. They were to highlight the emotions of the patients and to showcase the levels of illness in the ward. Throughout the film the emotional responses are to cause and effect. This means that the editing is to show and emotional effect to an emotional cause. If a patient has an outburst that heightens the tension or lightens the mood, this effect is then shown to state what emotion the outburst was meant to have on the other patients or staff and the audience.One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest, while being a great film, represents a telling view into the past and how non-conformity was treated.

People who don't think Nurse Mildred Ratched's evil you have problems :P One thing at the meetings its the same thing day after day after day no progress made just the same conversation she likes to get the patients fighting one on one. When she was having that meeting with Dr. Spivey she wanted control, and even tho she new that McMurphy was faking the whole thing she wanted to keep him on the ward so she could break him in, not so she could help him! The thing is that she thinks shes helping the men. And the main thing why people thinks shes evil is that she drove Billy into suicide. She try's to tell the men "Lets try to get on with are day" I am not shocked at all that McMurphy tried to kill her. Even though I have seen this movie 20 times, I'm always clenching my fists hoping that he wins into killing her.

I watched One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest for the first time in Dec. 1999. I was reading a report on the net about electro-shock therapy.  I have a family member who was treated wrongfully in this way & wanted to find out info. about the treatment.  The site mentioned the movie so I rented it.  I watched it alone at 4:30 a.m.  It made my heart weep.  I liked that McMurphy saw potential in the patients there in the hospital.  I now value my personal family member much more to know that they survived this sort of treatment.  The cast did a wonderful job in potraying each person who plays a real life role in such situations.  Thank you Jack Nicholson for making such a movie, everyone needs to see this movie.  It will change your mind about mentally challanged people.  It's changed mine.

McMurphy was a young fighter with large flaming red sideburns, swelling arms with huge tatoo's. The movies Mac was a tired looking Jack Nicholson. The narrator, Chief Bromden was a minor character whose past and mind was neglected. Big Nurse, Nurse Ratched did not have the Combine. His book was turned into a film. When this happened, the film was pro communism and the plot fought dissidents who were against it. I think the same thing happened here. The book was so well thought out, that everything had 3 meanings, every paragraph could be turned into an essay and every thing about it was zen:every place had it's thing and everything was in it's place. Example: Randle Patrick McMurphy-R.P.M.(fast, energetic)-Revolutions per minute (constantly fighting the combine) and Kesey picked the three names of R.P. McMurphy because they stand for something like, young, rebel, natural born fighter. Read the book, it'll do you good. Peace

reviews.review_title: This film must be seen as an allegory
reviews.content: This film is much more then meets the eye.It's an allegory about freedom, individualism, and will being intimidated by the system. The asylum is the world, and the hospital staff represents the authority.Which (despite first belief) is not negative.It's just a form of control, being seen from the rebel's view becomes negative.BUT,keeping a cold shoulder,there is no evil or despotic act being taken by nurse Ratchet.She acted just as any authority would in order to keep control,trying to please majority(for example the "vote for world series" scene).An important plot-point of the movie is when McMurphy finds out that most of the loonies are free to walk anytime, but,although unsatisfied,they prefer to remain within the asylum.Just as people in real life, prefer cold-rusty-confort, fearing a change.There are two rebels, but total-opposite types, hwo deny the system in their own way.One is McMurphy, the revolt-rising-rebel,a man of action,a lover of life (with all it's flaws & vices),that's motto is "at least I tried". And the other is "Chief" Brandon,the quiet-rebel, that locked himself away from the world.That's why the two become friends. McMurphy tries to set a change, and soon becomes a sort of spiritual leader and model for the rest of the group, threatening Ratchet's control.He is off-course put at ease, because in the end, "the system" will always reprime the individual. An excellent allegory it is! 10 out of 10!

After watching the movie "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest"; by Milos Forman; 1995 I give the movie a 50 out of 100 percent. The movie does not follow the the novel. 
If you read the book and watch the movie, you will notice that many parts are skip or switched around. Not only did the movie not follow the book, but some of the characters are bad actors.
