The 1970's were by far and away the absolute cream of the crop decade for Movies hands down.  And this movie is one of many masterpieces that came out of this time period.  I'd say starting 1968 to 1982 in that time frame.
While Jack Nicholson gives an electrifying preformance.  The movie is pretty obscure and is a cluster mess of what really goes on in a mental institution.

Possibly the crowning jewel in director Milos Forman's impressive body of work, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a faithful adaptation of Ken Kesey's brilliant novel.  When convict Randle McMurphy is assigned to a mental hospital for psychiatric evaluation, he finds himself engaged in a battle against the facility's rigid authoritarian rules, represented primarily through the actions of Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher).  In one of his greatest performances, Nicholson breathes live into McMurphy as he rails against the system, creating one of Hollywood's most memorable anti-heroes.  Filled with humor and drama, it's a remarkably powerful film with an ending that may leave the viewer cheering and crying simultaneously.  One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is worthy of the praise it has received over the years and is must-see viewing.

Jack Nicholson is incredible. I was cautious going into this film: I read the book and loved it, a sign that the film may not live up to my expectations. Thankfully Milos Foreman did his job and delivered a masterpiece. The cast didn't miss a beat, everyone was cast so well. Throughout the film I even had a soft spot for Nurse Ratched… however, the coldness of her demeanor and the ease at which she handed out sentences and punishment is chilling. I was fearful that justice would not be served in the end, but was happily proved wrong. Although terrible things happened, some sliver of "stick it to the man" shone through. If you haven't yet, watch this movie.
I can say this of few movies, but this movie changed my life.
This might very well be the best movie I've ever seen. No need to describe it in anymore detail.
A really good performance from Jack Nicholson, and a very simbolical story.

What an amazing movie! I cannot begin to describe how good One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is, the whole film has the word classic written all over it. The production values are of top notch quality, and Jack Nitzsche's music is excellent. The film also has a brilliant script, superb direction from Milos Forman(who also directed one of my other favourite movies Amadeus) and a compelling story. The pace is spot on, and there are many memorable scenes especially the very poignant yet harrowing ending. The characters all add a lot to the film, especially Nurse Ratched who is oppressive and terrifying. The cast are all terrific, Jack Nicholson is superb in one of his best roles and Louise Fletcher is just unforgettable as Nurse Ratched. Among the supporting cast are Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd and Brad Douif, all great. So overall, I cannot fault One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, it is considered not only one of the best of the 70s but one of the best ever, and it deserves that reputation. 10/10 Bethany Cox

One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest is my all time favorite film. It works in comedy with tragedy, has an antagonist whom you LOVE to hate, and the acting is stellar. Jack Nicholson is a wonder and it's no surprise he won best actor for his performance in this.

One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest is a story of friendship that is sure to make you smile. It's truly a beautiful film, but it will no doubt break your heart into pieces. 

With a breathtaking opening scene, this film is set up for success. A compelling story that will make you bend over laughing at the perfectly written/timed jokes, but will also make you cry and question everything you know about the value of human life. The characters are so wonderfully created that you get attached to them quickly and (I can't say it enough) the acting is some of the best I've ever seen in film. So many amazing actors, if I were to list off the best ones I would probably name the whole cast. The cinematography is gorgeous for the time period snd they do a great job of wide angles and (my personal favorite) long exposure shots. For 1975, it really is impressive.

I wish I could put more into this review but there's nothing that I could even say that would describe this film. When I say this is the greatest film I've ever seen, I mean it. Everyone needs to see it at least once in their lifetime!

This is one of the earliest films about the institutionalized. Nicholson as the all-american rebel is some iconic casting. The direction here is so absorbing yet above all there isn't a particularly poignant story here.

There is not a wasted scene or frame in this entire movie. I've seen it before, but not in a while and not with a critical eye. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a masterpiece. Jack Nicholson gives the performance of a lifetime as Randall Patrick "R.P." McMurphy and alone could carry the film. However, the entire cast is fantastic, from the medical staff to the other patients — Sydney Lassick as "Cheswick" was my personal favorite, but there's four or five that I could argue for a supporting actor nom (Brad Dourif as "Billy" did get the nom at the 48th Academy Awards). Then there's Nurse Ratched, who Louise Fletcher plays with a calculating coldness. McMurphy and Ratched are engaged in a tug-of-war over control of the ward, even if it's largely subversive. It's difficult to tell if McMurphy wants to embarrass his overlord, or if he genuinely just wants to enjoy himself. Nevertheless, he's a threat and needs to be neutralized. The film explores comradery, loyalty, self-confidence, madness and anarchy and power-structures. There are too many good scenes to recount, but the "fishing expedition," the "basketball game," the "Christmas party," and the reveal that "Chief" Bromden (Will Sampson) is neither mute nor deaf ("Mmm, Juicy Fruit." Classic!) all come to mind. Chief is a legendary figure, and I love him. The smile he cracks on the basketball court warms my heart — the hug he gives his sweet prince at the ending is cry-fuel. We end up where we start: "medication time". The opening and closing tracks are perfect. The casting is perfect. One of only three films to ever win all five of "The Big Five" Oscar categories, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest might be as close to a perfect movie as I've ever seen. To date, it's only my second (99). One of those rarities where the movie is better than the book (the book is also fantastic), I entreat you to watch it as soon as humanely possible.

I honestly cannot put my finger on what specific elements make this movie so great to me. Sure there is excellent acting, an interesting premise, and a unique setting, but the script on paper is just a rebellious guy getting into trouble with some mental ward patients. Despite this simple premise, this movie swept me into its story almost immediately and I could not look away, even during the slower scenes. Jack Nicholson absolutely owns this movie, but all of the side characters also add such convincing performances. Immediately I was interested in all of them and curious what their stories would be in this film. The pacing is very solid, and I really felt the weight of everything happening in the film. The use of music/sound is very tactful, such as the electrotherapy scene where all you could hear were the tortured grunts. An experience that I was not expecting to have, I would give this movie a 10/10 but I would need to have a second viewing, so for now, 9/10.

It is so booring and bad that only its final scenes could be good. Zero for do not use a decently scoresound, what a disgusting film and the Oscar for Nicholson is OK, but Louise Fletcher!!! WHYYYY? She was was unexpressive. 4/10

One of the Greatest movies of this Generation. it spotlights power, Mental illness, morality, Love, and reality all in one big swoop. when you can no longer trust the people in power how unhinged you feel! this movie speaks to the feelings of a generation through the eyes of Jack's best work!

Milos Forman's 1975 film adaptation of the Ken Kesey novel is a classic for good reason, starting with Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher who turn in near perfect performances.  Supporting cast members, including Danny Devito and Christopher Lloyd create a band of institution residents who are warm despite evidence of their insanity.  Forman's direction is dead-on, as he manages to capture the monotony of routine on the ward without allowing the film to drag.
Funny, poignant, tragic and ultimately uplifting; anchored by great performances.  Not necessarily an easy watch, but rewarding all the same.
This was really good but also really depressing at times.

Another one that I'm not super fond of. It's a strange plot. Most of the time I can't tell if they're actually trying to condemn the mental health system or not? I dislike movies like that, because I expect there to be a clear bias, and it confuses me when there's not. Are they just not doing it right? Or do they actually have an open mind and want to show both sides? Couldn't tell.

It's a good movie... but I really never want to watch this movie again. It was so frustrating!!! I know logically this is just a movie, but I couldn't help it. I was frustrated that this guy who knew he wasn't crazy-- and the doctors knew he wasn't crazy-- was allowed to be essentially killed by the institution/system. I don't want to see this again ever; it was just too tragic.

A movie which proposed many questions and answered them all in 2h 14mins. 

Mainly, who built the cages? 

A movie focused on escape and capture, disguised behind the mask of mental illness. We ask ourselves what institutions have we checked ourselves into, and is there an escape?

Jack Nicholson delivers one of the greatest performances ever. This heartbreaking and devastating film is a favourite of mine because of its incredible intensity and power. Nurse Ratched is truly one of the greatest villains in cinema history. The film deserves every bit of acclaim it gets. An absolute masterpiece.
gust great. Jack nicholson's acting just perfect. Story is great. Just love this movie

One of the best and most unique films ever made. The cast is perfect, the performances out of this world, the direction is brilliant, and the choise of location is crucial for the total to be so outstanding. A stroke of genius, but also luck. After failing with it as a stage play, Kirk Douglas tried to get a film version financed, and he also wanted to cast himself as McMurphy, but luckily Milos Forman didn't get the manuscript in the mail due to Czech censorship, so it stranded. Finally Kirk handed it over to his son, Michael, who did everything right and further got in touch with Forman again. There's so much more to it, but the rest is film history.

One of the few movies in modern history that capture the true essence of the novel it is taken from.  The story of Randle Patrick McMurphy's failed attempt to circumvent the criminal justice system through the safety of a mental institution is a fantastic film.   It was not only the perfect vehicle for Jack Nicholson to shine but also the entire supporting cast, including Danny DeVito, Christopher Lloyd, and, of course, Louise Fletcher.  A great look at mental illness, cruelty, and the marginalized members of our society.   Props to Michael Douglas for fighting so hard for the rights to Kesey's novel, and for for producing Hollywood history.
doesn't hold a candle to netflix's ratched
Powerful, dramatic, and darkly comedic. An enthralling film about mental illness, relationships and the human spirit. Powerhouse acting performances across the board. A must watch.
I have never smiled this much in a film.
A movie that have a message wich nowadays is still relevant, just a masterpiece!
A nearly cathartic experience about the importance of standing up to the system and free will.
The greatest mentally-ill movie!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Jack Nicholson's superb acting and great characters with some good laughs, a must see!

(Sigh.)   This movie isn't politically correct by the standards of the early 21st century.    There have been recent attempts to present Nurse Ratched  with sympathy and don't do a criminal records check on Randall Patrick McMurphy.    You won't like what you find.   Still, this is the great  American comedy about "madness" and medicine.    It may rise again as more baby boomers move into old age and institutional care.   Jack Nicholson delivered a superb performance.
Still one of my fav movies of all time. Worth re-watching to kill lockdown boredom.

A fantastic film. Jack Nicholson is obviously great but everyone delivers a strong performance. There are fun moments, heartbreaking ones, tense-filled scenes, and a conclusion that is shocking yet fitting.

("am I crazy?" film reviews by Timothy J. Verret)

NOTE: This is a film review of not only ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST but also GIRL, INTERRUPTED. Please bear with me on this one!

It is quite apparent that both films, GIRL, INTERRUPTED and ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST, are asking the audience the same question: "Am I crazy?" While on the surface it might seem both films have the same answer to that question, i.e., "depends who you ask," the answer goes deeper than that. Both films end with the freedom found in the "escape" from a mental institution, but the two films' deeper answers are found beyond "depends who you ask" and rest in another question needing an answer, "Why are those deemed ‘crazy' locked away in mental institutions when the REAL ‘crazies" are walking around free?" I hope I can attempt to explore all these questions and answers in reviewing both of these films to arrive at neither a question nor an answer but instead a revelation….but, knowing me, there'll still be a question or two!

GIRL, INTERRUPTED is based on Susanna Kaysen's 1993 autobiography about a year she spent in a mental institution. Actress Winona Ryder plays Susanna in the film and Angelie Jolie (Oscar winner for Best Supporting Actress) plays Lisa, a sociopath who challenges Susanna on this "am I crazy?" question. I'm not saying either Susanna or Lisa are NOT "crazy," but what I am saying is that they both have a thirst to understand their inner workings which probably makes them as sane (probably MORE sane) than most who do NOT thirst to understand their inner workings. I loved the book and I loved the movie, but the book "attacks" more than the movie, thanks to Kaysen's sharp observations into madness, stripping away from the reader the preconceived notion, "am I sane or insane?" After the reader turns the last page of the book, Kaysen does indeed have the last words to this notion: "I don't know. What do YOU think?" Thank God director James Mangold cast Angelia Jolie as Lisa. Truth be told, when Jolie is not on screen, the film coasts along pretty calming and safe (and that's hard for me to say, as I'm a Winona Ryder fan). But all is forgiven when Jolie shows up in a scene, wherein "attack" is a huge understatement where Lisa is concerned. Interesting to note is that I saw Angelina Jolie on INSIDE THE ACTOR'S STUDIO and James Lipton was interviewing her about her role as Lisa. Jolie said either before casting or after, she found Kaysen's book that she had read as a teenager and when she flipped through the pages, all of Lisa's lines were highlighted and underlined. Talk about willing yourself to play the role you know you have to play at some point in your life. What struck me so interesting about GIRL, INTERRUPTED is toward the ending of the film, not when Susanna was discharged from the mental institution but what she said before she was discharged. Susanna's roommate was Georgina (Lisa called her "Georgie Girl") who was a pathological liar. When Lisa steals Susanna's diary and all read it together without Susanna, Georgina is distraught and angry at the things Susanna wrote about her. When Susanna is leaving the institution, she tells Georgina as a sort of peace offering, "You know, what I write in my diary, I don't know what I'm saying, Georgina. Maybe I'm the liar?" Georgina replies, "Maybe not." This is how the film gives us mirrors. All the characters in GIRL, INTERRUPTED are mirrors for one another and mirrors for us. If we say, "that Lisa, she sure is crazy!" (and we do many times in the film), we might as well be saying, "that so and so in our life (to include us), he or she sure is crazy!" Of course, I'm talking about "the speck and the plank" (Matthew 7:3-5), as I always seem to be talking about. "Crazy" is NOT insanity. "Crazy" is sanity in a world of insanity. "Crazy" is you and me muddling through an insanely rigid and cold world that wants to label us as SOMETHING so we can be "boxed in," "you are different than me, and I don't like that, so you go over there (or "down there," which is more appropriate) and I'll stay over here." If we break free from of all of this, then how we can be "crazy?" Mental institutions are for those who the world beats up in this way and, if I'm being honest, if mental institutions were for people who beat up on others, EVERYONE would be in them and there would be no one walking around free.

ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST is another film based on a book, this time by Ken Kesey, and another film set in a mental institution. The central protagonist in the film and book is Randall P. McMurphy, but the book tells the story from the point of view of Chief Bromden, the enormous Indian who all the patients think is "deaf and dumb," until he speaks to McMurphy and becomes the sole figure who finds redemptive freedom by picking up an enormous fountain and throwing it through a window, escaping the institution and running through the "green pastures" (Psalm 23:2). I think you would have to be living under a rock if you have not heard the name, "Nurse Ratched," a term synonymous with "mean" and one with a horrifying bedside manner. Ratched is the nurse who despises disruption and disorder, and McMurphy is the epitome of disruption and disorder. Jack Nicholson as McMurphy and Louise Fletcher as Ratched both won Best Actor and Best Actress Oscars for their performances. There was one particular scene that truly stayed with me, and it's a scene less than a minute where the camera has Nicholson in closeup, no dialogue, but we can hear everything that his character, McMurphy, is saying. It's toward the end, and what I heard McMurphy say is, "How the hell did I get myself in here? They're trying to break me, but they won't do it! They'll shock me senseless, for sure, but Chief is my friend and if the shock is that bad or if it's a lobotomy (which it was), Chief won't let me live like that. He'll put me out of my misery and then he'll pick up that fountain that I secretly know he can pick up and throw it through a window and break out of here. His very act of freedom will be how I break out of here, too!" This is EXACTLY what happens in this film. ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST is about patients asking, "Who's the crazy one in here? Is it us for being in here or it is that Nurse Ratched over there behind that glass and the other hospital staff telling us we're crazy in here?" We don't need the answer to this question, because Chief gives us the answer, i.e., "crazy or not, I'm outta here!!!!"

Not to get too personal (though I will), I have to talk about my many visits to mental institutions. "Was I crazy?" "Depends who you ask." But if you're asking me, I WAS "nuts," but it was because I was "cracked." Truth be told, I still think I'm "nuts" ("cracked") on any given day or, better yet, on any given hour. But what is this "crazy" and this "nuts" if I voluntarily admitted myself into these mental institutions, which I did? Is it "crazy" for someone to voluntarily admit themselves to a mental institution? Is it only "crazy" if someone INvoluntarily is admitted to a mental institution? Maybe the "voluntarily admitted myself" is the "crazy" and the "nuts" part of it, because I'm NOT "crazy" or "nuts" for wanting to understand why I am like I am, why I need what I need, why I think like I think, why I feel what I feel. If you think that is "crazy" or "nuts" about me, challenge yourself to answer these same questions. And notice I didn't put question marks behind these questions, because you don't have to answer them if you don't want to. You can stay "sane" as long as you need to, as long as that is working for you, as long as that is how you "roll," and just plain as long as you possibly can in an insane world.

So, have I come to a revelation? I think I have. In reviewing GIRL, INTERRUPTED and ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST, I wanted to come to an understanding of these films' question, "Am I crazy?," but instead I seemed to have come to understand my own answers to this question. I understand now that I will NOT allow anyone to call me ANYTHING, nor anyone to "box me" or label me ANYTHING. And if they call me ANYTHING or "box me" or label me ANYTHING, I don't have to answer them back. I can hear what they called me and I can sit with what they called me and ask myself, "is this speck or is this plank?" But none of this has to alter me inside in any way, shape or form….unless I let it. I've been called A LOT in my life, some good, some not so good, and that has all altered me in more ways than I care to mention. But what can't alter me RIGHT NOW is what ANYONE chooses to call me, "box me" or label me. I struggle like Kaysen and McMurphy to understand myself better. I have been both Lisa and Nurse Ratched on more than one occasion. But what I DON'T struggle with or what I have NOT been both (actually, I'm lying….I AM BOTH!!!!) is me finding my own path, journeying, discovering, weeping, laughing, etc. I think they call this "living."

"Am I crazy?" "I don't know. What do YOU think?" or, more appropriately asked, "I don't know. what do YOU think about asking yourself this same question?"
Powerfully resonant piece of cinema.

The first thing that one notices while watching this film is the quality of the acting. It's extremely hard for actors to portray the intensity of mental illness in a way that is not offensive. Yet, the supporting cast of Will Sampson, Danny DeVito, Brad Dourif, Christopher Lloyd, among others make this a performance to remember. Everyone in their cast was spectacular in their roles. There were times I thought I was watching real patients with mental illness.

Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher do a remarkable job bringing the conflict to life. Playing  McMurphy and Nurse Ratched, audiences feel the high stakes card game at each act of this movie. Nicholson goes above and beyond in captivating audiences and making this a masterpiece.

The writing, dialogue, and plot give each character a chance at full development. Bo Goldman and Lawrence Hauben are amazing at letting each character shine. Audiences can understand the themes brought to light. Themes of authoritarian care, social support structures for the mentally ill, dependencies on said structures, and soul-crushing institutionalism vs individuality.

The script was incredible as the audience can never quite predict what happens next. There were moments of real tension felt as the suspense builds and we wonder if our protagonist gets caught.

Jack Nitzsche brings alive the entire movie with his wonderful music. Every scene is built upon and improved with the addition of his work.

An outstanding movie that still holds relevance in today's society. Milos Forman lets his artistic genius shine. 

5/5.

I watched it so long ago but it feels nice to revisit it 45 years later. 
Had no idea it was based on a book by Ken Kesey.
Directed by Milos Forman and produced by Michael Douglas it's been engraved into the public consciousness for so many years as one of the greatest movies ever made. 
This is still one of the best performances of Jack Nicholson's career.
A terrific supporting cast from Christopher Lloyd to Brad Dourif to Danny Devito to Sydney Lassick to William Redfield to Will Sampson as the mute but beloved Chief. Chief chooses not to communicate as a way of not being mistreated by the general population the same way his father was treated when he was a soldier so he and Randle are more alike in many ways. 
Randle is admitted into the Oregon psychiatric hospital to see if he's mentally unstable. He's committed statutory rape, has had physical altercations, and is not very work-savvy. He's flawed but feels he can find a solution to why he's so troubled. So for his entire stay Randle acts as a humorous con man. He's very roguish and rebellious making an impact for the other patients. The head nurse is Ratched being a corrupt authority figure. 
The rivalry of Randle and Nurse Ratchet played by Louise Fletcher is iconic. It serves as microcosm for the culture wars of the 1970s. Ratchet runs this hospital with an iron fist belittling the men making them talk about what's bothering them. It's until Randle arrives when her perfect world order is shaken up. Ratchet doesn't want to relinquish her hold over the patients so she bumps heads with Randle several times over. 
Kesey's novel was meant to offer a blunt study of the institutional process critiquing patients were treated in the 60s. One of his themes included machines always triumph over nature.
The book was also adapted into a broadway play. 
The movie was one of many criticized by psychologists. True it's difficult to properly depict mentally ill individuals. And the film does deviate from the source material a lot mainly white washing the lead. But the original novel has earned a spot on high school reading lists. That's how strong its staying power has lasted. Many of Kesey's themes are still intact such as freedom vs institutionalization as well as rebellion against authority, conformity, gender roles, homophobia, misogyny, racism, and mental illness. He saw that removing people from society not conforming to the norm turned functional members of society insane. 
With Randle he finds out during his time with the patients that they don't know how to leave even if they wanted to. So he offers a glimmer of hope for them enjoying the harmless pleasures of life not being restrained by strict rules and procedures. Even though the author despised the final product and Nicholson and Forman had a falling out the movie still remains a masterpiece of cinema. 
Definitely speaks out of the mistreatment of patients and the failing of the system itself. The main central theme remains; being institutionalized for better or worse will inevitably affect your own mental health. Mental health is better looked at today than it was way back. Thanks to this movie it shifted psychiatric practices for the better. For the patients it's up to them to commit themselves willingly to be treated so they can leave themselves. 
Nicholson shines as a rebellious patient hero and Louise Fletcher brings this devious nurse to life. Even the music at the end gives off a kooky yet emotional vibe. This is still a true cinematic achievement for life.
This movie deserved the oscars it got. 8.5/10, B+

Here we have another stab at communism with another great film One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. R.P. MacMurphy (Jack Nicholson) is a man who poses as a patient at a mental hospital led by Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) and encourages the other patients to embrace their human behavior and have fun. During which he befriends a mute Native American patient Chief (Will Sampson) who reminisces about freedom in his home Canada. Let's look at the film in context. Before the film, the communist party had spread in Asia, Europe and Cuba and the Cold War was still occurring. In fact, by the mid 1970's, America had lost a war in Vietnam, matching the tragic outcome of MacMurphy in the film. Speaking of, director Milos Forman, a native of Czechoslovakia, made a similar type of movie called The Firemen's Ball, which mocked the home country's communist party and was a milestone of the Czechoslovak New Wave. In the Americas, Ken Kesey wrote a novel about behaviorism and control called "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," which depicted the nurses as the socialists who imprisoned their patients. A decade later, producers Kirk and Michael Douglas bought the rights to the book and asked the Czech director to craft the movie. Although as political as Forman's work strives to be, it works thanks to its nihilistic themes and also Jack Nicholson's wild energy.

The climax has the shocking moments, from moments with Billy played well Brad Dourif,Nurse Ratched being strangled and the eventually mercy killing of Randle. We embrace the madness, we laugh at them, we laugh with them, we feel sorry for them and embrace when their regimented day is changed. The freedom seems to be only through escaping or dying. They are some moments where i feel it wouldn't happen, with many times the nurses station being easy access to the patients. The imaginary play by play baseball sequence is memorable as he shows them a different side than the normal everyday. His impact on the men is felt through the enjoyable moments but also in tragedy. Entertaining and thought provoking.

The movie, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" directed by Milos Forman, would receive a three out of five-star rating because of the actors, how closely it stayed true to the book, and the ending. Will Samson, the actor that portrayed Chief, was a strong acting choice because he strongly depicts the shy nature of Chief in the book, as well as, his physical appearance of a large Native American. However other characters, like Harding, are not as to be desired. After reading the novel, one would picture Harding to be a young, handsome man with high education, but in reality, the actor is a middle-aged, out-of-shape man. The movie also bypasses major parts of the book, like meeting Harding's wife and the development of the fishing scene, failing to stay true to the source material. Seeing how Harding's wife conducts herself and the planning that went into the fishing trip, helps in understanding some confusing scenes in the movie and inevitably makes the book more enjoyable. Even though Forman's casting choices were a bit questionable and he left out major parts of the book, he did capture the ending perfectly creating some closure for the audience but still keep them wondering about life on the ward. In conclusion, there are quality parts to the movie like Chief's character and the ending; however, the movie fails to stay true to the source material making the book a much more enjoyable use of your time.

The movie, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," directed by Miloš Forman in 1975 receives an average rating. There are multiple components from the book that were altered or didn't make it into the movie. In the book, Chief is the narrator, but in the movie the story is based around Mr. McMurphy's point of view; consequently, cutting out the ending of the book. One scene that was altered, is the fishing scene.  Mr. McMurphy is the ‘Captain' of the ship, but in the book George is the one who knows all about fishing and is the ‘Captain' of the boat. The movie alters this to make McMurphy more psychotic than he already is portrayed. One actress didn't look like she was described in the book. Louise Fletcher did a great job in the movie, but I was expecting more looks of the character Pam Ferris plays in "Matilda." Overall, the movie was relatively close to the book and not too many scenes were altered of cut out of the movie.

The film, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," directed by Milos Forman in 1975 rated a 70% in my opinion because of the plot/storyline, the truth to the source material, and the ending of the film. The plot throughout the movie was fairly similar to the book in regards to laying out the key events but the movie changed specific events. For example, in the movie McMurphy escaped from the fence and stole the bus to go on a fishing trip with candy and the other individuals from the ward, whereas, in the book, McMurphy had to convince many to go on the trip and did not have to steal the bus because the Doctor had to tag along in regards to the agreement of going out of the ward. The movie was not completely true to the source material because George a character used throughout the book did not exist in the movie, the narrator of the movie is from McMurphy's point of view and not the Chief's, and the Chief was seen as the hero in the book whereas in the movie McMurphy is seen as the hero. Lastly, the ending of the movie did not show Chief's escape as detailed as the book because the viewer never experiences Cheif meeting with a man to catch a ride as well as his plan to go to Canada. The ending of the book showed the readers the plan chief had after the ward escape, and the movie ended with Chief breaking the window and escaping from the ward. As viewers, we do not know what happened after the escape Cheif makes if you have not read the book. In conclusion, the book was a better version of the story, the movie's plot/storyline, truth to the source material, and ending lead me to think that the film was less enjoyable than the novel.

In the 1975 movie showing of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", produced by Milos Forman, not only was the casting mediocre and the plot confusing, but the storyline differed heavily from the original novel. Because of these traits, I would give the movie two out of five stars, which translates to a 40%. To begin, the physical characteristics of the characters were highly different from what was expected while reading the novel.  Jack Nicholson, who played McMurphy, was not nearly as tall, strapping, and of ginger complexion as he was described in the book. William Redflied, who depicts the character of Harding, was not beautiful and graceful, as the book had led me to believe.  While these two character discrepancies loom the heaviest, no character seen in the movie was true to Ken Kesey's original enactment.  Secondly, without the background knowledge stemming from the reading of the novel, the plot is confusing and events happen without reason.  The fishing trip was a blur, without purpose, and out of order.  The introduction of Sandy and Candy was also muddy, as the arrangement of their arrival is never seen being discussed.  Finally, with a differentiating storyline than the novel, key motifs were forgotten.  We were never introduced to Billy's mother, Harding's wife never came into play, Cheswick and Rowler the Squaller suicides were left out, and also, George, the germaphobe, was never present. In conclusion, the movie portrayal of Ken Kesey's One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest was frankly a waste of time and hard to watch.

It's really hard to find movies based on books that comes so close to the original material from the universe of literature. "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest respects almost everything that created by Ken Kesey and even gives us something more to the cheer about It: The pleasure of being alive in many types of prisons around the world, specially those ones in our minds. 

The script follows the rebeld caracther Jack Randle McMurphy, played by the immortal Jack Nicholson, a young man who can't live by the rules of society, that had a sexual relationship with a young girl whose under age and goes to prison. Once there, he pretends to be crazy only to pay for his crime in a mental hospital. By the time he gets there, he meets other men, the real patientes, whose suffers from the iron villain, the chief of the nursery, the evil Mildred Ratched - played by  Louise Fletcher. Once Jack gets to the heart of the other patientes, he decides to create a game against their enemy to see what happens when a big unexpected change comes along in a prison molded by rules.

It's funny to realize that the movie takes place in the 60's and the beatnik movement was all around in north american societies, building up new kinds of thoughts and everything. All those people portrayed as patients, I mean, those one close to Jack in the "round table" were really afraid to go back to the real world and that's how the magic comes along during to the whole picture. 

Jack is the revolution that every mind needs. How can't you not love the way he narrates the game on the shut television? How can you forget the moment that Cheswick comes up against Mrs. Ratched about HIS cigarettes? Milos Forman keep sending messages during the whole fun: Set yourself free from yourself. The greatest weapon It's your mind.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a 1975 drama based on a 1962 novel by the same name. The film was directed by Miloš Forman, and stars Jack Nicholson as Randle McMurphy and Louise Fletcher as Nurse Ratched.

The story follows Randle McMurphy a man who has been sent to a mental institution after his odd behaviour at his former prison. The story I found to be really strong and incredibly intriguing, especially once you hit the second act.

The acting was by far some of the strongest that I've seen in film, especially Jack Nicholson as McMurphy, I found that he gave an extremely entertaining and thrilling performance.

The characters were all portrayed and written incredibly well, from the schizophrenic Charley Cheswick to the silent but lovable Chief Bromden.

The setting, sets and costumes were also really strong, especially the set designs of the mental institution.

The soundtrack for the film in my opinion is one of the best, especially the song that plays at the beginning and end of the film. 

The film also had some incredibly strong atmosphere, especially at the end of the third act.

The film also carries emotions really well, from the mental patients to the people related to them.

The film is also extremely gripping and intriguing, and I hope to watch it again soon.

Over all I give it a 
10/10 - would recommend

This is an oddly watchable film for how dark it's subject matter is and for how difficult it is to watch a man receive electro shock treatment and see a man who has cut his wrists and killed himself. Those are the sorts of scenes you will have to face in this film but you also get funny moments and scenes that are just bursting with life even as men are surrounded by wire fences. Milos Forman made his second English language film with One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and he excels at he paces the story well knows when to let his actors shine and balances the tones perfectly. I can fully appreciate why this film is such a classic but in a year like 1975 I don't know if I would call it the Best Picture of the year even though it would easily beat most other Best Picture winners.

Randall McMurphy, Jack Nicholson, is pretending to be insane to avoid having to serve prison time and ends up at a mental hospital run by the steely Nurse Ratched, Louise Fletcher, who proves a worthy adversary. As he attempts to challenge her authority she exercises her ability to control his fellow mental hospital patients but after he takes the men out on a joyride in town she becomes more aggressive. He is sentenced indefinitely which increases his frustration and plots to escape the hospital with the help of some prostitutes but the morning after tragedy occurs as McMurphy attempts to strangle Ratched and ends up receiving more shock treatment as punishment.

What was interesting to me about the movie was that it could be interpreted in multiple different ways. The most traditional interpretation is that McMurphy is innocent and attempting to free the mental patients from the evil Ratched, which reviewers certainly give credence to. A more interesting interpretation is that McMurphy actually is mental but refuses to accept it and Ratched is simply doing her job and must subdue McMurphy as he is an obstacle to her noble goals. The direction and the performances allow you to see and enjoy the film from multiple different characters' points of view and that just makes it a richer experience.

Fletcher's performance is simply brilliant as she doesn't play the villain as icy and cold with a deep voice as many actresses would have but as sensible and measured with a softly spoken tone. We believe that she thinks what she is doing is correct, in some cases it may be, which causes her to be one of the best villains put on the screen as her motivations make sense and the extreme actions she takes are more tragic than maddening. She is matched by Nicholson who gives one of his best performances as he injects his own manic personality and odd warmth into the devilishly charming protagonist. Dourif stands out as the troubled but sympathetic Billy Bibbit as he masters the speech patterns and nervous tics of a significantly disturbed young man. I believe that Fletcher and Nicholson both earned their Academy Awards and Fletcher's performance is one of the greatest Best Actress winning performances of all time.

Forman's direction is great as he allows for long, drawn out scenes that occur in one room in the mental hospital and knows when to cut away. We do have to watch McMurphy face electroshock therapy but it's use does not feel exploitative and we don't see it again and again as we would in a more tawdry production. The final scene works because these characters have been built up so well and we feel that we know them and how they would react in certain situations so their emotional response to the devastating events in the final scenes of the movies draw a genuine reaction out of us.

I would have given Barry Lyndon (1975) the Best Picture award even as I would say it has more flaws than this film because it nevertheless contains some fantastic moments. This is certainly a worthy winner when compared to Tom Jones (1963) and A Man for All Seasons (1966) however and is one of the few real classics littered in there amongst the rest of the Best Picture winners.

One Flew Over The Cuckoo’s Nest: An impactful drama that tackles the themes of chaos and order; with a lasting impact 3 decades later. Milos Forman brings the some of the best out of Jack Nicholson and is a near career high.

The 1975 comedy-drama, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", directed by MiloÅ¡ Forman underperformed due to its inadequate character development and weak plot development, but recovered slightly with its satisfactory acting. The lack of character development in roles like Billy Bibbit and Chief Bromden limits the audience's ability to emotionally connect to the film and its events. The film pales in comparison to the novel when it comes to character development. Plot development is also a major shortcoming for MiloÅ¡ Forman's film. Many essential aspects of Chief's personality are omitted from the film, such as memories, flashbacks, and hallucinations. There were symbolic parts of the novel omitted as well, such as the dog sniffing for ground squirrels in the night. In contrast, the acting, specifically that of Jack Nicholson is suitable. Nicholson is able to transport the viewer to a 50s-era mental hospital by assuming the role of Randle McMurphy. In conclusion, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" slightly disappointed me as a viewer, but I appreciate the acting jobs and casting of the film.

The movie, "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" is about the life of people in the insane asylums and mental institutions. Compared to the book, it does go in order, but multiple events in the book were altered either for trimming down time or other reasons. I am going to say right away in the beginning of the review that I was not able to watch the whole movie. So, I am going off from what I have seen. I am going to focus on the main characters and their fit for the part, the setting and vibe of the movie, and the overall connection to the book itself. Starting with the characters, I believe that all of the actors fit very well with the part they played. The only character that I did not imagine in the movie the same was the Nurse. She is skinnier in the movie than I imagined her to be. She was also a lot younger looking. The acting for all primary, secondary, and the remaining character was very satisfactory overall. The actors were still very talented and played their role well. The setting and vibe of the movie was really good. It truly felt like they were in a ward/ asylum. The overall connection to the book was pretty spot on. The order was correct. The only thing that did not match the book were some events being altered. I would definitely recommend the movie and watch it again; this time, actually watch the entire film.

MiloÅ¡ Forman's film "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" would get about 3 out of five stars because of the actors, the character development, and how closely it followed the plot of the book. Jack Nicholson was a very good actor and made the movie funny. Some of the actors were a little cheesy. The character development was not the greatest. There was not much of a description of who the characters were and at some parts it was hard to remember who was who. The movie also did not follow the plot of the book very closely. For example, the fishing scene is in both the movie and the book; however, in the book they developed it a lot more and made it into more of a story which made it more enjoyable than in the movie.

The movie "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" directed by Milos Forman. This was very good watchworly movie even though it was made in 1975 because of its actors, cinematography, and personal connections. All of the actors fit all the characters in the book. The best actor was Will Sampson(Chief) because it was exact as the book. I also feel the cinematograph was outstanding. What I liked the most is how they got all the angles of the people and backgrounds. Everything was fitting and overall very clean. The personal connection was easy, I connected to the basketball scene and when they kind of partied. I give this movie a 100%.

Throughout the movie "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," the cinematography, actors, and emotional connection with the actors development was astounding. I was skeptical about how great the cinematography quality would be, being the movie was made in 1975; however, the lighting, camera work, and quality was overall acceptable. I felt that each actor did a good job playing their own unique role. I really enjoyed Billy Bibbits character because the actor did a wonderful job displaying the challenges of a stuttered boy in this time era. Also Jack Nicholson was a perfect role for McMurphy with his strong emotions and charming personality. On the other hand, I would give the character development a 3 out of 5 stars. I felt that the movie allowed the audience to connect with a few of the characters such as Billy and McMurphy; however, unlike the book, some of the other characters weren't fully focused on for example developing an emotional attachment with Chief. I wish the movie would've focused more on Chiefs story; however, the overall quality of the movie as well as the actors did a great job displaying the struggles of mental health in the past.

I give the movie adaptation of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" directed by MiloÅ¡ Forman a 75% based off of the criteria of Plot, Acting, and Character development. The plot was probably its best point. The movie had a solid story about patients in an asylum trying to live a life worth living while in the asylum. The acting was the movies weakest point. The acting was not terrible but not good either; It just made it difficult to immerse yourself in the movie and believe, for those 2 hours, that it was real. The Character development was poorly done but not terrible. What I mean by that is that the development felt off, and that made it hard to invest in the characters making what should have been powerful since relatively weak.

I rate the movie "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", a 1975 film directed by Milos Forman, at 9/10. It is an intriguing movie which includes Jack Nicholson as Randle McMurphy. It is a great story adapted into a movie containing nearly all of the highlights found in the book. It includes plenty of McMurphy's charm and a whole cast of crazies who are just waiting to learn what being a real person in society is like.

The movie adaptation of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," directed by MiloÅ¡ Forman, fell slightly below my expectations when focusing on acting, plot development, and character development in comparison to the book. Though I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the acting and ability of the actors to portray the uniqueness of the characters, I was a bit disappointed in actor selection. Jack Nicholson does a good job, but I don't think his look fit the appearance of McMurphy's character as described in the book. The same goes for a few other characters; maybe appearance could have been focused on more. The extremely detailed and expanded plot of the book left a lot to be done in the movie adaptation, which unfortunately didn't quite develop as strongly as I would have liked. Many of my favorite details from the book were skipped or completely changed in the movie. The book is narrated by the character Chief, who provides a unique insight towards the mind of a patient in a mental institution. Chief, as well as many other supporting characters, were only partially developed as characters. Therefore, I struggled to connect with the characters emotionally while watching the movie, which is something that is important to me while watching a movie. Overall, it was definitely not a bad film on its own; I simply had high standards after reading the book, which made it less enjoyable.
Excellent performances all round by the cast, as well as incredible writing leads to the viewer feeling genuine sympathy for the patients and the conditions they have to handle.

A touching testament to the power of empathy.

Milos Forman lets you understand what it is like confined in an insane asylum in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975). Forman adapts Ken Kesey's novel of the same name into a hilariously insane comedy that leaves you feeling destroyed due to its sincere dramatic finale and motifs.

Forman's direction is as perfectly in tune as the art of filmmaking gets. His allowance of letting actors just perform uninterrupted for minutes on end is revolutionary as is his incredible storytelling at depicting a harsh reality within One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest that never feels fake.

The authenticity of the acting within One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is why I think this film is timeless. Jack Nicholson's leading performance captures a genuine humanity with the range of a madman to a kindly sympathetic force of nature. Nicholson is hilarious and maddeningly entertaining. His choices as Randle McMurphy for each face, voice, and posture are all immaculate. He drives home the movie's sentiment that many of the mad are simply misunderstood and not cared for by those in mental hospitals.

This film has perhaps the greatest supporting cast of any movie. Namely, Louise Fletcher is unimaginably cruel as Head Nurse Ratched. Her belief that she is right and helping is what makes her so scary. Fletcher's performance features biting words and piercing looks that chill you to the bone.

William Redfield is funny as the stuffy and pathetic coward Harding. Will Sampson is brilliant as the apparent mute and deaf Chief Bromden. His massive stature and quiet persona are memorable enough, but his knowing looks and character development are unforgettable. His chemistry with Nicholson is very sweet and touching too.

Furthermore, Danny DeVito is fun as the simple Martini. Nicholson repeating phrases to DeVito's delight is just splendid to watch. Christopher Lloyd is shocking and angry as the constantly enraged Taber. His wide open eyes tell it all.

Then, Brad Dourif is magnificent as the stuttering shy boy named Billy Bibbit. As charming and delirious as Jack Nicholson is, I think Brad Dourif is the most relatable character in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. He is a dramatic weight that presents serious consequences to the events that unfold within the movie. You just feel terrible for Billy thanks to Dourif's tender display of acting.

Notably, Michael Berryman makes an appearance as a silent deformed man named Ellis in a vegetative state that is neat to see him here. Scatman Crothers makes a cameo role as the night watchman Turkle that succumbs to temptation and gives a fierce performance once his job is in jeopardy. It is cool to see Crothers act alongside Jack Nicholson before they appear together in Stanley Kubrick's horror film The Shining.

I also liked Vincent Schiavelli as the quietly mad Frederickson. Lastly, I must commend that endearing and troubled Charlie Cheswick played by the powerhouse actor Sydney Lassick.

Everyone shows up with their best for One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. Certainly Forman's finest film and one for the ages.

Iconic film but just not as good as we remember it. Great acting and THE Jack Nicholson performance (he was always pretty much the same character in all his heyday 70’s films). He is charismatic and its a bravura performance. Yet its not a particularly real or deep one. I’m glad he finally got an Oscar, but Al Pacino in Dog Day Afternoon was far more complex, and in a more difficult part. Cuckoo, while very good, doesn’t age well. Like most anti establishment films, time teaches us, and hindsight takes a toll. How juvenile and 70’s is it to cheer on taking emotionally and mentally fragile men with real problems out to watch you womanize, and setting up the most vulnerable one to get laid? Its adolescent as well as misogynistic. Like thats SO transformative and therapeutic and cool. There is a lot of male college freshman sex humor here, passed off as social statement. Women have no role here other than horrible ballbuster or bimbos used for sex. A good case can be made for this film representing rage at strong women. Louise Fletcher is fine in her one dimensional, and supporting role. But a lead Oscar winner?????!!!!!! Mindboggling. ‘75 was the worst year ever for women in American films. But with all that....the baseball scene is incredible!
Of course for 1975 it is brilliant,it is 10 of 10 but for 2019 it is just really good-it is 8 of 10

Powered by excellent writing and a fantastic performance from Jack Nicholson, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is an incredibly enjoyable and emotional ride for audiences everywhere.

Though this film is one of many timeless Nicholson performances, this cinematic treasure is stitched with a whole cast of masters. Its candid and breathable script allows one to savor every moment of chaos and camaraderie. Forman compels his audience to account for the actions of each individual, but with the compassion his villainess could never muster. When the final trial is paired with consequence, he drives one's convictions straight back to the heart. And from the heart comes the inscrutable truth.

Incredibly absorbing, moving and sometimes funny drama which succeeds in powerfully communicating the despair of life in a brutal mental institution. Jack Nicholson sets the screen alight and Nurse Ratched becomes an iconic sinister antagonist.

"One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is a wonderful adaptation that sparks so many emotions, even if the novel's author refuses to acknowledge its existence. 

First, I want to talk about a particular scene - which might actually be one of my favorites. Toward the end of the film when McMurphy was about to escape, he stopped for a moment. He took a moment to say goodbye to all of the people that he's come to know and care for. There was one in particular, Billy, who seemed awfully beat up about it. When McMurphy went to go talk to him, he realized that Billy was really falling for Candy. When McMurphy had a choice between escaping with ease or staying back to support a friend, he chose the latter. Billy got his time with Candy at the expense of McMurphy's freedom. He did this because he cared for Billy and everyone else there. In my eyes, it was a selfless decision and an easy one for McMurphy to make. While it didn't end the best for either, it was something admirable. After doing research, this scene, apparently, is very similar to how it played out in the book. In the book, McMurphy sacrificed his freedom to give Billy some time with Candy, and the end result of all of that was the same. I love how they kept that major moment true to the both versions of the story, because I think it was a real powerful moment. 

In terms of the structure, I really thought the movie flowed well. I understand that Ken Kesey refused to watch the film because of the major change in POV but in my humble opinion, I think that's arrogance. Books V. Movies are two entirely different mediums of art. You can't really write a book in the same way you would film a movie, and vice versa. I felt like it would've been difficult to tell the story from Chief's perspective in the film, especially if it was through voiceover. I thought the film had this wonderful arc and main protagonist in McMurphy, who was full of personality and ambition. I felt like seeing it through the eyes of McMurphy created this environment and this tone where the men could all come together as a family. McMurphy is the reason they bonded so much more, and I felt that his POV was the most complex / interesting route they could've used for this film.
 
In terms of time, I felt like the film moved within a straight-forward, linear time frame. I don't know the exact time frame that everything happened, but I felt like it couldn't be too long. It didn't seem like it could've been more than 1 month at the most. However, I do think they made the most out of their limited environment. If you think about it, almost the whole story took place in that psych-ward, and it stayed in the same general room. We rarely got outside of that (except for the playground and the boat) but it felt like we were constantly learning more and more about the environment. I never felt bored because we were constantly moving around and exploring new aspects of that place. McMurphy is a big reason why everything felt like it was constantly moving with excitement. 

I think the unity of opposites is a theme we could apply here. McMurphy is so unlike every other patient here. In that, he's also unlike Nurse Ratched. His optimistic personality was contagious, and he differed so much from everyone else in the film. I think his extreme personality was so opposite of everyone else's, but it all mixed together really well. For example, toward the end of the film, his relationship with Chief, who was a silent yet observant man, grew into something amazing. These two essentially became best friends, where McMurphy had Chief's back and Chief had his. Their personalities were opposite but, in the end, they came together. McMurphy changed Chief's life for the better and you can see the impact he had on him. I think that makes the ending especially heartbreaking, when Chief was the one who has to put down McMurphy. McMurphy was someone that throughout the film, nothing could take him down. He was a tough, strong-willed individual who didn't let even the slightest things knock him down. You really didn't know if he was crazy or not. But to see him somber and lifeless toward the end was kind of heartbreaking. For Chief, he had to commit a pity kill. He saw someone, who was his best friend, lose everything that made him, him. It's followed up with Chief running and escaping through the nighttime, doing something that McMurphy never got to do. I think that the unity of opposites worked brilliantly in this film and it was something that really stood out to me. 

In the end, I really enjoyed this film. I felt like everything really came together. The characters were so well-rounded and had so much dimension to them, especially McMurphy. I think the location was used to its maximum potential given how small of a space it really was. I also felt like McMurphy's objective was clear in his want to care for his fellow patients. The entire film really came together and told a great story.
i thought it was a great movie
What a sharp critique of conformity and the establishment. Ceaselessly entertaining.

Murphy, a resourceful convict, pleads insanity in order to avoid heavy physical work and spend the rest of his sentence in a âfriendly environment.â However, when he is committed to the a mental institution he finds himself in a situation in which sadistic medical personnel abuses and humiliates patients, systematically destroying their self-confidence and self-esteem. When Murphy opposes the authority of the head nurse and other staff, an already charged atmosphere brings tensions to a boiling point, eventually resolving Murphyâ(TM)s resistance by electroshocks and lobotomy.

This asylum is an exceptional metaphor of contemporary society. It raises some very serious questions, such as the normalization of the disbalance of power, the political (mis)use of normality and mental illness, the role of repressive mental institutions in maintaining stability of the system, as well as question of obedience to authority and brutal methods that authority uses to preserves its hegemony.

One Flew Over the Cuckooâ(TM)s Nest quickly gained status of a cult movie and became a must-see for all rebellious ones who felt resistance and the thirst for change, as well as the need to fundamentally re-examine the ideological basis of the world we live in. The movie ranked in the top fifty of the American Film Instituteâ(TM)s list and is generally regarded as one of the best films ever made.

In my adolescence, this was unquestionably my favorite and most personally formative film, its themes of nonconformity, antiauthority, struggle and risk striking a deep chord with me. At some point, after reading the novel, I even performed the play as Mac, though I really was just doing my best Nicholson impression (and not a great one at that). While other movies-especially the aesthetically more avant-garde, those that do formally what this cries for textually-have today become new favorites, Forman's brilliant (and only second Hollywood-made) film still makes an impact on me.

Those thematic overtones of the film are still razor sharp, clear as day, yet inevitably challenging to a perpetually stifling status quo. Forman's deft ability to mix the comedic and the tragic, the bureaucratic and the chaotic-an obvious extension of his antiauthoritarian early works of the Czech new wave, though here more refined-finds its perfect setting in a claustrophobic mental asylum. What happens when the inmates take over an already infuriatingly mad system? Who gets to define "crazy"-those who ostensibly *are* or those who are charged with curing the "illness"? In an institution where the doctors have no more claim to knowing than the patients, where the experts are as vegetable-like and dead-to-life as the most failed of cases, the lobotomized, what constitutes a cure whatsoever? Who of these people, the outcasts and the weirdos and the chronics, even need to be cured?

Having now immersed myself in Freud and Lacan in a professional setting, I am now particularly struck by the role reversal between Mac and Ratched. For all her awful efforts, it is Mac who achieves the only breakthroughs in the film-Chief breaking out of his statuesque silence and breaking out of the building, Billy briefly overcoming his stutter, the others learning to stand up for themselves, if only for a moment-while Ratched, in all cases but the Chief's, immediately shuts such breakthroughs down again in order to maintain order. Because for Ratched and her ratchet system, *order* means the functioning of "giving orders." Because "order" here works not to establish a routine that facilitates a cure, but in fact prevents it-in the need to maintain the status quo, I am reminded of that quote attributed to Einstein: "Insanity is doing the same thing over and over but expecting different results."

Well, that was a fun watch. In all seriousness though, immense praise has to be given to both the writing and acting in this movie. Despite any illusions you may have during the first half of the film, 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' is the polar opposite of a fun movie. It goes from uplifting to horrific in an instant, and the unhinged performances and great script meant that for the whole film I honestly had no idea what was going to happen. It's a really interesting and thought-provoking look at mental health and its treatment in the '70s that is just as relevant if not more so today; especially with mental health issues on the incline worldwide. In many ways, the most disturbing aspect of the film is the mindset of the doctors and nurses. They don't see their patients for who they are as individuals, but rather group them all under the rather vague title of 'mentally ill'.

On the back of the Blu-Ray here in the UK, it says it's rated 18 for "emotionally intense scenes", which I thought was a little silly before I watched the movie. Having seen it however, I think that's a fair warning. Some scenes, especially towards the end, really are quite harrowing. It's a hard movie to rate just because of how upsetting it can be. However - especially with time - I get the distinct feeling this will grow on me even more as I come to fully appreciate it. A very powerful movie with an important message to tell.

The movie "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" by Milos Forman from 1975 deserves 3 out of 5 stars because of the actors, the director, and the how closely it followed the book. 

The actors, played a pretty good from the time frame that was made in. The actors that they chose really did the characters justice from the book, but the script writers left a lot of the book out in the movie. It was very confusing trying to put the parts of the books and the movie together and how the characters matched up to the actors playing the characters in the movie. I thought that the Director Milos Forman did a good job selecting the actors to play the parts but horrible scripted writers. I know that the movie needed to be around two hours long but there is a lot of the parts that are good that were left out and changed. Lets go to the part where the fishing trip accord. The scripted writers thought it was they stole the bus but in the book the doctor and another person went with along on the trip. There is a lot of parts that I could mention but I would recommend reading the book and see for yourself. It didn't follow the book really closely events that were key in the book and there left out of the book. If you were wanting to watch a classic move and you have time to waist I would recommend watching the movie, but I would read the book first then watch the movies so you can see the missed events that were in a book.

The movie "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest", is based off of the book. The book is narrated by patient at a ward in the United States, presumably in the late 1900's. The narrator, Chief, is a 6'8" Native American who pretends to be deaf and dumb. The movie however, is shown through the point of view of Randal P. McMurphy. The movie is much faster pace than the book and much of it is cut out or altered for time. I personally didn't like the acting in the movie and think many of the characters did not match the descriptions given by the book. I also thought it was unrealistic when McMurphy rolled over a barbed wire fence without a scratch. It seemed like the movie just pulled random scenes from the book and didn't have much of a story line. Overall I give this movie two stars.

The Movie One Flew Over Cuckoo's Nest was directed by Milos Forman, made in 1975, and the main character we Randle P. McMurphy played by Jack Nicholson. Most of the actors of the film were very much like the actors described in the book. The only different character seemed to be Randle P. McMurphy because in the book he was described as a huge redhead that looked very manly however he didn't. Chief was pinpoint accurate on the way they described him and same with the nurses and patients. I rate the movie "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" directed by Milos Forman and produced in 1975 three out of five stars based on three criteria including how well the movie followed the book, the emotional connection between audience and characters, and the soundtrack. 

The first criterion I used was how well the movie followed the events of the book. In this category, I give the movie four stars because the movie did follow the same plot and the characters generally have the right personality and role. However, the movie did skip some events that occured in the book that I would have liked to have seen in the movie. For example, I was disappointed that the narrator of the book, Chief Bromden, was absent in several major events in the movie. Although the events of the movie do play a vital role in its quality, the underlying emotion that the audience feels during the event is also important. The second criterion I used was how well the movie developed an emotional connection between the audience and characters. In this category, I give the movie two-and-a-half stars. The book goes into detail to describe several scenes from Chief Bromden's past and to explain the reasons that several of the patients are at the hospital, but the movie almost completely excludes all of these allusions into the patients' lives. This leaves the audience with an almost apathetic feeling toward the characters and the outcome of the plot. Another element of the movie that plays a major role in the audience's emotional experience is the music and noise overlying the events. The third criterion that I used was the effectiveness of the soundtrack. In this category, I give the movie two-and-a-half stars. The soundtrack did not enhance the emotional experience of the movie at all. The majority of the soundtrack did not make sense. Many of the scenes were accompanied by music that did not match its emotional content or that was strange and confusing because it did not clearly convey an emotion at all. Most of the soundtrack served as a distraction because of its lack of compatibility with the visual events of the movie. 

I determined the overall movie rating by averaging the ratings from all 3 criteria. Therefore my overall rating for the movie, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" directed by Milos Forman, is three out of five stars based on my ratings of how well the movie followed the book, the emotional connection between the audience and the characters, and the soundtrack of the movie.

I would give "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", produced in 1975, a 3.8 out of 5 stars because I enjoyed watching the movie. I think that each of the characters/ actors did a phenomenal job on acting their part to make the movie great. I believe that there could not be better actors for the movie. I liked how the Big Nurse acted calm and collected during the movie even when she was upset, and McMurphy was another one of my favorite characters, he always made me laugh during the movie and was a funny character in general. The director, Milos Forman did a great job on directing the movie because each of the characters were in the right place, the scene was set well, and each part made sense. However, I did not like how the movie did not follow the book, written by Ken Kesey. The movie still obtained the main concept and the same ideas about the characters on the ward; however, there are critical parts in the book that did not occur in the movie, as I hoped to. I feel like the movie would've been even better if it followed the book. Overall, I would say that "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is a good movie.

Directed by Milos Forman and is about Randall Patrick McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) who gets transferred to a mental institution, the mental institution is ran by Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher) who tortures her patients and so the high spirited Randall is forced to stay in a very closed-minded hospital. Jack Nicholson gives an outstanding and charismatic performance as R.P. McMurphy and really sells the role extremely well and Louise Fletcher does a terrific job and so does everyone else in the film. Mental illness is shown in a very realistic way and it doesn't sugarcoat any of it. "Power" is a pretty big subject in the film, Nurse Ratched is very power hungry, Randall views the patients as powerless, when Randall was fighting one of the guards Chief viewed him as powerless so thats why chief came in and tried to help him, it is something that occurs a lot. From the beginning shot it shows nature with Native American like music playing, in my opinion the music symbolizes the patients with what sounds like someone crying. At the end of the film the music plays again also showing another shot of nature but in a less crying and in a more uplifting tone to show that the patients are not suffering as much now that Chief has broken the window and escaped free. The classical style music the nurses play I think symbolizes power as it powers over the patients which forces them to shout. R.P. McMurphy gives the patients joy as the film progresses and he cares for the people around him for example when Billie committed suicide he could have just left and went off to Canada but he decided to stay and choke Nurse Ratched. On my first viewing I thought Nurse Ratched wasn't a bad person but just someone doing her job but as I watched it again I am convinced she is a bad person who pressures her patients. I loved Chief's character development throughout the film, at first he starts out as someone who decides to not speak and pretends to be deaf and he still did (except in front of Randall McMurphy) but as the movie goes on he gains courage from Randall and he gains the courage to escape and utilize his strength which was his strong muscles, the first time he utilizes one of his strengths (which was his height) was in the basketball game. The scene where the supervisor comes in and the patients and Turtle hide is an extremely funny scene but I also felt anxious in the same time thinking if they were to get caught. one of the themes I got from this film was that people with mental illness are not dumb and can think for themselves. This is a film I highly recommend, the film is great in both emotionally and aesthetically and if you haven't checked it out you should.

(btw I haven't read the book but I will in my senior year of high school so wish me luck)

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is brimming with memorable characters. Films today just don't have that sense of story and character, it's more visual narrative and overacting. There's no overacting here, every performance is understated in their own unique way. Nurse Ratched, played by Louise Fletcher, is cool, calm and collected and yet her mannerisms exude terror. Her authoritative figure and soft spoken voice just adds to this, so much so that the patients in the state mental hospital are petrified of her. Randle McMurphy, played by Jack Nicholson, is just a common criminal who to start with plays along with the other patients. However, upon the realisation that he may not ever get out...he starts to find ways in order to escape. I found his performance captivating and clearly he is great and portraying crazy people, just look at The Shining. He is able to control the smaller scenes with his charisma and own the bigger crazier scenes with his excitable energy. His raucous behaviour puts the other patients at risk of certain procedures such as the controversial electro therapy. What really compelled me was the similarities between the mental patients and the outside world, to which McMurphy says that there is no difference. The screenplay for that scene, well every scene actually, brings life to each character. From the first 30 minutes, every character's personality and state of mind is indicated to us. There are no boring characters, each of them have unique qualities and that is something you don't see in every film. Loved the fishing boat scene, adored Chief's and McMurphy's friendship and appreciated the time and effort spent on character interactions. The way they talk to each other in the therapy sessions just felt natural, and to balance the screen time between them all was just genius. You just don't get films like these anymore.

With a magnetic performance from Nicholson and a superbly written script that pits his unruly, wilful character against a worthy foe in the form of the head nurse of the mental institution that he finds himself in, 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' is a fascinating film that explores a number of social issues within the microcosm of the setting. There are a few places where it drags here and there, but for the most part, it is simply a joy to watch the effect that one man armed with self-confidence and a very different attitude can have on those who have all but given up on themselves.

Led by powerful and versatile performances from Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher, this film manages to be an emotionally engaging drama and a thought-provoking critique on society and culture that leaves viewers thinking onward.

I feel that my movie relates directly to the Beat Generation. Mac teaches the other inmates to rise up for what they believe in and to challenge the ideals of the ward. This can be seen as a metaphor to the men of the beat generation, who inspired others to rise up and challenge conforming to the post War ideals of settling down with a wife, having kids, and living in a 'white picket-fence' world. Although Mac was not successful in his attempt to escape, his real success was teaching those men that they should not be ashamed of who they are and how they should lead their lives. The lasting quote that I will remember is from Mac, talking to the group. "What do you think you are, for Chrissake, crazy or somethin'? Well you're not! You're not! You're no crazier than the average asshole out walkin' around on the streets and that's it."  Mac's inspiration towards the other inmates will leave a lasting impression on them, and the lesson I learned from this movie, is everyone is a little crazy. But who cares? No one is even perfect so why not have a little fun? Be a little crazy! I think Mac's motto in life was to live life fun, rather than to die being boring.
